Name: Cluck and Trowel
Bio/Story:
Cluck & Trowel is a small, passionate family farm nestled in the coastal town of Little Compton, Rhode Island. A relatively new presence in the Farm Coast's agricultural tapestry, Cluck & Trowel is already making a name for itself with a dedicated focus on quality, sustainability, and community. Their name evokes both the playful spirit and hard work that define their approach to farming.

Certified organic by Baystate Organic Certifiers, the farm produces a vibrant and varied yield. They specialize in pasture-raised eggs, heritage pork, poultry, and a range of seasonal vegetables cultivated from late winter through the end of the fall harvest. Their greenhouse hums with life starting in February, and they pride themselves on nurturing each crop with careful intention and organic methods.

At the heart of Cluck & Trowel's mission is a commitment to healthy, flavorful food that strengthens the bond between land, farmer, and consumer. Their flocks of heritage breed hens serve as a daily example of this ethos—carefully selected for both their beauty and natural instinct, raised organically on soy-free feed. Whether through their CSA programs or online pre-order farm stands, Cluck & Trowel invites the community to eat well and connect deeply with the source of their food.
Hours: Mon‑Sat 9 AM‑5 PM; Sun closed

Name: Cold Spring Farm
Farm Type: Beef, Pork, Poultry, Produce, Honey, Syrup, Eggs
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the rolling countryside of Colchester, Connecticut, Cold Spring Farm is stewarded by Jeff and Jess, a couple brought together by their shared love of cultivating food and community. Their story began in the bustling heart of a farmers’ market, where Jess was running her own farm venture and Jeff was helping lead the market. A chance meeting turned into a shared mission to nurture the land and build a life rooted in hard work, sustainability, and the joy of growing nourishing food.

At Cold Spring Farm, growth is more than agricultural—it's personal. The farm thrives by working in harmony with nature, nurturing the soil with microbial life to feed the plants, which in turn, nourish the community. Their guiding philosophy is simple yet profound: by collaborating with nature rather than controlling it, they produce vibrant, healthy food that benefits everyone. This dedication is visible in every crisp vegetable, fresh egg, and lovingly harvested fruit they offer.

Community engagement is central to the Cold Spring Farm ethos. Through programs like CSA shares and work share opportunities, Jeff and Jess invite neighbors and visitors alike to take part in the farm’s daily rhythm. Whether shopping at the farm stand, joining a CSA, or volunteering in exchange for produce, patrons become part of a larger, purposeful cycle of giving, growing, and gratitude. In every season, Cold Spring Farm stands as a testament to the power of passion, partnership, and a commitment to cultivating a better future.
Address: 46 Lake Hayward Town Rd, Colchester, CT 06415

Name: Confreda Greenhouses and Farms
Bio/Story:
With a legacy that stretches back over 90 years, Confreda Greenhouses & Farms has become a cornerstone of Rhode Island agriculture. Located in the heart of Western Cranston, the farm has been passed down through generations of the Confreda family, each one committed to upholding the traditions of quality and community that define the business. What began as a modest endeavor has blossomed into one of the state’s most celebrated destinations for fresh produce, plants, and gourmet offerings.

The Confreda family story is rooted in a deep respect for the land and a passion for farming that spans nearly a century. Their commitment goes beyond simply growing crops; it includes an ongoing dedication to sustainable practices and maintaining a bee-friendly environment to support both pollinators and healthy ecosystems. This conscientious stewardship has not only earned them the trust of their customers but also accolades such as Rhode Island GAP Certification.

Today, Confreda Greenhouses & Farms continues to evolve while staying true to its core values. The farm market remains a vibrant hub for fresh food and seasonal delights, offering everything from greenhouse plants to specialty gourmet foods and baked goods through its popular pie fundraising program. At its heart, Confreda’s mission is to nourish the local community—cultivating not just crops, but also the bonds between neighbors, heritage, and the local food economy.

Name: Copps Island Oysters
Bio/Story:
Copps Island Oysters is a fourth-generation, family-owned shellfish farm located in Norwalk, Connecticut—long revered as the historic “Oyster Town” of the East Coast. The business was formally founded in 1994 by Norman Bloom, though its roots trace back to the 1940s when his father, Norm Sr., and uncle Hillard began reviving Connecticut’s shellfish industry after its collapse in the mid-20th century. Today, with a fleet of 15 boats and thousands of acres of natural oyster beds, Copps Island continues to supply restaurants and consumers across the country with some of the freshest, most sustainably farmed oysters available.

Norman Bloom & Son is known for operating one of the last traditional, wild-harvest oyster farms in the United States. Their shellfish are cultivated using age-old seafloor farming techniques across the Norwalk and Westport Island chain—where sandy bottoms and nutrient-rich, fast-moving tides create ideal conditions for plump, sweet oysters with a signature briny bite. The company harvests daily, ensuring unmatched freshness and quality. Their product line also includes clams and lobsters, all available year-round, along with a retail line of shucking tools, cookbooks, and skincare products made from their own sugar kelp farm.

Sustainability is at the heart of everything they do. From rigorous water testing and environmental partnerships to their kelp cultivation and local conservation efforts, Copps Island Oysters embodies a full-circle commitment to both ocean health and community. What began as a single boat and a few oyster grounds has blossomed into a legacy carried forward by Norm’s children, Jimmy and Jeanne, who are preserving the tradition while embracing innovation. Whether you're visiting their retail shop in Norwalk, enjoying a catered raw bar at your next event, or simply savoring their oysters at home, you're experiencing a living heritage—one that's been shaped by the tides, the land, and generations of hands that still work them.
Hours: Retail Hours (Norwalk): Wednesday: 9:00 AM – 4:00 PM Friday & Saturday: 9:00 AM – 4:00 PM Closed Thursday

Name: Coruscant Farm
Bio/Story:
Founded in 2014, Coruscant Farm is a labor of love by the Jenne Family, rooted in the peaceful countryside of Ashford, Connecticut. The farm is a close-knit family venture, with Ginger leading the horticultural efforts with her green thumb, Doug applying his engineering skills to maintain the infrastructure, and their son helping feed animals and tend the garden. With their combined efforts, they've created a farm that honors heritage breeds and time-tested growing methods.

The philosophy at Coruscant Farm is built on gentleness and sustainability. They practice no-till agriculture, eschew harmful chemicals, and avoid antibiotics and hormones. Their Red Devon cattle are grass-pastured in warm seasons and raised on local hay in the winter, receiving attentive, humane care throughout the year. Their pasture-raised chickens are on the field year-round, foraging freely and producing well-loved eggs for the community.

Beyond meat and eggs, Coruscant Farm cultivates heirloom vegetables, fruits, and nuts, rotating crops and exploring unique seed varieties for each season. They offer garlic, melons, tomatoes, and more, much of it grown with compost, biochar, and vermicompost on-site. Their commitment to quality and care is evident in every offering, whether it’s a pasture-raised chicken or a naturally grown loofah sponge. Coruscant Farm embodies the spirit of small-scale, intentional farming devoted to nourishing both the land and the local residents.
Hours: Farmstand always open, contact for meat sales

Name: Cucumber Hill Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the rolling countryside of Western Rhode Island’s historic Moosup Valley, Cucumber Hill Farm is a lovingly run, family-owned destination that opens its gates each fall to welcome friends, families, and visitors from near and far. With a commitment to authentic local farming traditions, the farm has grown into a cherished seasonal retreat, drawing guests with the promise of recreation, connection, and simple rural pleasures.

Cucumber Hill Farm offers a vibrant tapestry of fall activities that engage all ages—from winding corn mazes and bumpy tractor hay rides to friendly axe-throwing contests and pony rides for the little ones. The farm’s grounds transform each autumn into a bustling gathering place where visitors can pick their own pumpkins, enjoy the sights and smells of food trucks, and experience the old-fashioned charm of rural New England.

At its heart, Cucumber Hill Farm is devoted to providing not just entertainment, but also nourishing, locally raised food. Alongside its seasonal attractions, the farm sells its own beef, reflecting a mission to offer high-quality, responsibly raised meat to the local community. Every season may come to a close, but the warmth and authenticity of Cucumber Hill endure, promising a return each autumn, when the leaves begin to turn and the valley once again comes alive.
Hours: Fall Hours: Saturdays 10am-9pm, Sundays 10am-6pm, Fridays 5-9pm

Name: Cupola Hollow Farm
Bio/Story:
Cupola Hollow Farm—also known as Dunai Farm—is a fourth-generation family farm nestled in the preserved farmland of West Suffield, Connecticut. Its story begins in the early 1900s when Lucaz and Celia Dunai, Polish immigrants, first acquired the land. With a deep love for the soil of the Connecticut River Valley, Lucaz expanded the dairy farm into a thriving operation that also grew premium tobacco. This love for the land was passed on through generations, shaping the farm into a cornerstone of the local agricultural community.

After the dairy operation ceased in the late 1970s due to declining milk prices, Lucaz’s daughters, Donna and Kathy, stepped in to preserve the family legacy. They began modestly—converting an old garage into a market stand—and over the decades, their vision and dedication transformed the farm into a multifaceted enterprise. In 2007, aided by a state farm reinvestment grant, they built a commercial kitchen and retail store. By 2009, the family launched a CSA to expand community access to their homegrown produce and artisan goods.

Today, Kathy Dunai and her daughters Amanda and Ashley carry the torch with pride. Cupola Hollow Farm offers an array of handcrafted, small-batch products—from jams and pickles to baked goods and soaps—all made with care and tradition. The farm remains an active participant in regional farmers markets and community events, and its doors are always open to those seeking a taste of Connecticut’s agricultural heritage. With its rolling 59 acres and enduring spirit, Cupola Hollow is more than a farm—it’s a living legacy.
Address: 1510 North Stone Street, West Suffield, CT 06093

Name: Dame Farm and Orchards
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the heart of New England, Dame Farm and Orchards has been a multigenerational family farm for six generations. The family's dedication to the land and its bounty is evident throughout their longstanding stewardship, evolving with each season and generation. What began as a traditional farm has transformed into both a beloved local destination and an enduring symbol of agricultural heritage.

The farm prides itself on offering an inviting space where families can experience nature, tradition, and the seasonal beauty of the orchard. Although the rhythm of modern life and complex regulations have brought their share of challenges, the Dame family remains committed to delivering quality, care, and connection through every apple picked and flower grown.

With their mission rooted in faith, family, and community, the Dames strive to adapt while staying true to their values. They greet each season with renewed energy, welcoming visitors to enjoy the fruits of their labor. For this farm family, every planted seed is a testament to resilience, and every open day an opportunity to share their American-grown legacy with others.

Name: DeCastro Farms
Bio/Story:
DeCastro Farms began its journey in 1961 when Winfield and Ruth DeCastro opened a humble farm stand on their 7-acre parcel in Portsmouth, Rhode Island. Rooted in a deep love for agriculture, they cultivated and sold fresh vegetables directly to their community. Their dedication and hard work laid the foundations of a thriving family enterprise, which they would later pass on to their sons who inherited not just the land, but also their parents' devotion to farming.

Today, DeCastro Farms is proudly operated by the DeCastro family’s next generations — Stephen, Patti, Tom, Rich, and Matthew — who have worked diligently to expand the original farm to over 100 acres. Despite its growth, the farm has stayed true to its tradition of offering local, fresh produce straight from the field. Known throughout Rhode Island for their freshly picked corn, the farm also grows a wide array of vegetables and seasonal flowers. This expansion reflects not just a scaling of operations, but a sustained commitment to quality and community.

Beyond produce, DeCastro Farms showcases its dedication to supporting other Rhode Island businesses by sourcing specialty foods from local producers. Customers can find artisan cheeses, marinated meats, fresh eggs, and local honey — all curated to offer a true taste of the region. With a rich history, strong family values, and a mission rooted in community support and responsible farming, DeCastro Farms continues to be a cherished destination for fresh goods and local flavor.
Hours: Apr‑Dec: Mon‑Sat 8 AM‑6 PM; Sun closed

Name: DeFrancesco Farm Stand
Farm Type: Produce, Dairy, Eggs, Syrup, Honey, Flowers
Bio/Story:
Located in Northford, Connecticut, DeFrancesco Farm has been a proud, family-run operation since 1907. Now five generations strong, the farm has cultivated not just crops, but a deep-rooted legacy in local agriculture. From their greenhouses to expansive fields, the DeFrancesco family has continuously upheld a commitment to nurturing the land that has sustained them for over a century.

In 1995, the farm expanded its reach to the community by opening a farm stand, offering fresh produce and a welcoming atmosphere that makes every visitor feel like part of the family. Dedicated to bridging the gap between grower and consumer, the farm encourages people to shop both onsite and online, making it easier to connect directly with the source of their food.

DeFrancesco Farm stands for more than just commerce—it champions the value of knowing where your food comes from and who grew it. Prioritizing quality over quantity, especially in their flowers and vegetables, the farm continues to offer a personalized, hands-on experience to every customer. Their philosophy is rooted in transparency, care, and the enduring love for both land and community.

Name: Deep Hollow Farm
Bio/Story:
Deep Hollow Farm is a Certified Organic, no-till vegetable farm rooted in the gentle hills of Chester, Connecticut. With a steadfast commitment to sustainable agriculture, the farm provides fresh, nutrient-rich produce to communities in southern Connecticut. The team at Deep Hollow believes in a deep responsibility to both the earth and their neighbors, cultivating food that reflects their values of environmental care and community nourishment.

The farm’s operations are grounded in organic and no-till practices, preserving the integrity of the land while encouraging soil biodiversity and health. This approach allows them to grow vibrant, flavorful crops without the use of synthetic pesticides or fertilizers. By prioritizing soil ecology and long-term sustainability, Deep Hollow Farm emphasizes working with nature rather than against it—a philosophy evident in every head of lettuce and every sun-ripened tomato they harvest.

At its core, Deep Hollow Farm exists to deliver not only delicious and wholesome produce, but also a greater sense of connection to where food comes from. With offerings through their CSA, an online store, and local community events, they invite customers to partake in a shared journey of responsible, healthful farming. From the first sowing to weekly harvests, every act on the farm underscores a pledge to care for the land while feeding and uplifting the people it supports.

Name: Deerfield Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the rolling landscape of Durham, Connecticut, Deerfield Farm stands as a proud steward of tradition and quality. At the heart of the farm are its registered Jersey cows, whose rich, creamy milk forms the foundation of the farm's beloved farmstead dairy products. Every element of their operation speaks to a meticulous commitment to animal care, sustainable practices, and artisanal craftsmanship.

Owned and operated by Melynda, the farm exudes a warm and personal charm. Her dedication is evident in every aspect of the business—from the daily rhythms of milking to the curated selection of goods offered at the farm store. With an unwavering belief in the nutritional and digestible superiority of Jersey milk, she ensures that every customer enjoys a product that is both healthful and delicious.

Deerfield Farm isn't just a place to shop—it's a community touchstone for those who value local agriculture and honest food. Visitors are welcomed with open arms, invited to explore the grounds, and experience firsthand the care and effort behind each gallon of milk or cut of beef. In a world that's increasingly distant from its food sources, Deerfield Farm offers a refreshing return to authenticity and connection.

Name: Devon Point Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the rural hills of North Stonington, Connecticut, Devon Point Farm has cultivated a reputation for raising some of the cleanest and most flavorful meat in New England. Family-owned and deeply committed to sustainable agriculture, the farm is run with a passion for traditional practices, humane treatment of animals, and environmental care. Their pride lies in working with heritage breeds, particularly the American Milking Devon cattle and Red Wattle and Gloucester Old Spot pigs—livestock renowned not just for their history, but for their outstanding meat quality.

Devon Point Farm specializes in 100% grass fed, grass finished beef and pasture-raised heritage pork, offering cuts by the half, quarter, sampler box, and individual selections. Their animals are antibiotic-free, steroid-free, and raised without any synthetic chemicals. The cows are nourished only on lush pasture and hay in the winter months and are never fed grain, ensuring not only pure taste but also clean nutrition. With frequent butcher cycles throughout the year and a thoughtfully managed schedule for pork processing, the farm ensures customers have consistent access to premium meat.

Beyond farming, the team at Devon Point Farm aspires to make a broader impact by supplying “clean meat” to families across the Northeast. Embracing transparency and integrity, they take pride in directly connecting with their customers, accommodating custom orders, and educating others on ethical meat sourcing. Whether you follow a carnivore, paleo, or keto lifestyle—or simply seek high-quality, local meat—Devon Point Farm welcomes all who value tradition, flavor, and food raised right.
Address: 54 Jeremy Hill Rd, North Stonington, CT 06359

Name: Dondero Orchards
Bio/Story:
Dondero Orchards is a cornerstone of South Glastonbury’s agricultural community, celebrating over a century of family-run farming since its founding in 1911 by Joseph and Mary Ann Dondero. Originally immigrants from Italy, the Donderos settled in Connecticut and cultivated a homestead centered on cows, raspberries, apples, and grapes. Their youngest son Edward—affectionately known as Rugged—and his wife Doris continued the tradition, raising apples with their son Eddie and his wife Judy. It was under their care that the beloved “pick your own” experience began, bringing community members closer to their food and to the family behind it.

Today, the farm is operated by Joe and Sandy Dondero, along with their children Joey Jr., Nicholas, Anthony, and Angelina, marking four generations of continuous stewardship. The family has grown the operation into a vibrant, multi-faceted farm business, including farmers markets across the state, a thriving CSA program, a bakery known for award-winning pies and preserves, and a sprawling 7,200 square foot greenhouse. In 2011, Dondero Orchards expanded with the acquisition of Mountain View Farm on Hebron Avenue—land farmed by the Malnati/Sestero family since the 1800s—further deepening their roots in the region.

At its heart, Dondero Orchards is about community and connection—between the land, the growers, and those who gather to enjoy the fruits of their labor. From farm dinners under the open sky to handmade holiday pies, Dondero delivers quality, tradition, and a warm welcome to all. Whether you're savoring sun-ripened berries, wandering through rows of heritage apples, or enjoying a bite from their orchard café, each visit is a reminder of the farm’s timeless mission: to nourish, delight, and bring people together.

Name: Down the Lane Farm
Bio/Story:
Down the Lane Farm began its journey in 1990 when the owners moved into the family homestead. In the early days, they found joy in scouring tag sales for unique furnishings and unexpected treasures. One fateful Saturday in Clinton, a chance discovery of beekeeping equipment set them on a path that would transform their lives and lay the foundation for what the farm is today.

The farm has since blossomed into a haven for artisanal goods, steeped in tradition and care. Specializing in raw honey, handmade beeswax candles, and natural soaps, Down the Lane Farm takes pride in producing high-quality, natural products with meticulous attention to detail. Their candles are crafted from 100% pure beeswax and feature lead-free cotton wicks, ensuring a cleaner and brighter burn with no artificial additives.

At the heart of their mission lies a deep reverence for bees and the vital role they play in our ecosystem. Visitors are welcomed to learn more through the farm's seasonal shop, view their observation hive, and experience firsthand the magic of beekeeping. With accolades like Third Place in Zip06 Best on the Shoreline for three consecutive years, Down the Lane Farm continues to thrive—all thanks to a passionate commitment to quality, sustainability, and community connection.
Hours: Seasonal shop (May 10–Nov 30); Sat & Sun 10 AM–4 PM

Name: Draghi Farms
Bio/Story:
Founded in 1917, E. Draghi & Sons, LLC is a family-run farm that has grown into one of the most beloved agricultural institutions in South Glastonbury, Connecticut. Its story began when Angelo Draghi, an Italian immigrant who arrived in New York with just $15, purchased a rocky farm nestled in the hills of Foote Road. With determination and the help of his sons and a loyal draft horse, Angelo transformed the rugged terrain into fruitful orchards, laying the groundwork for generations of farming excellence.

The farm passed through generations, adapting and expanding with the times. In 1968, Angelo’s sons Gino and Andrew acquired the farmstand on Main Street, and in 1980, Gino’s son Darrell joined the business—marking the rise of its third generation. With a passion for horticulture, Darrell introduced greenhouses and launched a robust flower-growing operation, eventually establishing six greenhouses including a state-of-the-art sales house. The bakery was later added, and quickly became known for its wide array of scratch-made pies, breads, cookies, quiches, and more.

Today, E. Draghi & Sons continues under Darrell’s stewardship, with the loyal support of his mother Sandra, sister Cheryl, and a dedicated team. The farm is a celebration of tradition, seasonal abundance, and hospitality—from daily baked goods and native produce to custom flower arrangements and holiday offerings. Whether stopping by for a pie or picking up Christmas greenery, customers are welcomed like family into this enduring legacy of local agriculture.
Hours: Open daily from 7:00 AM – 6:00 PM (until November 1), After November 1: 7:00 AM – 5:00 PM, Open seasonally from late April until December 24

Name: Earth’s Palate Farm
Bio/Story:
Earth’s Palate Farm is a regenerative haven nestled across 40 acres in the hills of Warren, Connecticut. Established in 2018 by husband-and-wife duo Renee Giroux and Kevin MacPherson, the farm is a living expression of ecological stewardship, culinary artistry, and devotion to community. The land features four greenhouses and a small field plot where heirloom vegetables flourish year-round, alongside pastured meat birds, heritage pork, and 100 foraging hens. Every corner of the farm reflects their deep commitment to soil health, animal welfare, and nutrient-rich, chemical-free food.

Renee brings nearly two decades of agricultural experience grounded in international practices—from Korean Natural Farming to biodynamics and plant homeopathy. Her methods prioritize the intelligence of nature, using holistic inputs and rhythm-aligned growing strategies to foster resilient ecosystems. Meanwhile, Kevin—trained as a pastry chef in Paris and seasoned across the globe—leads the farm’s acclaimed bakery. His small-batch pastries and confections are both refined and rustic, using herbs and produce from the land to reflect the farm’s unique terroir in every bite.

Together, Renee and Kevin have cultivated more than just crops. They’ve cultivated trust. Through CSA shares, “Farm Bucks,” weekend markets, and a bakery beloved for its tarts and croissants, Earth’s Palate Farm has become a vibrant hub for food lovers who seek integrity from field to fork. Each harvest and handcrafted loaf is a reminder that true nourishment begins with love for the land—and ends in a community fed by its gifts.
Hours: Farm Stand Pickup: Saturdays, 10:00 am – 1:00 pm, Farm Stand: Self-serve, open dawn to dusk

Name: East Meadow Farm & Orchard
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the quiet farming community of Coventry, Connecticut, East Meadow Farm and Orchard occupies a pastoral landscape long dedicated to agriculture. The current stewards of the land are committed to breathing new life into its soil, practicing sustainability through organic farming techniques. Their work reflects a blend of tradition and ecological stewardship, renewing the land’s purpose with an eye toward harmony with the natural world.

The farm centers its operations around producing organic seedlings, orchard fruit, and berry plants—all cultivated without the use of chemical pesticides. Inspired by the thoughtful philosophy in One Good Apple by Catherine Paladino, East Meadow Farm and Orchard is driven by the belief that healthy, thriving plants are integral to both ecological well-being and human nourishment. Every sapling and fruit is a testament to their dedication to biodiversity and lasting soil vitality.

Today, the farm is entering its ninth season with a renewed vision and deepened roots. As they prepare for 2025, the team continues to grow and offer an expanding selection of organic fruit, eggs, and garden-ready plants. East Meadow Farm and Orchard has become more than a place of production—it is a flourishing example of sustainable living, connecting the community with good food cultivated with care and conscience.
Hours: Daily 10 AM–5 PM in May‑June; Sat 10 AM–4 PM mid‑July–mid‑Oct

Name: Eastford Farm
Bio/Story:
Tucked in the rural landscape of Eastford, Connecticut, Eastford Farm, LLC is a proud family-owned farm dedicated to producing nutritious, ethically raised meat. With a strong commitment to transparency and responsible farming practices, the farm emphasizes quality over quantity, specializing in soy-free varieties of chicken, pork, and lamb. Their mission is clear: to offer wholesome food that supports both the well-being of their animals and the satisfaction of their community.

Over the years, Eastford Farm has built a solid reputation for its no-compromise approach to feed ingredients. By eliminating soy from their animal diets, the farm provides an alternative to conventional meat products, appealing to health-conscious consumers and those with dietary sensitivities. This careful attention to detail is a hallmark of their operation and reflects the care taken in every step of their farming process.

More than just a place to purchase food, Eastford Farm fosters a connection between land, animal, and customer. Through their presence on social media and community participation, they keep customers engaged not only with products and recipes but also with farm life, including quirky characters like Scramble the Duck—Eastford’s lighthearted weather forecaster. In every interaction, Eastford Farm invites customers to be part of their story—one rooted in family, integrity, and good food.
Address: 76 Weeks Rd., Eastford, CT, United States, Connecticut

Name: Easy Pickin’s Orchard
Bio/Story:
Easy Pickin’s Orchard is a diversified farm located on Bailey Road in Enfield, Connecticut. For years, the farm has served as a trusted source for local, sustainably grown produce, offering a wide array of fresh fruits and vegetables straight from their fields to the tables of their community. Deeply rooted in the principles of responsible agriculture, Easy Pickin’s emphasizes environmental stewardship, healthful food, and education through direct farm experiences.

With a robust CSA program, on-site farm stand, and strong farmers’ market presence, Easy Pickin’s offers customers multiple ways to access their produce. Their pick-your-own model invites families and individuals to engage with farming firsthand—wandering among rows of berries, orchard fruit, vegetables, herbs, and flowers in-season. It’s a space designed for connection: to food, land, and community.

Though the farm stand closes for the winter, Easy Pickin’s continues to offer online orders year-round and participates in winter markets across Ellington and Suffield. Their offerings include not only produce but also frozen fruits, jarred goods, firewood, and handmade items. With flexible CSA options and a “Weekly Welcome” alternative for newcomers, Easy Pickin’s makes it easy to support local, eat seasonally, and stay rooted in the rhythms of New England’s growing seasons.
Hours: July - October: Monday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday: 9:00am - 12pm, Tuesday & Thursday: 4:00pm - 6:30pm, Saturday & Sunday: 9:00am - 5:00pm

Name: Eddy Farm
Bio/Story:
Eddy Farm, nestled on 60 acres in the heart of Newington, Connecticut, is a fourth-generation family farm deeply rooted in history and intention. Once the home of Captain Martin Kellogg—who survived a childhood capture by the Iroquois and later returned to Newington to start anew—the land has witnessed over two centuries of agricultural evolution. It was in 1960 that Roger W. Eddy and his wife Deborah Bankart formally established the farm stand that still flourishes today. Their daughter Lucy carried on the family legacy, working passionately to protect the land from development, ensuring it would remain forever green and agriculturally vibrant in a modern suburban landscape.

Today, Lucy’s daughter Haley and her husband Andy Billipp are the stewards of Eddy Farm, honoring the past while breathing new life into its soil and spirit. Haley, a Rhode Island native and Yale-trained designer with roots in traditional Swedish woodworking and culinary arts, met Andy—a blacksmith, writer, and former ranch wrangler—in Colorado. Together, they pursued a land-based lifestyle, hunting, growing, and preserving their own food before returning to Connecticut to take over the farm in 2011. Since then, they’ve grown the farm into one of the largest producers of chemical-free cut flowers in the state, and their produce continues to be a seasonal favorite at their roadside farm stand.

Eddy Farm’s growing philosophy is rooted in health and sustainability. Though not certified organic, they grow everything without synthetic fertilizers, pesticides, or herbicides, instead prioritizing soil mineral balance as a natural defense. This careful stewardship ensures not only the long-term vitality of the land but also the highest-quality, most flavorful produce and flowers. From peak-ripeness tomatoes to stunning heirloom mums, the farm’s bounty is a reflection of its values: beauty, resilience, and an unshakable commitment to integrity.
Hours: July 1 – mid-October, 7 days a week Monday to Friday: 10:00 AM – 6:00 PM Saturday & Sunday: 10:00 AM – 5:00 PM Closed for the season outside of these months.

Name: Evergreen Berry Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled among forest, field, and ponds in the rolling Litchfield Hills, Evergreen Berry Farm in Watertown, Connecticut is a living testament to the power of persistence, stewardship, and family legacy. Established in 1979 by Bob and Cathee Alex, the farm began as a vision rooted in childhood memories and a passion for the land. The original 27-acre parcel—once an untended mix of cornfield and wetlands—was lovingly transformed over decades into a biologically managed haven for fruit, flowers, and pollinators.

The farm initially blossomed as a thriving blueberry operation, with over 7,000 bushes meticulously planted and nurtured through the 1980s and beyond. But Evergreen’s evolution is also a story of adaptability. When conventional farming methods proved unsustainable, Bob made the courageous shift in 2012 to fully organic and biological practices—eschewing synthetic inputs in favor of compost tea, fish hydrosylate, hand-weeding, and soil revitalization techniques. This transition renewed not only the health of the land but the farm's spirit. Over the years, Evergreen expanded to include blackberries, elderberries, and raspberries, and ultimately restructured as an LLC with an eye toward multi-generational succession.

Today, as weather patterns shift and crops face new challenges, Evergreen has entered its next chapter. In 2024, after 45 years of blueberry cultivation, Bob and Cathee retired the berries that once defined the farm. In their place, a sweeping wildflower meadow now flourishes, serving as a sanctuary for native bees, butterflies, and birds. Black raspberries remain the farm's seasonal treasure, grown in deeper, more resilient soils. With each visitor who picks a berry or a bouquet, the legacy of love, resilience, and stewardship continues. Evergreen Berry Farm stands not just as a place of harvest, but as a living narrative of how to care for the earth—and one another.
Hours: Black Raspberry Season (Early–Mid July): 8:00 AM – 12:00 PM daily while berries last Post-Berry Season: Occasional pop-up wildflower bouquet days; check social media for dates

Name: Fairholm Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the rolling hills of Woodstock, Connecticut, Fairholm Farm is a proud fourth-generation family dairy committed to sustainable farming and exceptional animal care. Since its founding in the early 1900s, the farm has evolved through decades of innovation, hard work, and dedication to the land. Today, it remains a vital part of the local agricultural landscape, blending time-honored traditions with modern practices.

Owned and operated by the Miller family, Fairholm Farm raises registered Holsteins and Jerseys using robotic milking systems that ensure comfort and optimal health for the herd. The farm's holistic approach includes sustainable soil management, locally grown feed, and meticulous stewardship of its pastures. Community engagement is also at the heart of the operation, with opportunities for educational visits and firsthand experiences in farm life.

At the on-site Dairy Store, customers can enjoy the freshest products straight from the source. Whether it's rich, creamy milk or a scoop of local ice cream, everything offered reflects Fairholm's unwavering standards of quality. The store also showcases an array of locally made pantry items, from honey to homemade jam, reinforcing the farm’s mission to support regional artisans and provide wholesome, traceable food for their neighbors.
Hours: Monday–Friday: 10am–6pm, Saturday–Sunday: 10am–5pm

Name: Farmer Joe’s Gardens
Farm Type: Produce, Dairy, Eggs, Syrup, Honey, Flowers, Microgreens
Bio/Story:
Nestled in Wallingford, Connecticut, Farmer Joe's Gardens is more than just a local market—it's a vibrant community hub where agriculture, education, and healthy living flourish. The farm is deeply rooted in the values of sustainability and transparency, with programs that build a genuine connection between customers and their food. Through their Farmer Harvest Program (CSA), they provide meticulously cultivated weekly baskets, teeming with fresh, seasonal flavors and the labor of love from a dedicated grower.

Beyond their CSA offerings, Farmer Joe's Gardens invites the public to engage directly with agriculture through unique animal experiences like ‘Rent The Chicken’ and ‘Hatch The Chicken’. These interactive programs are designed not only to educate but also to reconnect individuals and families with the origins of their food in a tangible, heartfelt way. Serving all of Connecticut and nearby regions, they make agriculture accessible and personal, one chicken rental at a time.

At its core, Farmer Joe's Gardens is dedicated to encouraging healthier lifestyles and protecting the environment. Through initiatives that highlight clean eating and responsible growing practices, the farm strives to be a catalyst for positive change. Whether you're stopping by for local honey, artisan pantry goods, or farm-fresh eggs, the experience is steeped in authenticity and care, shaped by people who believe that every meal should nourish both body and community.
Hours: Mon‑Sat 9 AM–6 PM, Sun 9 AM–2 PM

Name: Fat Stone Farm
Bio/Story:
Tucked away in Lyme, Connecticut, Fat Stone Farm has been crafting farm-based products since 2014, building a loyal community of customers who value quality, simplicity, and authenticity. What started as a small operation soon blossomed into a beloved local brand found in over 70 shops across Connecticut. Its story is rooted in a passion for natural wellness and a love for rolling up sleeves to create wholesome offerings directly from the land.

At the heart of Fat Stone Farm is a signature product: the Elderberry Apple Shot — a beloved tonic that underscores the farm’s focus on natural, healthful ingredients. From rich maple syrups made with painstaking care to handcrafted elderberry gummies and vibrant vinegar infusions, every item reflects the farm’s commitment to both tradition and innovation. There’s no flashy storefront, just an honest invitation to experience the farm through its goods — either online or at local retailers.

Fat Stone Farm’s mission is simple: delight customers with pure, thoughtfully made products that nourish both body and soul. They’ve carefully curated their catalog to include not only farm-created staples but also playful and practical innovations like elderflower soap or soda syrups perfect for cocktails. With a promise of quality backed by a 30-day money-back guarantee, the farm operates on trust, transparency, and an unwavering dedication to excellence.
Hours: By appointment/online orders

Name: Fernandes Farmstead
Bio/Story:
Fernandes Farmstead is a small, family-owned and operated farm located in Manchester, Connecticut, where multiple generations of the Fernandes family work together to provide the community with exceptional, ethically raised food. Managed collaboratively by parents Manuel and Lurdes Fernandes and their children, the farm embodies a deeply rooted commitment to traditional, transparent, and responsible farming practices.

Focused on quality over scale, Fernandes Farmstead raises grass-fed beef, pasture-raised pork, free-range chicken eggs, and raw local honey. Their animals are raised with care and respect—grazing on open pastures and living as naturally as possible, without the shortcuts of industrial agriculture. Customers frequently praise the freshness and superior flavor of the farm’s meats, often noting that it’s the best they’ve ever tasted.

Open twice a week for on-farm pickups, Fernandes Farmstead offers a welcoming and straightforward purchasing experience. With beef and pork shares available and a simple payment system (cash or Venmo), they make it easy to support local, sustainable agriculture. Their products reflect not just a livelihood, but a family’s passion for feeding their neighbors well.
Hours: Thursdays 4 - 6 p.m. Saturdays 10 - 1 p.m

Name: Festival Farm (NEED PICS)
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the picturesque town of Hope Valley, Rhode Island, Festival Farm offers a slice of traditional New England charm. Operating at the corner of Route 3 and Canonchet Road, this local favorite weaves together agriculture, community, and family activities to create a welcoming, down-to-earth experience. From plant starts and hanging baskets in the spring to pumpkins and Indian corn in the fall, the farm adapts its offerings with the rhythm of the seasons, ensuring there's always something fresh and vibrant to explore.

Festival Farm is more than just a place to shop for fresh produce—it’s a cherished gathering spot where families come to reconnect with farm life. Each weekend, children delight in pony rides and hayrides pulled by a vintage Farmall tractor, creating lasting memories in a setting that wholeheartedly embraces the motto “The Way Things Used To Be.” Visitors can enjoy fresh items from the gardens and greenhouses, as well as carefully sourced goods from local farmers and artisans.

At the heart of the farm’s charm is its Country Store, home to the Yankee Pantry—a curated collection of mouthwatering jams, jellies, relishes, and baking mixes. Farm Fresh Eggs from local farmers are a beloved staple, while festive offerings like maple syrup and handpicked apples make every season feel special. With its blend of rustic fun, homegrown goodness, and heartfelt community spirit, Festival Farm continues to be a destination where tradition lives on and joy is grown year-round.
Hours: Mon/Tue/Thu/Fri/Sat 9 AM‑6 PM; Wed 9 AM‑4 PM; Sun 10 AM‑4 PM
Food Items: Vegetables - Patio vegetable plants Fruit - Apples Eggs - Farm Fresh Eggs Pantry/Other - Jams - Jellies - Relishes - Baking mixes - Maple syrup

Name: Field House Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the coastal town of Madison, Connecticut, Field House Farm is a charming, small-scale homestead that celebrates thoughtful stewardship of land, food, and community. With a reverence for slow food and sustainable agriculture, the farm has become a cherished destination for seasonal dinners, children’s educational programming, and the thoughtful production of nutrient-rich local food. Owned and operated by Stephanie Lesnik, Field House Farm reflects the values of care, intention, and authenticity in every aspect of its offerings—from pasture-raised meats and organically-raised bees to community-centered events that bring neighbors together around the table.

At the heart of the farm’s calendar are its celebrated Field-to-Table Dinners. These intimate gatherings bring guests into the rhythms of the land, beginning with a stroll through the farm and ending with candlelit meals crafted by renowned chefs using ingredients grown on-site. Wine pairings, local desserts by Hen & Heifer, and thoughtful conversation turn each evening into a slow celebration of Connecticut’s agricultural bounty. Beyond the dinners, Field House Farm collaborates with artisan partners and neighboring farms to elevate their product offerings, including goat milk skincare from Blazing Sky Farm and maple syrup from Matteson’s Maple Manor.

Though boutique in scale, Field House Farm's commitment to integrity runs deep. Animals are raised with care, without animal byproducts or synthetic inputs. Their Shetland sheep contribute wool for household goods, while their chickens produce vibrant eggs in a rainbow of colors. In every jar of honey, every package of beef, and every heartfelt dinner invitation, Field House Farm offers a profound reminder that real food, when raised with intention, nourishes far beyond the plate.
Hours: By appointment

Name: Finnegan’s Farm, West
Bio/Story:
Finnegan’s Farm, West is more than a farm—it’s a story of love, legacy, and the rebirth of land once forgotten. Located on 17+ fertile acres in New Milford, Connecticut, the property had been a dormant farmstead dating back to the 1700s. In 2012, Bill and Amy, driven by a deep longing to live more intentionally, purchased the land and began transforming it with their own hands. Every structure on the property, from the guesthouse to the chapel, was built using trees milled right on-site, a testament to their craftsmanship and reverence for the land.

The farm reflects their shared commitment to stewardship and sanctuary. Bill, once a carpenter, and Amy, a former elementary school teacher, built this place as a refuge—first for themselves, and now for all who visit. Their vision is grounded in permaculture principles and organic growing methods. Today, Finnegan’s Farm is home to Scottish Highlander cattle, goats, ducks, chickens, and two beloved horses—Ruby Tuesday and Mr. BoJangles—along with a lively crew of barn cats and their watchful Australian shepherd, Finula. From animal companionship to beekeeping and a blossoming maple syrup operation, the land is alive in every season.

The name Finnegan’s Farm, West honors Amy’s Irish roots and a heritage farm still run by her family in Western Ireland. Their chapel, a handcrafted thatched-roof sanctuary, hosts intimate weddings and sacred gatherings, while a yurt and guesthouse invite overnight stays immersed in nature. Whether you come to reconnect with animals, pick up honey and produce from the farm stand, or simply breathe in the stillness of the Litchfield Hills, Finnegan’s Farm, West welcomes you to slow down and savor the quiet magic of farm life.
Hours: The Shack is open 10-5 from June - Oct. on a self serve honor system.

Name: Fire Ring Farm, LLC
Bio/Story:
Founded in 2009 by Nancy Livensparger and her family, Fire Ring Farm has since cultivated more than just crops—it has grown into a cornerstone of community and sustainability in Portland, Connecticut. Perched on four serene acres overlooking the Connecticut River and surrounded by the Palmer Taylor Preserve, the farm honors its placement on the ancestral land of the Wangunk and Quinnipiac peoples. Embracing this heritage, the farm commits deeply to sustainable living and community engagement.

Fire Ring Farm operates as a multifaceted space: a community-supported farm, an herbalist learning hub, and a venue for meaningful events. While not USDA-certified organic, its philosophy and practices are rooted in organic standards—eschewing synthetic chemicals in favor of crop rotation, composting, cover cropping, and natural pest management. This dedication ensures that every aspect of the farm nurtures rather than depletes the environment, maintaining a harmonious relationship with the soil, water, and ecosystems upon which it depends.

With a mission centered on local impact and global awareness, Fire Ring Farm extends a warm invitation to individuals from all walks of life, providing opportunities to reconnect with the origins of their food and the earth itself. As a proud partner of Cultivating Justice, the farm supports inclusive agricultural practices by empowering underrepresented communities in Connecticut. Through education, cultivation, and community celebration, Fire Ring Farm continues to sow the seeds of a more just and regenerative food system.
Hours: By appointment—email for visiting hours

Name: Flamig Farm
Bio/Story:
Tucked in the heart of West Simsbury, Connecticut, Flamig Farm is a cherished family-owned gem that has been nurturing community, animals, and joy since 1907. Founded by German immigrant Herman Flamig, this enduring farm has evolved through more than a century of transformation—from a 12-cow dairy to a bustling egg operation with thousands of chickens, to a flourishing organic vegetable farm. Today, it is known as much for its whimsical spirit as for its heartfelt mission, symbolized by the now-iconic backwards "EGGS" sign that proudly graces the red barn—a piece of art born from creativity and embraced by the town.

The Christensen family, now the stewards of Flamig Farm, have created a multifaceted haven that offers more than your average agricultural experience. Visitors can engage with a vibrant petting zoo, enjoy pony rides and hayrides, celebrate birthdays, attend holistic animal reiki sessions, or even stay overnight in the cozy on-site Farm Stay. Flamig Farm is also a destination for weddings, concerts, and summer camps—always infused with a spirit of joy, education, and harmony with nature. Their commitment to community extends to thoughtful children's programs, seasonal events like Earth Day and Santa visits, and the ever-popular “Eggs Around the World” initiative.

At its core, Flamig Farm believes in optimism and the power of positive thinking. Their mission is to educate and inspire, encouraging all who visit to consider how we might live more consciously and sustainably on this earth. Whether it’s through feeding goats with your toddler, gathering fresh eggs, or exchanging a smile with Farmer Nevin himself, Flamig Farm offers moments of wonder that leave lasting impressions. More than a farm, it’s a living vision—blending tradition, imagination, and the deeply rooted belief that even small experiences can spark big transformations.
Address: 7 Shingle Mill Road, West Simsbury, CT 06092-2311
Hours: Open daily from 9:00 AM – 5:00 PM, April 1 through mid-November (weather permitting)
Food Items:
Animal Products

  • Fresh, organic eggs ($7/dozen)

Name: Forest City Farms
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the fertile soil of the Connecticut River Valley, Forest City Farms operates with a dedication to sustainable agriculture and local community nourishment. Certified organic by Baystate Organic Certifiers, the farm is steadfast in its commitment to environmentally responsible farming practices and producing clean, healthy food.

From its roots, Forest City Farms has embraced the values of stewardship and transparency. Its organically grown offerings are the result of deep respect for the land and a desire to foster meaningful connections between people and their food sources. Though the website offers only a brief glimpse, the location and organic certification suggest a farm that holds itself to high agricultural standards.

Forest City Farms cultivates not just crops, but a philosophy of mindful, ethical food production. The emphasis on organic integrity and regional identity anchors the farm’s place in the wider Connecticut farming community. Its presence within the Connecticut River Valley underscores a legacy of rich farming history and a future rooted in sustainability.
Hours: Farm stand Sat 10 AM–1 PM; sells at Cromwell & Durham farmers markets

Name: Fort Hill Farm
Bio/Story:
Fort Hill Farm is a certified organic farm rooted in the sandy loam of the Sunny Valley Preserve in New Milford, Connecticut. Established in 2002 by Paul Bucciaglia, the farm grew from four bare acres into one of the region’s most respected organic producers, stewarded with care by Paul and his partner Rebecca Batchie. Together with their talented crew, they farm nearly 20 acres using time-honored ecological practices—no synthetic fertilizers or pesticides, just compost, cover crops, and soil-first principles that honor the land’s deep agrarian and Indigenous history.

Paul and Rebecca are a complementary force. Paul holds degrees in agriculture and plant biology and began his path through apprenticeships and CSA management before founding Fort Hill. Rebecca, a trained horticulturist with a passion for food, transitioned from ornamental gardening to farming through her work at the farm and studies in Critical Social Thought. Their shared commitment to sustainability, community nourishment, and high-quality produce powers everything they do.

Today, Fort Hill Farm serves over 300 CSA members through its innovative debit-style Harvest Card, attends multiple farmers’ markets, and sells directly through a bustling on-farm stand. Their offerings span over 225 varieties of vegetables, fruits, herbs, and flowers, including a beloved Pick-Your-Own program and a nationally recognized collection of certified organic dahlia tubers. Fort Hill is more than a farm—it is a living legacy, a place where healthy soil yields not just vibrant food, but meaningful connection.
Address: 18 Fort Hill Road, New Milford, CT 06776
Hours: Farmstand: Tuesday, Thursday, Friday: 2:00 pm – 6:30 pm Saturday: 8:00 am – 12:30 pm Pick-Your-Own (PYO): Tuesday, Thursday, Friday: 1:30 pm – 7:00 pm Saturday: 7:30 am – 1:00 pm

Name: Fort Hill Farms
Bio/Story:
Tucked in the tranquil town of Thompson, Connecticut, Fort Hill Farms stands as a vibrant testament to agricultural heritage and immersive outdoor experiences. The farm is a haven where nature, family, and sustainability converge, offering scenic beauty, seasonal attractions, and hands-on events that embrace the rhythms of rural life. At its heart, Fort Hill Farms is a year-round retreat inviting visitors to stroll through lush nature trails, marvel at curated gardens, and lose themselves in the iconic corn maze every autumn.

Owned and lovingly operated by Jared and Kristin Kies, Fort Hill Farms also includes The Farmer’s Porch—an extension of their working dairy farm and personal dream brought to life. From this roadside farm stand, the family proudly offers local staples like eggs and The Farmer’s Cow milk, with products from the revered Cabot Creamery Cooperative also featured. Their dedication to quality, accessibility, and community roots supports not only their own livelihood, but also helps sustain a local food movement cherished by neighbors and newcomers alike.

The farm’s values of connection, education, and environmental mindfulness shape every interaction and experience offered on-site. Whether visitors come to build gingerbread houses, sip warm soup, or engage in a serene nature walk, Fort Hill Farms encourages all to pause, breathe deep, and energize in the natural world’s simple gifts. Through the seasons, it remains a sanctuary of learning, joy, and genuine New England farming spirit.
Hours: Sunday: 11:00am to 4:00pm; Monday: Closed; Tuesday-Saturday: 2:00pm to 4:00pm

Name: Four Mile River Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the quiet hills of Old Lyme, Connecticut, Four Mile River Farm has carved a trusted name for itself in premium, locally raised meat. The farm's story embodies the enduring tradition of family farming, with a commitment to raising livestock with care, transparency, and pride. Every cut of meat delivered or sold from their farm stand reflects a dedication not just to the craft of butchering, but to the well-being of the animals and land they steward.

Four Mile River Farm markets directly to their local and regional customers, making it easy for families in the Northeast to enjoy responsibly raised proteins. The farm’s philosophy centers on knowing where your food comes from—a belief evident in their diverse offerings, including thoughtfully blended burgers, hand-prepared sausages, and all-beef hot dogs. Each product reflects the farm's values: simple, honest, and flavorful food, carefully made and conveniently delivered or picked up at the source.

Building upon generations of knowledge and passion, Four Mile River Farm maintains a clear mission—to make great meat more accessible without compromising on values. From pasture-raised animals to high-quality customer service, they represent a vibrant example of modern farming rooted deeply in traditional care. Whether shopping online or visiting the picturesque farm stand, customers know they’re tasting the product of integrity-driven agriculture.
Address: 124 Four Mile River Rd, Old Lyme, CT 06371
Hours: Mon–Fri 9 AM–6 PM; Sat–Sun 9 AM–5 PM

Name: Four Root Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the heart of East Haddam, Connecticut, Four Root Farm is a certified organic farm dedicated to cultivating high-quality produce and flowers. Founded with a commitment to ecological stewardship, the farm has grown to embody sustainable practices and a deep respect for the land. Every seed planted reflects the farmers’ thoughtful approach to organic agriculture, driven by a desire to build a more sustainable and resilient food system.

The farm team, led by Aaron and Elise, pours dedication and expertise into every harvest. While Aaron typically fields general and vegetable inquiries, Elise lends her passion and knowledge to all things floral. Their partnership and shared values form the backbone of the farm’s operations, where each decision is grounded in care for both plants and people. Their clearly defined roles support seamless farm coordination and customer service.

Four Root Farm’s produce and flowers are primarily sold at farmers’ markets throughout Connecticut, allowing for direct relationships with their community. The farm also supports its neighbors through CSA options, on-farm pickups, and online ordering. With transparency, integrity, and a genuine love for growing, Four Root Farm continues to flourish as a model of what regional agriculture can and should be.
Address: 257 Tater Hill Rd, East Haddam, CT 06423
Hours: Order Monday 9 AM–Wed 9 PM; pick‑up by appointment on Thurs

Name: Frerichs Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled along the scenic Kickemuit River in Warren, Rhode Island, Frerichs Farm has been a beloved family-owned destination for gardeners and nature lovers since 1986. What began as a humble nursery has flourished into a seasonal sanctuary for those seeking vibrant blooms, expert gardening guidance, and a joyful sense of community. Operated with care by David and Barbara Frerichs, the farm now spans 11 greenhouses bursting with lovingly grown annuals, perennials, and vegetables, carefully tended to during the colder months in preparation for a grand spring reopening each April.

Frerichs Farm is perhaps best known for its festive fall transformations. Each Columbus Day weekend, the farm hosts the Southern New England Giant Pumpkin Grower’s Annual Weigh-Off—an event that draws families from across the region. Other seasonal delights include pumpkin coach rides, whimsical attractions like Windy River Junction, and an abundance of locally grown autumn décor. As winter approaches, David turns his attention to crafting one-of-a-kind holiday pieces, while Barbara fills The Barn Gift Shop and upstairs Loft with ornaments, home goods, and cozy seasonal treasures.

But Frerichs Farm is more than a nursery or farm stand—it is a space of learning, connection, and inspiration. Through their educational resources and their welcoming “Ask Farmer Dave” outreach, the Frerichs have cultivated a place where gardeners of all levels feel supported and inspired. With bees buzzing in the background and the scent of fresh soil and blooms in the air, Frerichs Farm continues to offer not just plants and produce, but a warm invitation to slow down and savor the rhythm of the seasons.
Hours: Mid‑Apr–Jan: Tue‑Sun 9 AM‑5 PM; closed Mon

Name: Full Heart Farm
Bio/Story:
Tucked in the picturesque town of Ledyard, Connecticut, Full Heart Farm is a vibrant testament to family farming and community-driven agriculture. Now in its 14th growing season, the farm is stewarded by Allyson, Keith, and their children Henry, Cora, Sadie, and Lila—whose names are lovingly woven into the fabric of everyday farm life. With a devotion to sustainable practices and heartfelt cultivation, Full Heart Farm has become a cherished provider of specialty vegetables and stunning, diverse flowers across the region.

Operating as more than just a place of production, Full Heart Farm is a cornerstone in its local food economy, supplying fresh produce and blooms to farm stand visitors, restaurants, school cafeterias, and members of its signature FarmShare programs. From seasonal flower shares to summer veggie clubs, everything is nurtured with care and purpose. Their well-known commitment to diversity in crops includes over 300 varieties of vegetables and 125 flower cultivars, purposefully selected to maximize color, flavor, and connection.

At the heart of the farm lies a deeper mission—to nourish both land and community through attentive growing practices and shared abundance. Through workshops, floral events, and wholesale ordering, Full Heart Farm continually expands its role from plot to plate. Though the farm is closed to the public, the bonds it builds through its offerings and outreach bloom as consistently as the flowers it lovingly raises.
Hours: Closed to public; CSA pickup and pre‑order only

Name: Gather Farm (X CSA ONLY)
Bio/Story:
Nestled in Johnston, Rhode Island, Gather Farm is a multifaceted haven where community, sustainability, and creativity intersect. The farm not only offers Community Supported Agriculture (CSA) memberships but also invites visitors to engage with animals and the land through goat experiences, seasonal events, and hands-on opportunities. It represents more than a place — it is a gathering ground that celebrates life’s seasonal rhythms and the connections built around food and farming.

In addition to its agricultural offerings, Gather Farm is home to a vibrant creative space featuring glassblowing classes, live demonstrations, and custom glassware. These artistic initiatives illustrate the farm's commitment to fostering not just sustainability of the land, but also sustainability of the spirit through craftsmanship and shared experiences. The farm seamlessly integrates art into its natural surroundings, making it a destination that nourishes both body and soul.

Gather Café adds yet another layer to the farm’s offerings, with small-batch ice cream, ice cream-making classes, and even bar service for events. These curated culinary experiences enhance community gatherings and private celebrations, establishing the space as a cornerstone of joyful, intentional living. Through its variety of immersive programs and community-centered spirit, Gather Farm continues to grow as a place of nourishment, connection, and creativity.
Hours: No fixed hours; contact for availability

Name: Gazy Brothers Farm
Bio/Story:
Founded in 1918, Gazy Brothers Farm has nourished generations with its steadfast commitment to freshness, family, and tradition. It all began when Grandma and Grandpa Gazsi purchased their original land in Oxford, Connecticut, planting the seeds for a legacy that would span over a century. Their produce supplied local grocers and delis across the Naugatuck Valley, while homemade pickles and sauerkraut from their own cucumbers and cabbage were sold by relatives who ran a local butcher shop. It was a time when food was more than sustenance — it was connection, community, and care.

Today, the fourth generation of the Gazsi family continues to uphold those values. Ed Gazy, along with his wife Alexis, his brothers Pete and Tony, and his children Dominic, Roseanne, Nicholas, and Albert, run the 80-acre farm with heartfelt dedication. Together, they grow roughly 25 acres of vegetables, herbs, flowers, and plants, while also harvesting up to 200 acres of hay annually. The farm uses integrated pest management techniques to ensure healthy crops with reduced reliance on synthetic chemicals, striking a balance between environmental stewardship and flavor-rich produce. During the season, you’ll find them at farmers markets across Fairfield and New Haven counties, as well as at their welcoming roadside stand in Oxford.

Gazy Brothers Farm is not just a place to buy vegetables — it's a way to reconnect with seasonal rhythms, regional bounty, and the heart of Connecticut agriculture. Through their CSA program, flower shares, farm stand, and vibrant presence at weekly markets, the Gazsi family invites the community into their story — one woven through soil, sun, and family heritage. Their deep roots in the land and love for what they grow are evident in every harvest, carrying forward a century-old mission: to feed families freshly, and to do so with joy, pride, and purpose.
Address: 391 Chestnut Tree Hill Rd, Oxford, CT 06478
Hours: Call for hours

Name: Gently Grown Farms
Bio/Story:
Rooted in the heart of Plantsville, CT, Gently Grown Farms is a small family-owned urban farm with a big commitment to wellness, sustainability, and flavor. Specializing in microgreens, transplants, and fresh eggs, this NOFA-affiliated farm takes a gentle, intentional approach to growing—offering soil-grown, non-GMO, pesticide-free greens that are as nutritious as they are beautiful.

Their rotating selection of microgreens includes nutrient-dense varieties like broccoli, radish, kale, pea shoots, and sunflower, alongside chef blends and spicy mixes crafted for both culinary creativity and functional nutrition. In addition to greens, Gently Grown offers fresh gourmet salad mixes, heirloom transplants, dill bouquets, and vibrant eggs from happy hens—all with local delivery available straight to your doorstep.

At its core, Gently Grown is about more than produce—it’s about restoring the connection between food, health, and the Earth. Whether you’re building a salad, stocking your fridge with microgreens, or supporting their year-round CSA subscription, every purchase supports a cleaner food system, grown with care and integrity.

Name: George Hall Farm
Bio/Story:
George Hall Farm has been a cornerstone of organic agriculture in Connecticut since its founding in 1966. Located on Old Farms Road in Simsbury, this multigenerational farm was started by George Hall, a visionary who adopted environmentally safe farming techniques long before they were widely recognized. In 1979, the farm became one of the first in the state to achieve certified organic status, a commitment it proudly upholds today through the Baystate Organic Certifiers.

Now managed by George’s nephew Daren Hall, along with his wife Janet and their three children, the farm spans over 50 acres dedicated to the production of diverse, nutrient-rich vegetables. With the addition of hoop houses to extend the growing season and a deep investment in heirloom and specialty crops, the farm produces high-quality food from early spring through late winter. Alongside produce, the farm is also home to egg-laying hens, honey bees, and pasture-raised pork.

George Hall Farm is more than a working farm—it’s an educational space and a community hub. It offers robust CSA programs, participates in top farmers' markets, and invites the next generation through student programs and internships. Daren’s team of trained oxen, Moe and Curly and Eli and Sam, even contribute to the farm’s unique charm, drawing interest from families and children. Rooted in tradition yet forward-looking in practice, George Hall Farm remains a model for sustainable farming and community-supported agriculture in New England.

Name: Gilbertie’s Herb Gardens
Bio/Story:
Gilbertie’s Herb Gardens is a cherished Connecticut institution—one of the oldest family-run organic farms in the region, now into its fourth generation. Established in the 1920s as a cut flower farm, it has blossomed over the past century into the largest USDA Certified Organic herb grower on the East Coast. With locations in both Westport and Easton, Gilbertie’s has become a destination for home gardeners, chefs, health-conscious families, and plant lovers alike.

At the heart of Gilbertie’s is a deep reverence for soil-grown, organic cultivation. Sal Gilbertie, a third-generation grower and nationally recognized authority on herbs, continues to lead the operation with the same integrity and commitment that defined his ancestors. Every herb, vegetable, and microgreen is grown in carefully blended soil—free of chemicals, nurtured with compost, and watered with UV-treated, bacteria-free water. The result is a nutrient-dense, intensely flavorful product unmatched by hydroponic alternatives. With over 400 varieties of herbs and vegetables and more than 40 microgreen blends, Gilbertie’s offerings serve both retail shoppers and wholesale partners across the Northeast.

But Gilbertie’s is more than a farm—it’s a community hub, a classroom, and a sanctuary for anyone seeking connection to nature. The Westport garden center hosts lectures, plant demos, and seasonal events, while also supporting local nonprofits, schools, and community gardens. Guided by the belief that good food starts with good soil, Gilbertie’s continues to inspire and nourish its community one organic leaf at a time.
Address: Retail Store: 7 Sylvan Lane Westport, CT 06880, Herb Farm & Microgreens: 65 Adams Road Easton, CT 06612
Hours: Westport Retail: Monday – Saturday: 8:30 AM – 5:00 PM Sunday: 10:00 AM – 4:00 PM, Easton Herbs & Microgreens: Monday – Friday: 8:00 AM – 5:00 PM Saturday & Sunday: Closed

Name: Gotta’s Farm
Bio/Story:
Founded in 1898, Gotta’s Farm and Cider Mill is a proud, fifth-generation family farm rooted in Portland, Connecticut. With deep ties to the land and community, the farm has grown into a regional staple known for its commitment to quality and tradition. Over the past century, it has flourished across generations, each one nurturing the soil with care and expanding the legacy of this family-run operation.

Operating from two seasonal locations—Gotta’s Farm on Route 17 and the Quick Pick (QP) Market on Route 66—the business offers an array of fresh produce and pick-your-own fruit experiences featuring strawberries, peaches, apples, and pears. In addition to fruits and vegetables, Gotta’s is a grower of ornamental plants and garden varieties, servicing the region with annuals, perennials, shrubs, and more. For holiday celebrations, the farm embraces the season with a curated selection of Christmas trees and decorations.

Gotta’s Farm also boasts an on-site bakery that produces fresh-baked pies, cookies, and breads—an authentic taste of New England farm life. Alongside their farm stands, they engage with the broader community through participation in three regional Farmers’ Markets. With a steadfast devotion to quality, sustainability, and tradition, Gotta’s continues to be a beacon of agricultural vitality in the Connecticut River Valley.
Hours: Farm & Cider Mill: daily 8 AM–6 PM; QP Market on Route 66 open daily 8 AM–6:30 PM

Name: Grant’s Berry Patch
Bio/Story:
Christopher Grant, a third-generation farmer, launched Grant’s Berry Patch in 1997, inspired by a teenage job at a local dairy farm and a passion for strawberry picking. Unlike his forebears who raised livestock, Christopher envisioned a farm devoted entirely to fruits and vegetables, where community members could immerse themselves in the joy of pick-your-own produce. Over time, he expanded the farm's offerings from a single acre of strawberries to include blueberries, raspberries, pumpkins, and a bounty of seasonal vegetables—anchored by customer favorites like sweet corn and tomatoes.

Together with his wife Michelle, Christopher has woven his family legacy into the soil of Lisbon, Connecticut. The farm now spans over 12 acres, enriched by three greenhouses that extend the harvest season into early June. Beyond the fields, the farm operates a thriving roadside stand, participates in local farmers markets, and supports the community through a Farm Share CSA program. Any excess produce is thoughtfully donated to local food banks, reflecting the Grants' deep-rooted commitment to food accessibility.

Grants Berry Patch is more than a place to purchase produce—it's an experience built on the values of stewardship, sustainability, and authentic connection to the land. The Grants have cultivated not just a farm, but a welcoming, family-friendly environment where every visitor steps into a rhythm shaped by care, community, and the rewards of honest labor. From their meticulously enforced onsite guidelines to their dedication to quality and affordability, the Grants embody what it means to farm with both heart and hands.
Hours: Mon–Fri 9 AM–1 PM; Sat–Sun 9 AM–4 PM

Name: Green Gorilla Farm
Bio/Story:
Green Gorilla Farm is an innovative soil-based microgreen farm rooted in the hills of Torrington, Connecticut. Founded on the principle that true flavor is the proof of nutrition, the farm grows all of its greens in living organic soil—never hydroponics—utilizing a proprietary blend of compost, worm castings, kelp meal, lobster meal, and other natural amendments. This approach mirrors the intricate symbiosis found in nature, resulting in greens that are not only more nutritious, but also bold, vibrant, and full of life.

What sets Green Gorilla apart is a steadfast belief in microbiology and the wisdom of nature. Their irrigation system is fortified with organic molasses, humic acids, and other bio-available nutrients, feeding soil microbes that in turn support plant health and deepen nutrient uptake. The outcome is a microgreen with exceptional shelf life, texture, and flavor complexity—an offering that speaks to chefs, grocers, and home cooks alike.

Led by Ed Patterson, Green Gorilla Farm serves customers across Northwest Connecticut with weekly harvests and a wide selection of specialty blends, from "Wild Wasabi" to "Crimson Crunch." Their packaging is clean, stackable, and retail-ready, and their commitment to their partners extends beyond the product—offering demos, recipes, and tastings to make each collaboration a success. At Green Gorilla, the mission is clear: to prove that when greens are grown the right way, the difference is undeniable.

Name: Gresczyk Farms
Bio/Story:
Tucked into the hills of northwest Connecticut, Gresczyk Farms is a vibrant family-run operation rooted in sustainability, quality, and community. Since its founding, the Gresczyk family has steadily grown their farm into a year-round source of nourishment for households across the region. With 130 acres of vegetables under cultivation, 600 cage-free laying hens, and 1.5 acres of berry patches, they offer an exceptional bounty—whether through their CSA, farm store, farmers' markets, or garden center.

At Gresczyk Farms, everything begins with the seed. From greenhouse propagation to field planting, the farm’s produce is carefully nurtured using Integrated Pest Management (IPM) techniques to minimize environmental impact while maximizing quality. Their farm store overflows with their own fresh produce, sauces, and pork, alongside a curated array of locally made cheeses, pierogis, breads, and much more. Their CSA program—among the most flexible and member-friendly in the state—provides not just seasonal abundance but thoughtful engagement through recipes, education, and community events.

The farm is more than just a business—it’s a local institution with roots that grow deeper every year. From hanging baskets in early spring to heirloom tomatoes and sweet corn in summer, mums in fall, and produce all year round, Gresczyk Farms is woven into the fabric of the New Hartford community. With a deep commitment to affordability, access, and exceptional quality, they continue to raise the bar on what a family farm can be.
Hours: Monday–Saturday: 9:00 a.m. – 7:00 p.m. Sunday: 9:00 a.m. – 6:00 p.m.

Name: Guardians Farm
Bio/Story:
Located in the heart of Connecticut, this farm proudly holds the distinction of being the state's only veteran-owned dairy operation. Anchored in dedication and hard work, the farm represents the values and resilience carried from military service into agricultural life. The owners bring a sense of mission and integrity to their approach, rooted deeply in both service to country and stewardship of the land.

The farm specializes in dairy, with a commitment to quality and animal welfare evident in their day-to-day practices. While full details of their production methods and variety are not explicitly listed, their identity as a dairy operation signals a focus on providing fresh, local dairy products to the surrounding community. Their unique positioning as a veteran-owned entity also speaks to a wider ethos of community engagement and sustainable farming.

Though specific details of their founding or the range of their offerings are not provided, the emphasis on veteran ownership sets them apart in Connecticut’s agriculture landscape. The farm stands as a testament to the power of second chapters—where the discipline and leadership of military service find new life in the quiet strength of rural labor.

Name: Guilford Greens
Bio/Story:
Founded in 2018, Guilford Greens has quickly cultivated a niche as a dedicated purveyor of fresh microgreens in the local Connecticut food scene. Positioned in Guilford, the farm is proud of its commitment to vibrant, flavorful greens that are harvested with care and consistency. From restaurants to health-conscious consumers, Guilford Greens caters to those who value high-quality, nutrient-dense produce.

The farm’s ethos centers on sustainability, health, and community collaboration. Their greens can be found not only at their own farmstand but also at regional cooperatives and natural food markets such as Go Foodworks, Fiddleheads Food Cooperative, and Healthy Planet. This wide availability reflects the farm’s dedication to making wholesome, locally-grown food accessible throughout the area.

More than just a supplier, Guilford Greens engages with its partners and patrons through a continued sharing of ideas and inspiration. Whether through their blog, seasonal offerings, or collaborations with establishments like Bufalina and Rose Vineyards, the farm remains rooted in the belief that nourishing produce should be both delicious and thoughtfully grown.
