Name: Halas Farm Market
Bio/Story:
Halas Farm Market is a living tribute to four generations of Connecticut farming, a story that began nearly a century ago in 1925. Founded by Czechoslovakian immigrant Joseph Halas Sr., the original family enterprise was a self-sufficient dairy farm nestled on Bear Mountain Road in Danbury. With 30 cows, the Halases produced milk, cream, eggs, and other dairy goods for their community. Through the trials of war and loss, the Halas family’s strength and devotion to their land and one another never wavered. Joseph’s son, Paul Halas Sr., returned from WWII to carry on the legacy, eventually founding the Pembroke Road farm market in 1969 alongside his sister “Aunt Peggy.”

The modern Halas Farm Market now flourishes under the care of Michael Halas, the youngest of Paul’s ten children. With a degree in mechanical engineering and a deep love for the land instilled from childhood, Michael reimagined the family farm with an eye toward sustainability. He introduced ecologically responsible practices and constructed a state-of-the-art greenhouse that remains the heart of the business today. Though not organically certified, the farm is committed to safe, chemical-free growing practices, and its fields yield an extraordinary variety of vibrant, nutrient-rich produce.

From the charm of an 18th-century horse barn to the bustling seasonal rhythms of their CSA program, Halas Farm Market is more than a business—it is a legacy of resilience, family, and stewardship. Michael now resides in the restored 250-year-old home beside the market with his wife and three children, the fourth generation of Halases to rise with the sun and tend to the land. Visitors to the farm are welcomed not only by the bounty of fresh vegetables, fruits, eggs, and herbs but by the warm, enduring spirit of a farm that has weathered generations with grace and pride.

Name: Harmony Farms
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the heart of North Scituate, Rhode Island, Harmony Farms has become a cherished seasonal destination for families and fruit enthusiasts. With a focus on cultivating premium-quality blueberries, the farm opens its fields each summer, offering visitors a chance to hand-pick fresh, ripe berries in a serene countryside setting. The tranquil landscape and family-oriented atmosphere make it a quintessential New England experience.

Harmony Farms operates as a family-run business with deep roots in the local community. Passionate about sustainable agriculture and customer connection, the farm caters to both long-time patrons and new visitors alike. Its simple yet genuine approach emphasizes transparency, friendly service, and a dedication to producing one stellar crop: blueberries.

Each summer, beginning in late June and extending through August, Harmony Farms welcomes guests from across the region. Whether arriving with baskets and sun hats ready or discovering the joys of fruit picking for the first time, guests return year after year for the welcoming spirit and consistently delicious harvest. It's more than just a farm — it's a seasonal tradition woven into the rhythm of summer in Rhode Island.
Address: 387 Saw Mill Rd, North Scituate, RI 02857
Hours: July‑Aug blueberry picking: Mon 8 AM‑5 PM; Thu 8 AM‑7 PM; Fri‑Sun 8 AM‑5 PM; closed Tue & Wed

Fruit

  • Blueberries
  • Raspberries

Name: Hartford Plant Company
Bio/Story:
The Hartford Plant Company is a family-rooted urban farm born from an unlikely but heartfelt journey. In 2020, Valentina—now the principal grower—relocated from Belarus to Hartford, Connecticut, amid the country’s political upheaval. Settling into her daughter Anastasiya and son-in-law Matt’s home in West Hartford, Valentina’s natural gift with plants soon transformed from a personal pastime into something much more. What began with propagating begonias and tending to flowers around their home evolved into a passion for cultivating microgreens, ultimately blooming into the Hartford Plant Company.

By February 2021, the trio had gone from kitchen-counter experiments to producing and delivering vibrant, nutrient-rich microgreens to homes and restaurants across Greater Hartford. As the business grew, so did the need for space, and by mid-2021 they moved into a commercial kitchen at the Swift Factory, a historic redevelopment project near Keney Park. Their produce now supplies restaurants across Hartford, Glastonbury, Middletown, Essex, New Haven, and Old Saybrook. The company remains a staple at the West Hartford Farmers’ Market and continues to offer convenient pickup and local deliveries to individual customers.

At its core, the Hartford Plant Company is driven by values of family, health, and sustainability. All microgreens are organically grown and harvested the same day they're delivered, ensuring exceptional flavor and nutritional potency. From spicy radish mixes to aromatic cilantro and power-packed broccoli shoots, their greens are not only a culinary delight but also a quiet revolution—offering a tangible way to eat better, waste less, and support local growers rooted in resilience and care.

Name: Hartland Hollow Modern Homestead
Bio/Story:
Hartland Hollow Modern Homestead is a charming first-generation family farm nestled in the hills of East Hartland, Connecticut. Founded in 2016 after the owners transitioned from condo life to country living, the farm has grown from a personal dream into a thriving operation grounded in integrity, sustainability, and a passion for local food. From their modest beginnings, they’ve built a homestead that celebrates the bounty of the land and the joy of living simply and intentionally.

Specializing in organic microgreens, maple syrup, and duck eggs, the team at Hartland Hollow proves that farming need not require sprawling acreage to be successful. Their "front porch farm stand" is a delightful roadside stop, stocked daily from morning to dusk, offering self-serve access to a rotating selection of seasonal goods. The farm also hosts open houses during maple syrup season, welcoming visitors to witness the beauty and process behind small-scale sugaring—where tradition meets thoughtful innovation in a solar-powered setting.

The heart of Hartland Hollow is its authenticity. With a flock of ducks full of personality, a deep respect for the rhythms of nature, and a commitment to educating others about modern homesteading, this is a place where values take root. Whether you're savoring their rich maple syrup, crunching on nutrient-dense microgreens, or reading their thoughtful blog posts on duck care and sustainable living, Hartland Hollow offers a warm invitation into a simpler, more connected way of life.
Address: 54 Walnut Hill Road, East Hartland, CT

Name: Hastings Farm
Bio/Story:
Hastings Farm is a multi-generational dairy and beef farm in Suffield, Connecticut, with deep roots in the state's agricultural heritage. The farm began when Howard Hastings transformed the family's tobacco operation by introducing a small dairy herd. His son Richie expanded the herd, and today, the farm is run by the fourth generation—Megan and Lauren Hastings—who are continuing the legacy while adding new dimensions to the farm’s offerings.

Currently milking about 100 Holsteins and Jerseys, Hastings Farm produces a variety of dairy products, including yogurt, aged cheeses, fresh milk, and ricotta. In recent years, the family also introduced natural beef production, raising their animals without antibiotics or artificial growth hormones and processing meat through a USDA-inspected, humane-certified facility. Their cows are pastured for most of the year and fed on-farm-raised hay and corn during winter months.

The farm store, open Monday through Saturday, is stocked not only with the farm’s own products but also those from neighboring producers—local eggs, honey, syrup, ice cream, jams, and even seasonal turkey from Ekonk Hill. Visitors are welcome to stop by, see the calves, or even watch the robotic milker in action. Hastings Farm continues to honor its past while pushing forward with sustainable and community-centered agricultural practices.
Hours: Mon-Sat 9 AM - 6 PM

Name: Hathor Hill Farm
Bio/Story:
Hathor Hill Farm, located in the quiet countryside of Lakeside, Connecticut, is a revival of both heritage and heart. With roots tracing back to 1747, this land has sustained generations through farming, timber, brickmaking, and more. Today, the farm is being lovingly restored by Joe and Sally, who have embraced their role as stewards with a commitment to ethical, regenerative agriculture. Every aspect of the farm honors a natural relationship between land and livestock—from pastured chickens to Black Angus and Devon cattle.

The farm specializes in nutrient-dense, pasture-raised beef, heritage poultry, eggs, and Connecticut-made maple syrup, all raised and produced with transparency and care. Their commitment to localism is not only reflected in their diverse offerings but in their presence across Litchfield County farmers’ markets and their dedication to free local delivery. Hathor Hill also raises livestock guardian dogs and keeps a growing flock of goats, adding to the farm’s vibrant biodiversity.

The story of Hathor Hill is one of restoration and revival—a blend of history, innovation, and hard-earned wisdom. Every product offered speaks to their values: quality, sustainability, and community connection. Whether you're visiting the weekend farm store or discovering them at a local market, the team at Hathor Hill invites you to taste and support a future rooted in tradition and nurtured with care.

Name: Hayward Farm
Bio/Story:
Perched on a scenic hilltop overlooking the tranquil beauty of Connecticut's Farmington Valley, Hayward Farm is a cherished family-owned orchard that has been nurturing and harvesting fine fruits since 1927. Deeply rooted in tradition, the farm occupies historic grounds, with the farmhouse itself dating back to 1778, adding to its charm and rich sense of heritage.

At Hayward Farm, generations of careful cultivation have yielded lush orchards brimming with fresh apples, juicy peaches, succulent pears, and delightful cider. Their commitment to quality produce, grown and harvested directly on-site, reflects nearly a century of familial dedication, making this farm a beloved local institution.

Visitors to the farm not only savor the delicious fruits but also revel in the sweeping panoramic vistas of the surrounding valley, enhancing their experience of connecting with the land and its bounty. With an overwhelming community recommendation, Hayward Farm stands proudly as a testament to sustainable agriculture, family legacy, and the simple joys of fresh, locally grown fruit.

Name: Henny Penny Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the hills of Ridgefield, Connecticut, Henny Penny Farm is a small but mighty beacon of regenerative agriculture. Founded and operated by Whitney, alongside her husband Ron and daughter Penny, the farm is built on principles of ecological stewardship, respect for animals, and a deep connection to the land. For nearly 15 years, they have nurtured not just pasture-raised livestock but also a vibrant community of families and food lovers who come to their red-roofed store in search of clean, nutrient-dense meat and handcrafted artisan goods.

The farm is home to a diverse family of animals, including Romney sheep—prized for their superior wool and flavor-rich meat—alongside chickens, turkeys, goats, ducks, a pot-bellied pig named Felix, and even a charismatic Angora rabbit called Big Ben. In addition to their Ridgefield home base, Henny Penny manages grazing herds at nearby McKeon Farm and across state lines in Lagrangeville, NY, where their adaptive grazing techniques breathe new life into neglected fields and forgotten orchards. Their livestock play a vital role in the regeneration of soil health, biodiversity, and habitat restoration.

More than just a source of wholesome food, Henny Penny is a destination for learning and connection. Through their education programs, seasonal events like the beloved Hootenanny, and frequent farmers’ market appearances, they invite the public into a fuller understanding of what it means to eat responsibly and live in harmony with the earth. Their commitment is as much to their customers as to the land itself—raising animals with care, producing meat with integrity, and creating a warm, welcoming place where people can experience the joy of knowing exactly where their food comes from.
Hours: Online orders available for pickup Monday–Friday 9:30am-1pm

Name: Hickory Hill Orchards
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the heart of Cheshire, Hickory Hill Orchard is a celebration of community, tradition, and the natural bounty of Connecticut. This farm has become a cherished gathering spot for families, where the beauty of the landscape is matched only by the warmth of the welcome. With rows of apple trees stretching across scenic acres, the farm brings guests closer to the roots of agriculture while delivering crisp, flavorful fruit straight from the trees.

Hickory Hill Orchard takes pride in offering more than just a place to pick apples. At the heart of its mission is the desire to foster meaningful connections—between people and the land, between generations, and within the broader community. From the vibrant farm market brimming with fresh cider and baked goods to the joyful play of children in the Kid Zone, everything at Hickory Hill is crafted to create memorable, enriching experiences for visitors of all ages.

With each season, the orchard evolves, adding new experiences while remaining grounded in timeless values: authenticity, quality, and hospitality. Whether meandering through hand-tended apple rows, browsing handcrafted goods in the market, or simply savoring the charm of farm life, guests are invited to slow down and be present. Hickory Hill Orchard isn’t just a place to visit—it’s a tradition to return to year after year.

Name: Hidden Blossom Farm
Bio/Story:
Tucked away in the rural tranquility of Union, Connecticut, Hidden Blossom Farm spans 134 acres of thoughtfully cultivated land. This diversified farm is known for producing grass-fed beef, rich full-flavor vegetables, and a treasured variety of family heirloom figs. Every product sold is grown or raised right on site, a testament to the farm's commitment to quality and natural practices.

What sets Hidden Blossom Farm apart is its pioneering use of silvopasture, an agroforestry method that allows cattle to graze beneath the canopy of trees. This integration of pasture and woodland creates a sustainable, ecologically enriched environment that benefits both the livestock and the land. As one of the few farms employing silvopasture in the Northeastern United States, Hidden Blossom is leading by example in regenerative farming.

At its core, Hidden Blossom Farm is committed to producing food in harmony with the earth. Their mission is fueled by a deep respect for agricultural traditions and an innovative approach to land stewardship. Every decision made — from what they grow to how they raise their animals — reflects an ethos of care, sustainability, and authenticity.
Hours: Saturdays from 9am-3pm and Wednesdays from 10am-4pm, July through early October

Name: Hidden Gem Orchard
Bio/Story:
Tucked away in the quiet Purchase section of Southbury, Hidden Gem Orchard lives up to its name. Founded in 2017 by James Wargo, a native of Woodbury, this young orchard has quickly grown into one of Connecticut’s most distinctive apple farms. Established on land once part of the Southbury Training School farm, Hidden Gem now boasts over 4,000 dwarf apple trees planted on just six acres. With a sharp focus on cultivating both antique and modern apple varieties, James has curated an orchard that blends horticultural science with old-world charm — from 16th-century French apples like Calville Blanc to newly released Cornell hybrids like Cordera and Firecracker.

James Wargo brings deep-rooted expertise to the farm. Armed with a degree in Horticulture from UConn and a Master of Science in Pomology from Cornell, he has spent over two decades working in fruit science, product development, and applied field research across the eastern United States. After nearly 20 years away, James returned to Connecticut to fulfill a lifelong dream: owning and operating a fruit farm. His passion is evident in every branch of Hidden Gem — where apples are grown on a vertical axe training system that maximizes sunlight, yield, and flavor. His approach is informed, intentional, and infused with reverence for both the science and soul of apple farming.

Hidden Gem Orchard offers a peaceful, non-commercial apple picking experience that feels more like stepping into a storybook than a roadside attraction. Guests are invited to meander through rows of conical, fruit-laden trees, enjoy scenic hayrides, and discover rare apple varieties whose names and flavors evoke centuries of cultivation history. With over 30 apple types — including prized heirlooms for fresh eating, baking, and cider — and new ventures like seedless table grapes on the horizon, Hidden Gem Orchard continues to evolve while staying grounded in its mission: to grow remarkable fruit with integrity, curiosity, and quiet beauty.

Name: Hilltop Apiaries
Bio/Story:
Hilltop Apiaries is a family-owned Connecticut-based honey producer rooted in a quiet backyard on Hilltop Drive. What began over a decade ago with a single hive and a few chickens has evolved into a thriving apiary operation spread across eight family-owned farms throughout the Farmington Valley. Today, Hilltop is known for its pure and raw wildflower honey, a range of gourmet whipped honeys, and an expanding line of thoughtfully crafted kitchen staples. Every product is a reflection of their devotion to responsible beekeeping, local sourcing, and a deep respect for the land and bees that make it all possible.

Steeped in heritage and grounded in community values, Hilltop Apiaries is run by a multigenerational team of Connecticut beekeepers. They are True Source Certified, Kosher Parve, and proud members of both the Connecticut Beekeepers Association and the Connecticut Farm Bureau. Beyond honey production, Hilltop partners with local orchards to offer pollination services, supporting the broader agricultural ecosystem across New England. Their goods—ranging from honey spreads and jams to infused syrups, teas, and dressings—can be found in farm stores, retailers, and pantries throughout the region.

The heart of Hilltop Apiaries, though, is its origin story. The business was nurtured by a family matriarch whose spirit and dedication helped shape its early days. Her legacy lives on in every jar and bottle, in every delivery made to customers near and far. What began as a backyard curiosity has matured into a symbol of family strength, local resilience, and the sweet, enduring power of nature.

Name: Hindinger Farm
Bio/Story:
Hindinger's Farm stands as a testament to more than a century of agricultural legacy in Hamden, Connecticut. Established in 1893, the farm has been lovingly cultivated by generations of the Hindinger family who continue to uphold its longstanding tradition of fresh, local produce. Nestled among picturesque countryside, the farm offers visitors a warm, inviting atmosphere alongside abundant harvests of fruits and vegetables.

Committed to growing practices that support both the environment and the community's health, Hindinger’s Farm utilizes Integrated Pest Management (IPM) methods. This conscientious strategy effectively controls pests while minimizing the use of pesticides, ensuring that the produce delivered to families is both safe and remarkably fresh. Their approach reflects a thoughtful balance between agricultural productivity and ecological responsibility.

Beyond produce, the farm has evolved into a hub of seasonal charm and family engagement. Featuring community initiatives like CSA subscriptions, flower shares, a goat pen, and lively food truck events, Hindinger’s Farm thrives as both a source of sustenance and joy. Whether visiting for a weekend festival or savoring ripe peaches at the peak of summer, guests are welcomed into the Hindinger family’s ongoing passion for wholesome farming and genuine hospitality.
Hours: Tue–Fri 9 AM–6 PM, Sat & Sun 9 AM–5 PM; closed Mon

Name: Hoadley Hills Farm
Bio/Story:
Hoadley Hills Farm is a small, family-owned operation nestled in the rolling landscape of South Kent, Connecticut. For over a decade, this land has been in the hands of the Hoadley family, now in its fourth generation, who began farming as a hobby to feed their family better, cleaner food. What began with a few chickens gifted by Tyler Hoadley’s father has blossomed into a thriving regenerative farm producing some of the most nutrient-dense meats and eggs in the region.

At the heart of Hoadley Hills is a deep commitment to regenerative agriculture—a philosophy that centers on restoring soil health, enhancing biodiversity, and respecting the natural rhythms of animal life. All animals are rotationally grazed, moved regularly to fresh pasture, and fed a carefully considered diet free from antibiotics, hormones, and synthetic additives. Their pigs enjoy organic grain and whey from Arethusa, their poultry forages daily on vibrant fields, and their Eggmobile system ensures hens lay rich, creamy-yolked eggs with access to endless fresh forage.

The farm is stewarded by Tyler and Haley, whose paths crossed while working on a Connecticut vegetable farm. Their shared passion for a grounded, seasonal life and traditional, nourishing food became the foundation for both a life and a farm built with care and purpose. Together, they’ve turned a dream into a practice—offering their community more than just meat and eggs, but a true model of sustainability, transparency, and reverence for the land.
Hours: No farm store – pick-ups by appointment only though online store

Name: Holcomb Farm
Farm Type: Produce, Beef, Pork, Poultry, Eggs, Mushrooms, Honey, Syrup
Bio/Story:
Holcomb Farm, nestled in the rolling hills of West Granby, Connecticut, is a storied and vibrant agricultural gem with roots tracing back to 1756. For over two centuries, the land was lovingly stewarded by the Holcomb family, culminating in a generous gift to the University of Connecticut in 1976 by siblings Tudor and Laura Holcomb. Their vision was to preserve the land for agricultural research, education, and conservation. In 1990, ownership transitioned to the Town of Granby, and since then, the nonprofit Friends of Holcomb Farm has breathed new life into the property—restoring its legacy as a working farm and enriching it with a deeply community-focused mission.

Today, Holcomb Farm thrives as a non-profit, chemical-free production farm growing on 26 acres of conserved land. Their CSA program serves over 500 households across summer and winter seasons, while the on-site Farm Store offers fresh produce alongside locally crafted goods and pantry staples. Central to Holcomb’s ethos is its Fresh Access initiative—a program that distributes tens of thousands of pounds of nutrient-dense produce to food-insecure families throughout Hartford County and beyond. Their farming practices are rooted in sustainability: composting, crop rotation, cover cropping, beneficial insects, and flame weeding are all thoughtfully applied to ensure that every harvest nurtures both people and the planet.

Beyond the fields, Holcomb Farm has evolved into a hub for education, recreation, and celebration. Its 312 acres include over ten miles of public trails, a renowned Tree Trail arboretum, and a historic barn available for community events. Classes, yoga sessions, volunteer days, and youth programs are held throughout the seasons, creating a space where locals and visitors alike can connect to nature, wellness, and one another. Holcomb Farm is not only a testament to the enduring beauty of New England agriculture—it is a model for what it means to farm with purpose, passion, and heart.
Hours: Wednesday–Saturday, 10:00 AM – 6:00 PM (Mid-June through Late October)

Name: Holmberg Orchards & Winery
Bio/Story:
Totten Family Farm, nestled in Montague, New Jersey, is a testament to sustainable, small-scale agriculture grounded in heritage and passion. Owned and operated by the Totten family, the farm has become a cornerstone in the local community for its commitment to responsible livestock management and environmentally conscious practices. Every inch of this farm reflects the care and deep-rooted values of a family dedicated to natural farming.

With a mission centered around healthful food and land stewardship, Totten Family Farm raises 100% grass-fed beef, pasture-raised chicken, and heritage pork without the use of antibiotics or hormones. Their dairy offerings, raw milk cheeses, and fresh eggs are produced with attention to humane animal care and traditional methods. This devotion to quality also extends into their handmade pantry goods — all crafted or curated with that same authenticity.

The farm’s ethos is one of transparency, education, and sustainability. Through their on-site farm store and presence at area farmers markets, Totten Family Farm not only provides nourishing products but also fosters a deeper connection between consumers and local agriculture. Their fields and barnyards tell a story — one of resilience, family values, and a reverence for the land that continues to feed both body and spirit.
Hours: Wine tasting June–Oct Fri–Sun 12 PM–6 PM; wine sales daily at farm market

Name: Howling Flats Farm
Bio/Story:
Howling Flats Farm is a third-generation, family-run pasture-based livestock farm nestled in the hills of North Canaan, Connecticut. Founded in 2010 by Kelley Babbin, the farm began as a rebellion against factory farming—starting with a handful of hens and a few cows. Since then, it has grown into a thriving, multi-species operation rooted in timeless values: humane treatment, regenerative land stewardship, and clean, honest food.

Kelley and her family raise grass-fed beef, heritage pork, lamb, and poultry without antibiotics or added hormones. Their animals live outdoors, rotated across lush pastures in the rolling foothills of Litchfield, Berkshire, and Dutchess Counties. While not certified organic, the farm follows organic principles and ethical practices with transparency and care.

Through home delivery, custom subscription boxes, on-farm pickup, and their beloved “Meat-Up” pop-ups, Howling Flats brings premium cuts from pasture to plate. Customers can build their own box or gift a 10-month share—with a freezer included on the first delivery. Every order comes backed by a 100% satisfaction guarantee and a deep-rooted commitment to quality.

For Kelley, this isn’t just about meat—it’s about rebuilding trust between eaters and the land, one ethically raised cut at a time.
Hours: Online ordering 24/7

Name: Hungry Reaper Farm
Bio/Story:
Hungry Reaper Farm is a small but mighty community-centered farm nestled in Morris, Connecticut. Co-founded by Jill Verzino and Will O’Meara, the farm has become a haven for ecologically responsible farming and a hub of local food culture. With deep roots in New England agriculture, the team brings years of hands-on experience and a shared passion for regenerative farming practices to every harvest. Their mission is not only to grow food but to steward land, support community health, and build resilient local food systems.

Jill Verzino, an artist and environmentalist, brings an eye for both design and ecological balance to the farm. Her farming journey began in her grandparents’ garden and blossomed into a full-fledged career through experience at Evergreen Berry Farm and academic studies in visual art and environmental policy at Fordham University. Her co-founder, Will O’Meara, studied Sustainable Food and Farming at UMass Amherst and cut his teeth in the fields of Waldingfield Farm, where he honed his skills in soil stewardship and farm management. Together, Jill and Will bring a thoughtful, hands-on approach to their work, inspired by a shared commitment to land, flavor, and community.

At Hungry Reaper, all produce is grown using methods that adhere to National Organic Program standards, though the farm is not formally certified. Their holistic approach includes composting, biodiversity, OMRI-approved inputs, cover cropping, and integrated pest management. Their CSA program reflects this ethos: generous, flexible, and rooted in community support. Whether you're picking up a share at the farm stand in Morris or browsing their abundant booth at the Black Rock or Westport farmers’ markets, Hungry Reaper Farm invites you into a food system grounded in integrity, care, and delicious, nutrient-dense vegetables.
Address: Farm Stand: 9 Thomaston Rd, Morris, CT 06763 Mailing Address / Headquarters: 122 Thomaston Rd, Morris, CT 06763

Name: Hunts Brook Farm
Farm Type: Produce, Eggs, Honey, Syrup, Poultry, Seafood
Bio/Story:
At Hunts Brook Farm, the philosophy of farming runs deeper than soil and seed—it’s rooted in intention and purpose. The farmers believe in living lives full of positivity and productivity, channeling that mindset into every facet of their operation. They see farming not just as a livelihood but as a force for good, imbuing their work with care that resonates through their fields and extends to the plates of their community.

The farm is committed to ecologically and socially responsible food production, fostering a system that supports both environmental health and local vitality. From their field practices to the way they engage with customers, Hunts Brook Farm consistently emphasizes health, beauty, and sustainability. Their mission is to cultivate not just crops but also meaningful connections—with nature, with people, and with the rhythms of the seasons.

Located in Quaker Hill, Connecticut, Hunts Brook Farm serves as a vital hub for those who care about where and how their food is grown. It's a place built on values, where feeding the community goes hand in hand with nurturing the land. Each harvest reflects a commitment to integrity and a belief that good energy in the farming process leads to better food for all.

Name: Husky Meadows Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled on a breezy hilltop in Norfolk, Connecticut, Husky Meadows Farm is a thoughtfully cultivated, certified organic farm grounded in regenerative practices and seasonal abundance. The farm spans three acres of fine sandy loam soil, originally part of a dairy operation, now reimagined by the Low family into a flourishing ecosystem of vegetables, herbs, fruits, mushrooms, and flowers. Their dedication to stewardship radiates through every part of the operation—from soil health to pollinator habitats—creating a biodiverse and ecologically rich farm that sustains both land and community.

At the heart of Husky Meadows is a philosophy that blends tradition with innovation. The farmers integrate age-old growing methods with modern organic techniques, cultivating nutrient-dense food while honoring the land’s natural rhythms. The result is a vibrant yield of produce—from arugula and heirloom lettuces to shiitake mushrooms grown on forest logs—each harvested with care. The farm also tends antique fruit trees, including a century-old pear planted by John Curtiss, preserving the agricultural history of the land while expanding into new varietals and value-added products.

But Husky Meadows is more than a farm—it is a gathering place and culinary hub. The on-site farm kitchen transforms fresh harvests into hand-crafted prepared foods, savory sauces, and baked goods. Weekly newsletters and curated menus bring farm-to-table inspiration directly to customers. Whether strolling through their bustling summer farm stand, savoring a freshly baked tart, or attending a seasonal workshop, visitors are invited to experience the full expression of a farm deeply rooted in community, sustainability, and the joy of growing good food.
Address: Farm Address: 26 Doolittle Drive, Norfolk, CT 06058 Farm Stand Address: 30 Doolittle Drive, Norfolk, CT 06058

Name: Indian River Shellfish
Bio/Story:
Nestled along the Connecticut coast, Indian River Shellfish cultivates its oysters in the pristine waters of Long Island Sound. With a specialized approach to aquaculture, the farm exclusively raises eastern oysters in cages—a rarity in traditional oyster farming. This practice ensures the oysters remain in peak condition from seed to harvest, resulting in a consistently sweet and refreshing taste that defines the Indian River Shellfish experience.

Operating in the towns of Clinton and Madison, the farm integrates sustainably into the region’s rich maritime heritage. Its prime location in the nutrient-rich waters of Long Island Sound grants the oysters an ideal environment to thrive. Rather than following industry conventions, Indian River Shellfish relies on the natural quality of its habitat and a hands-on farming process to produce oysters made for life on the half shell.

A passion for quality and a dedication to the local ecosystem are at the heart of Indian River Shellfish’s mission. The team behind the farm champions responsible aquaculture practices and maintains a tireless commitment to offering a premium shellfish product. Whether enjoyed fresh-shucked or shared among friends, their oysters reflect both care in cultivation and pride in origin.
Hours: Fri 12 PM–4 PM, Sat 9 AM–12 PM
Food Items:
Shellfish

  • Farm-raised Eastern oysters (for the half shell)
  • Wild Eastern oysters (“original” Blue Point style)

Name: Irish Bend Orchard
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the scenic landscape of Somers, Connecticut, Irish Bend Orchard is a cherished, fourth-generation family farm that welcomes visitors each season with open arms and deep community roots. Now operated by the Pinney family, the orchard has long been committed to blending traditional farming practices with warm hospitality. The terrain, once worked by past generations, continues to bear fruit — both literally and figuratively — as Irish Bend Orchard flourishes into its latest chapter.

Irish Bend Orchard offers a quintessential New England farm experience, where patrons are invited to pick their own peaches, apples, and Asian pears straight from the trees. The orchard cultivates a wide array of apple varieties such as Zestar, McIntosh, Cortland, Macoun, Golden Delicious, Honeycrisp, Empire, Early Fuji, Gala, Smokehouse, and Cameo, ensuring something for every taste. Alongside its vibrant fruit offerings, the farm grows a rich assortment of vegetables, including sweet corn, tomatoes, eggplant, onions, cucumbers, and peppers. Eggs and pumpkins in the fall round out the seasonal bounty, making each visit to the orchard wonderfully diverse.

A cornerstone of Irish Bend Orchard’s mission is to create joyful, lasting memories for local families while providing the freshest produce the region has to offer. Whether you choose to hand-pick fruit in the gentle sun or stop by for pre-picked favorites, the orchard’s atmosphere is one of heartfelt welcome and seasonal delight. With a steadfast dedication to agriculture and community, Irish Bend Orchard stands as a testament to the enduring values of family farming.
Hours: Fri 9 AM–3 PM; Sat & Sun 9 AM–5 PM

Name: Jaswell’s Farm
Bio/Story:
Jaswell’s Farm, nestled in the rolling landscape of Smithfield, Rhode Island, has been a proud family-run agricultural institution since 1899. Generations of dedication have cultivated a rich heritage that spans over a century, with the farm continuously evolving to serve its community while maintaining strong roots in tradition. Known for its market, bakery, cider mill, and pick-your-own apple orchard, Jaswell’s offers a slice of wholesome New England life that keeps visitors returning season after season.

At the heart of Jaswell’s Farm is a steadfast commitment to quality and community. From fresh seasonal vegetables to handcrafted apple cider and house-made baked goods, each product is the result of careful cultivation and local pride. Whether you're shopping at the renovated market or experiencing the beauty of the orchard during pick-your-own apple season, you’ll find hospitality and care embedded in every experience.

Beyond its fields and storefront, Jaswell’s Farm continues to deepen its connection with Rhode Island families by fostering joyful traditions and seasonal celebrations. As the farm prepares to celebrate its 125th anniversary, its enduring presence is a testament to the Jaswell family's resilience, passion, and unwavering devotion to shaping shared memories around good food and a welcoming atmosphere.

Name: Jillybeans Farmstand
Farm Type: Produce, Bakery, Honey, Eggs, Syrup, Flowers
Bio/Story:
Jillybeans Farmstand is a cherished, family-run seasonal farmstand nestled in the heart of Farmington, Connecticut. With over 100 acres of local farmland, including parcels along the Farmington Flats and nearby Bristol, this operation has long been a pillar of the community’s agricultural landscape. Each year, the stand opens on Easter weekend and carries through to Christmas Eve, offering a vibrant mix of fresh produce, homemade desserts, holiday decor, and locally beloved traditions.

The farm is committed to sustainable, GMO-free growing practices, raising everything from tomatoes and squash to strawberries and their famously sweet corn. Their produce is carefully planted, weeded, picked, and washed by hand, ensuring customers take home only the freshest crops. Beyond vegetables, Jillybeans sources fruit from trusted Connecticut orchards and maintains their own flock of hens for a daily supply of fresh brown eggs. The farm’s greenhouse-grown vegetable plants and colorful flowers brighten homes each spring, while autumn brings an explosion of pumpkins, and winter wraps up the year with wreaths, trees, and Christmas cheer.

What truly sets Jillybeans apart is their heartfelt approach to community farming. Through their CSA program, affectionately called “The Bean Crew,” they offer flexible shares that support the farm’s seasonal needs while giving customers access to everything from pies and jams to vegetables and veggie plants. Their Kidz Club Card invites the next generation to develop healthy habits and financial responsibility, reinforcing the farm’s deep commitment to education and well-being. More than a market, Jillybeans is a gathering place—a joyful, homegrown experience that has become a staple of life in Farmington.
Hours: 12pm-5pm M-F, 10am-5pm Weekends, Easter weekend through Christmas Day

Name: Jones Family Farms
Bio/Story:
Jones Family Farms is a seven-generation family farm nestled in the hills of Shelton, Connecticut. The farm’s story began in the 1850s with Philip James Jones, a man whose timeless words—“Be good to the land and the land will be good to you”—continue to guide every generation of Jones farmers today. From these humble beginnings, the Jones family has stewarded the land with passion, care, and an unwavering commitment to community.

In the decades that followed, each generation left its own mark—most notably Terry Jones, who returned to the farm in the mid-20th century and introduced strawberries as a new crop. Known lovingly as the “perfect fruit,” strawberries became a beloved summer tradition for thousands of families across the region. Over time, the farm expanded its offerings to include blueberries, pumpkins, Christmas trees, and a celebrated winery, creating a full calendar of harvest experiences that honor both the land and the people who cherish it.

Beyond its crops, Jones Family Farms is a living embodiment of sustainable farming. Every field is tended with environmental care—utilizing cover crops, composting, integrated pest management, and even no-till practices to preserve and improve soil health. Whether it’s the greenhouse blooming in spring, children planting sunflowers in July, or families bundled in December searching for the perfect tree, every season at Jones Family Farms is rooted in love for the earth and a deep respect for its heritage. The Jones family invites all who visit to be good to the land—and to one another.
Address: Homestead: 606 Walnut Tree Hill Road, Shelton, CT 06484
Hours: Hours vary due to weather and picking conditions. Please call ahead before visiting for daily information or questions.

Name: Joseph Preli Farm & Winery
Bio/Story:
Joseph Preli Farm & Winery is a generational gem nestled in the hills of South Glastonbury, Connecticut. The farm’s origins date back to 1920, when Joseph Preli and his wife Rose arrived from Northern Italy and settled into the rich soil of the Connecticut River Valley. From the very beginning, Joseph nurtured the land with care, planting Concord grapes and crafting wines for family and friends with Old World methods and timeless pride.

As the decades passed, the Preli family’s agricultural legacy flourished. Joseph and Rose raised six daughters who carried forward both the farm and the winemaking tradition, stewarding the land and keeping alive the rituals that shaped their childhood. Today, that heritage lives on through Joseph’s grandson John and his partner Jeanne, who now operate the farm with reverence for the past and a renewed vision for the future. Together, they have restored antique tractors, cultivated a lush landscape of produce, and opened a boutique winery—welcoming the community to gather, sip, and celebrate the beauty of local craftsmanship.

Every bottle of wine, jar of jam, and basket of fresh-picked produce at Joseph Preli Farm & Winery speaks to a commitment to purity, sustainability, and soul. From naturally fermented hard ciders and hand-harvested garlic scapes to beeswax candles and rare heirloom tomatoes, the farm honors a simpler time while embracing the joy of sharing that richness with others. It is not just a place to buy food—it is a place to experience the land, taste the season, and feel the enduring warmth of a family that has made this corner of Connecticut their life’s masterpiece.
Address: 235 Hopewell Rd, South Glastonbury, CT, United States, Connecticut

Name: Kalenauskas Farm & Market
Bio/Story:
Founded in 1914 by John C. and Josephine Kalenauskas, Kalenauskas Farm is a storied fifth-generation farm in Watertown, Connecticut. For much of the twentieth century, it was a working dairy operation, but in 1986, the family pivoted away from commodity milk and toward hay, beef, and livestock—laying the groundwork for a diversified, sustainable farm focused on direct-to-consumer relationships. Today, it is lovingly run by the third and fourth generations, with a fifth generation of young helpers never far from the fields or barns.

Spanning over 400 acres, Kalenauskas Farm carefully tends to more than 250 head of livestock and manages vast hay and corn silage production to feed its animals. Every detail of the farm’s operation reflects a commitment to sustainability and humane animal care—from cover cropping and reduced tillage to maximizing pasture access and ensuring animals receive nutritious, consistent feed. This reverence for land and livestock is palpable in every cut of beef and lamb, every jar of honey, every lovingly felted wool item on their market shelves.

In 2020, the family opened Kalenauskas Farm Market, a retail outpost offering 100% farm-produced goods—from USDA beef and lamb to maple syrup, handcrafted soaps, and wooden gifts. Karen’s Lambs, a beloved offshoot of the farm, showcases lamb, goats, and wool products at festivals and farmers markets across Connecticut. With deep roots and wide-ranging talents, the Kalenauskas family remains true to their guiding principle: “Do less better.” By focusing on a smaller variety of higher-quality offerings, they deliver not just food, but trust, heritage, and care in every purchase.
Hours: Spring & Summer: Tuesdays & Fridays: 3:00 p.m. – 6:00 p.m. Saturdays: 10:00 a.m. – 3:00 p.m. Sundays: 10:00 a.m. – 1:00 p.m. Fall & Winter: Tuesdays & Fridays: 3:00 p.m. – 5:00 p.m. Saturdays: 10:00 a.m. – 3:00 p.m. Sundays: 10:00 a.m. – 1:00 p.m.

Name: Karabin Farms
Farm Type: Produce, Livestock, Syrup, Orchard, PYO, Honey, Flowers
Bio/Story:
Karabin Farms began as a hobby in 1972 when Michael and Diane Karabin moved to Southington, Connecticut. What started with a few animals to teach their children responsibility has evolved into a thriving 50-acre family-run farm deeply embedded in the community. The Karabin family—now multiple generations strong—has built a legacy rooted in hard work, sustainability, and a passion for agriculture.

Today, Karabin Farms grows over 2,000 fruit trees and 10,000 Christmas trees, operates four greenhouses, and runs a bustling country store. They offer pick-your-own apples and pumpkins, hormone-free meats raised on-site, seasonal baked goods, flowers, maple syrup, and handcrafted items. The farm is known for its commitment to clean, local food and old-fashioned, hands-on farming practices—from maple syrup made the traditional bucket-and-boil method to holiday trees grown and cut by hand.

Whether you’re visiting to pick apples with your family, grab a frozen pasture-raised turkey for Thanksgiving, or pick out a Christmas tree with a cup of cider in hand, Karabin Farms offers an authentic, seasonal farm experience rooted in trust and tradition.

Name: Killam & Bassette Farmstead
Farm Type: Produce, Livestock, Dairy, Eggs, Syrup, Honey
Bio/Story:
Killam & Bassette Farmstead is a multigenerational family farm rooted in South Glastonbury since 1893. The farm is run by the Killam and Bassette families, with Chris, Abby, Dina, Henry K, Jamie, Olivia, Henry B, and Kevin all playing an active role in its daily operations. Over more than a century of farming, they’ve cultivated a reputation for quality, sustainability, and community-centered agriculture.

Today, the farm is known for its wide variety of fresh produce, all-natural USDA pork and chicken, free-range eggs, and award-winning canned goods. They are deeply embedded in the local scene—participating in over 18 farmers markets and a dozen craft fairs each season, hosting farm dinners, spooky strolls, tastings, and private events. Their “Fresh From the Farm” dinners support the Judy Lynch Memorial Scholarship Fund, established in honor of Chris Bassette’s mother, and have raised tens of thousands for local students.

Visitors can shop year-round at their 1098 Main Street stand, which also features other Connecticut-sourced goods like milk, cheese, honey, maple syrup, baked goods, and handmade crafts. In colder months, their CT Made Gift Shop offers curated selections from local artisans. The farm is a testament to hard work, community roots, and a love for the land, encouraging everyone to “Keep it local, keep it fresh.”
Address: – 1098 Main Street, South Glastonbury, CT 06073 – 14 Tryon Street, South Glastonbury, CT 06073

Name: Kollas Orchard
Bio/Story:
David and Janet Kollas, the husband-and-wife duo behind Kollas Orchard, have spent decades cultivating more than fruit — they've nurtured a living laboratory of innovation in the rolling heart of New England. Born from David's aspiration to explore better, easier methods of apple cultivation, Kollas Orchard took root in 1975 as a personal experiment in thoughtful farming. David, deeply immersed in the science of fruit production, brought to the soil his vast experience as the Extension Fruit Specialist at the University of Connecticut, where for 30 years he served as a trusted advisor to commercial growers across the region.

Though now retired from their formal careers, David and Janet have turned what was once a side endeavor into the cornerstone of their lives. For Janet, a retired elementary school teacher from Hartford, the farm fulfilled a lifelong yearning to live close to the land. Together, their work is marked by diligent experimentation — trying, testing, and refining practices to see what truly benefits a small, family-run, retail orchard. Their approach is both methodical and deeply personal, guided not only by scientific rigor but also by a commitment to meaningful, hands-on labor.

At the core of Kollas Orchard are their three distinct goals: to grow fruit known for its exceptional flavor, to improve low-cost and effective farm practices accessible to small family farms, and to champion the viability of retail orcharding as a rewarding and achievable career. With every grafted branch and every crate of hand-picked apples, David and Janet are not only growing food — they are cultivating a vision of sustainable, thoughtful farming that enriches lives both on and beyond the orchard.
Hours: Fall (Sept–Nov): Wed–Fri 1 PM–5 PM, Sat–Sun 10 AM–5 PM; winter (Nov 25 onward) Fri–Sat 10 AM–4 PM, Sun 12 PM–4 PM

Name: Lapsley Orchard
Bio/Story:
Lapsley Orchard sits on land steeped in history, with roots tracing back to colonial America. First cultivated by Israel Putnam in 1750, the acreage was originally used for stock raising and fruit growing. Over the centuries, it has remained a vital part of the community's agricultural fabric, consistently yielding food to nourish local families. Today, its legacy is preserved through the care and commitment of those who continue to farm its 200 acres.

At its core, Lapsley Orchard is about more than just produce—it's about sustaining a way of life. The present-day farm reflects the essence of a classic New England operation, offering a wide selection of fruits and vegetables grown right on site. The retail stand serves as a central point where freshness, health, and local pride come together to provide high-quality items straight from the fields.

This family-operated farm takes genuine pride in every harvest, celebrating not only the seasonal bounty but also the timeless values of community and stewardship of the land. Through sustainable practices and a love of agriculture, Lapsley Orchard continues to uphold a heritage that feeds both body and spirit in Pomfret Center and beyond.

Name: Latella Farms (X)
Farm Type: Beef, Poultry, Pork, Turkey, Eggs, Christmas Trees
Bio/Story:
Latella & Sons Farms, also known as Big Dog Meats, is located in Orange, Connecticut, at 90 Prindle Hill Road. The farm operates as a family-run business, emphasizing personalized service and fresh, local products. With a long-standing presence in the community, it has established itself as a reliable source for food straight from the farm to the table.

The heart of Latella & Sons lies in its dedication to quality and tradition. The farm runs a meat market that serves both retail customers and provides meat for events like pig roasts and rentals. Transparent pricing and a clear schedule reflect the business's commitment to integrity and customer satisfaction.

With weekly specials and accessible operating hours throughout the week, the farm encourages local customers to stop by and shop directly. Their offering of fresh white eggs at competitive prices and their welcoming, small-business ethos speak to their mission of making fresh, farm-raised goods an everyday option for their community.

Name: Laurel Glen Farm
Farm Type: Produce, Flowers, Eggs, Honey, Syrup, PYO, Orchard
Bio/Story:
Rooted in the rich soil of Shelton, Connecticut, Laurel Glen Farm is a four-generation family farm devoted to growing over 80 varieties of fresh produce with honesty, transparency, and an unwavering commitment to community. The story began in the early 1900s when John Rogowski immigrated to the United States and planted the first seeds of Laurel Glen after leaving work in Pennsylvania’s coal mines. Originally a 100-acre dairy farm, the business evolved with the times, and by the 1970s, shifted to beef and hay under the stewardship of Peter and Alexander Rogowski.

In 2013, the next chapter began when Randy Rogowski returned to his roots and transformed the farm into a thriving, sustainable vegetable operation. Together with his partner Victoria, who brings warmth and creativity to community engagement and CSA management, the family reimagined the farm not only as a source of nourishment, but as a hub for connection. Whether through weekly subscription boxes, pick-your-own days, or potluck breakfasts, Laurel Glen has become a beloved gathering place that centers around wholesome food and heartfelt hospitality.

Today, every bunch of Swiss chard, jar of Sunday Sauce, or pint of just-picked raspberries represents more than a product—it is the culmination of generational labor, environmental stewardship, and genuine love for feeding others. Laurel Glen is proud to use sustainable practices including crop rotation, IPM, composting, biodegradable mulch, and drip irrigation to preserve the land they’ve cherished for over a century. As Randy and Victoria raise their young children among the rows and tractors, they continue to write the farm’s story—with humility, joy, and deep gratitude for the community that supports it.

Name: Ledge Stone Orchards
Bio/Story:
For over two decades, Ledge Stone Orchards has cultivated a legacy of fruit growing on farmland steeped in history. Nestled in Lebanon, Connecticut, the orchard operates on grounds that trace back to 1740, where heritage and agricultural roots run deep. The farm began with a passion for nurturing fruit and produce the traditional way—by hand, in harmony with the land.

Ledge Stone Orchards is most celebrated for its apples, peaches, and an abundant variety of farm-fresh produce. By balancing time-honored growing techniques with a steadfast commitment to sustainability, the farm ensures each harvest is flavorful, responsibly grown, and of the highest quality. Seasonal highlights such as plums, blueberries, and heirloom vegetables are picked at the peak of ripeness to bring vibrant, local taste directly to customers’ tables.

The farm’s mission extends beyond cultivation—it’s about building community through fresh food. By partnering with local markets and businesses across Connecticut, Ledge Stone Orchards shares its bounty with a wider audience while supporting a resilient local food ecosystem. Through glimpses into farm life, simple recipes, and proud customer stories, the orchard invites visitors not just to taste what’s fresh, but to become part of something deeply rooted and ever-growing.
Hours: Daily 6 AM to 8 PM

Name: Litchfield Hills Blueberry Farm
Bio/Story:
Litchfield Hills Blueberry Farm is a beloved, family-owned gem tucked into the gentle hills of Plymouth, Connecticut. Known for its peaceful landscape and sweeping views of the Litchfield Hills, the farm offers guests a classic New England berry-picking experience in a setting as scenic as it is serene. Founded on the principles of hard work and connection to the land, this farm has welcomed generations of berry lovers each summer with the invitation to pick their own blueberries at the peak of ripeness.

The heart of the farm’s operations is its pick-your-own blueberry field, where visitors are invited to wander through the rows and fill their pails by hand. The farm also offers pre-picked berries when available, though nature sets the pace—daily harvests are subject to the rhythm of the season and the cooperation of the weather. With a per-pound pricing model and payment flexibility (including credit cards and Venmo), the farm is as welcoming as it is straightforward.

Open seasonally from early July through late August, Litchfield Hills Blueberry Farm remains a favorite summer destination for families, friends, and anyone seeking the simple pleasure of freshly picked fruit. Whether it’s your first time picking berries or an annual tradition, the experience at this farm is one that connects people back to the land—and to the joy of harvesting food with your own two hands.
Hours: Tuesday – Friday: 8:00 AM – 6:30 PM, Saturday & Sunday: 9:00 AM – 4:00 PM (standard hours), During peak season (July 4 onward): 9:00 AM – 1:00 PM or as crops and weather permit, Closed on Mondays
Food Items:
Fruit

  • Blueberries (Pick-your-own and limited pre-picked availability)

Name: Little Ark Farm
Bio/Story:
Little Ark Farm is nestled in a quiet clearing at the edge of Enfield, Connecticut—a small but abundantly productive four-and-a-half-acre sanctuary run with deep intention by Paul and Nina Lukens. Their love story with the land began in childhood and matured over nearly two decades of gardening, ten years of cultivating this property, and a shared commitment to raising five children while juggling off-farm responsibilities. Their farm is not only a place of food production but a living embodiment of stewardship, humility, and reverence for the natural world.

Operating with a fierce dedication to sustainability and transparency, Paul and Nina farm according to certified organic standards and back every decision with rigorous self-education and meticulous recordkeeping. Their CSA program offers members the fruits of their labor—fresh vegetables, radiant flowers, pasture-raised poultry and eggs, and thoughtful preserves—all grown and prepared with respect for ecology and flavor. From black soldier fly larvae feeding their ducks to no-till practices that nourish the soil, their approach is both traditional and forward-thinking.

Little Ark is more than a farm—it is a deeply personal project built on knowledge, principle, and a joyful obsession with growing well. Though the farm is not open for unannounced visits due to safety, those who make time to join their CSA or meet them at a market will discover a rare integrity that runs through every egg, every bouquet, every jar of chutney. It’s a place where science meets soul, and where farming becomes a quiet act of devotion to the land, their family, and the future.
Hours: Not open for drop-in visits; products available via website, CSA, and local farmers markets (Spruce Street Farmers Market, Northwest Park Farmers Market, South Windsor Farmers Market).

Name: Little Dipper Farm (X)
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the rolling hills of Northeastern Connecticut, Little Dipper Farm is a haven where nature, nourishment, and community seamlessly intersect. With hundreds of acres of open land, the farm offers a sanctuary for those seeking connection—whether through visiting the seasonal market, attending exclusive farm dinners, or celebrating life events in their beautifully preserved 1800s post and beam barn. Their ethos speaks to a deeper mission: fostering meaningful relationships through immersive experiences that nourish both body and soul.

Originally home to the acclaimed Golden Lamb Buttery, the barn and surrounding land have been lovingly transformed into a vibrant hub for sustainable agriculture and curated events. The farm collaborates with expert hospitality partners to tailor unforgettable culinary experiences, ranging from elegant plated dinners to relaxed buffets. Little Dipper Farm is more than just a venue—it’s an invitation to celebrate life in its most authentic, grounded forms.

Dedicated to regenerative farming methods, the team at Little Dipper Farm tends acres of pesticide-free vegetables, herbs, and flowers with a commitment to soil health and sustainability. Educational workshops, wellness programs, and art events are thoughtfully designed to engage the public and cultivate curiosity. Whether you're a member or a guest, Little Dipper Farm welcomes all into its constellation of community and connection.
Hours: Seasonal Farm Market and gift shop is open from June through November.

Name: Long Lane Farm
Bio/Story:
Long Lane Farm is a small-scale, no-till organic produce farm located in Warren, Rhode Island. Managed by husband-and-wife team Devin and Camille Abdel-Nabi, the farm spans five fertile acres and has been serving the East Bay community since 2020. Focused on sustainable agriculture, they grow a wide variety of certified organic vegetables and microgreens for most of the year, operating from April through December.

The farm offers several ways for customers to access fresh produce, including a weekly veggie box membership, an online store, and an on-site honor system farm stand. Each week, members of the veggie plan have the opportunity to hand-pick their favorites from a market-style selection, ensuring freshness and minimizing waste. The online store—and corresponding weekly email alerts—keeps customers informed about what's available and when to pick it up. The farm stand, open during the growing season, also carries locally produced goods, fostering a stronger connection with surrounding farms and producers.

More than just a source of food, Long Lane Farm fosters community and connection. With offerings like CSA coaching, recipe ideas, and a private Facebook group, they aim to educate and inspire their customers. Their mission is simple yet powerful: to help people cook more nourishing meals at home using produce that is fresher and more flavorful than what one might find in a standard grocery store. All while cultivating a space where people can reconnect with where their food comes from and build relationships with those who grow it.
Hours: Farm stand open April to December or Order Online

Name: Long Table Farm
Bio/Story:
At the heart of Long Table Farm lies a mission rooted in sustainability and community. Located in Lyme, Connecticut, the farm is driven by a steadfast commitment to restoring the health of soil and providing nutrient-dense food to its neighbors. With every bed turned and seed sown, Long Table Farm upholds the belief that everyone deserves access to wholesome, life-giving food.

Long Table Farm takes a holistic approach to agriculture, employing methods such as composting, rotating cover crops, and rotational grazing to strengthen both the soil and the ecosystems it supports. The health of the land is intrinsic to the farm's values, and this principle carries through to every aspect of their operation—from the mindful cultivation of crops to the human connections fostered through weekly markets.

Every Saturday, the farm invites the community to gather for its market, where fresh produce and offerings from guest vendors await. It's an open space not only for purchasing food but for engaging with others who believe in the transformative power of local agriculture. In all its efforts, Long Table Farm cultivates more than systems of farming—it nurtures systems of care, collaboration, and community resilience.

Name: Luckyfoot Ranch
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the heart of Rhode Island, Luckyfoot Ranch is a dedicated steward of local, sustainable agriculture. The farm's mission is clear and heartfelt: to provide the community with the freshest, highest-quality seasonal produce while honoring the land and its nutrients. Their daily operations reflect deep care for the environment and a relentless spirit of innovation.

Luckyfoot Ranch isn’t just a place to buy vegetables—it’s a thriving hub of seasonal abundance and grassroots food culture. Open weekly at their farm stand and actively participating in several farmers markets across the region, the farm offers a consistent and personal connection between grower and customer. Whether at the vibrant Goddard Park market or the local stand in North Kingstown, Luckyfoot brings a diverse haul of greens, roots, and fruits directly to Rhode Island tables.

Rooted in a philosophy of continuous learning and adaptability, the farm’s approach evolves each season. Challenges, like the loss of crops to disease, are met with thoughtful experimentation—such as shifting crops like broccoli and brussel sprouts under cover to improve health and yield. This balance of tradition and trial is the foundation of Luckyfoot’s success, ensuring that each harvest is not only sustainable but also a product of passion and perseverance.
Address: 1337 Gilbert Stuart Rd, North Kingstown, RI 02874

Name: Lyman Orchards
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the heart of Middlefield, Connecticut, Lyman Orchards is more than a farm—it's a living legacy. The Lyman family has cultivated this land since 1741, carefully tending its fields through ten generations. Now overseen by Executive Vice President John Lyman (8th generation), along with his son Adam and grandsons John and Daniel, the farm stands as a testament to deep-rooted tradition, agricultural dedication, and a strong commitment to community. Their enduring connection to the land echoes through every peach, apple, and berry picked on its rolling hills.

Lyman Orchards has grown into a multifaceted destination that blends rustic charm with modern recreation, offering visitors an abundance of experiences. Guests can wander through vibrant sunflower and corn mazes, pick their own fruit straight from the orchards, or enjoy artisanal goods at the Apple Barrel Farm Market. The inclusion of a full-service deli, an on-site creamery, and a year-round golf course speaks to the farm’s willingness to evolve while staying grounded in nature’s bounty.

At its core, Lyman Orchards is dedicated to bringing people together through food, family, and fun. Whether it's indulging in an award-winning pie, exploring local festivals, or simply savoring the tranquility of the Connecticut countryside, each visit offers a chance to reconnect with life’s simpler pleasures. As the farm continues to grow with its community, it remains steadfast in its mission: to honor the past by cultivating a meaningful present and a sustainable future.
Hours: Apple Barrel market daily 9 AM–6 PM; pick‑your‑own open 8 AM–4:30 PM

Name: Manfredi Farms
Bio/Story:
Tucked away in the charming town of Westerly, Rhode Island, Manfredi Farms offers visitors an experience that goes far beyond a simple trip to the market. With rows of vibrant produce and the low hum of farm activity in the background, this farm has become a beloved local gem, serving as both a purveyor of fresh food and a place where families forge lasting memories. Its welcoming layout and seasonal offerings create a setting where tradition blends seamlessly with community spirit.

The heart of Manfredi Farms beats strongest in its interactive spaces – children laugh as they engage with friendly goats and donkeys, while adults browse market selections filled with flavorful jars of fruit butter, jars of preserves, and more. The farm’s visually engaging play area and calendar full of family-friendly events, including harvest festivals and petting sessions, reinforce its mission to nourish both body and soul.

Though formal history or ownership details are not elaborated online, what clearly emerges is a portrait of a place grounded in passion, family, and quality. Whether picking up freshly harvested strawberries and blueberries from the stand or enjoying a warm afternoon surrounded by sunflowers and smiling faces, Manfredi Farms appeals to the senses and the heart alike.

Name: Maple Bank Farm
Bio/Story:
Steeped in the rich agricultural heritage of New England, Maple Bank Farm is one of the oldest family-run farms in the United States, its roots reaching back to 1730. Founded by Jonathon Hurlbut on land granted by the King of England, the farm began as a humble subsistence operation with livestock and crops. Over generations, the Hurlbut family expanded its acreage and output, cultivating fruit orchards, raising animals, and eventually selling their produce, eggs, and poultry to towns across Connecticut. In the early 20th century, a modest roadside market emerged—first a picnic table, then a small gabled stand in 1963—where the community came to gather and enjoy the bounty of the farm.

In 1980, stewardship of the farm passed to Cathy and Howie Bronson. Cathy, the daughter of Lewis Hurlbut, was born into the farm and raised with hands in the soil. Howie, a native of Washington, CT, brought a background in dairy and formal training from the University of New Hampshire. Together, they grew the farm’s offerings, built greenhouses, and expanded vegetable production, eventually constructing a new farm stand in 1986. Their children, Linnea and Christopher, became the fifth generation raised on the land, continuing the rhythm of seasonal life under the backdrop of Roxbury’s scenic hills, where sheep and cows still graze peacefully behind the stand.

Today, Maple Bank Farm continues to thrive under the care of Cathy and Howie, alongside the next generation of young farmers like Kirby Peters. With deep roots and a reverence for tradition, the farm offers not only heirloom apples and pick-your-own blueberries but also a timeless experience of pastoral New England. Preserved through partnership with the Weantinoge Land Trust and the State of Connecticut, the land remains protected for future stewards. Maple Bank Farm is not just a place of production, but a legacy of care, community, and continuity—welcoming visitors into its centuries-old embrace.
Hours: Tuesday – Sunday: 10:00 a.m. – 5:30 p.m. Monday: Closed Season: April – December

Name: March Farm
Bio/Story:
March Farm is a fourth-generation family farm nestled in the scenic hills of Bethlehem, Connecticut. Since its humble beginnings in 1915, when Thomas and Rose Marchukaitis first tilled its soil with 15 cows and two horses, the farm has flourished into a beloved local destination. Through decades of stewardship and innovation, the March family has grown the property into a vibrant 150-acre enterprise offering not only bountiful produce, but also treasured community experiences.

In its earliest days, March Farm was a diversified homestead producing milk, poultry, vegetables, and hay. The 1950s brought expansion into fruit with the planting of apple orchards, and by the 1980s, a renewed focus on produce and community engagement emerged. The farm’s commercial kitchen and bakery became local staples, and its greenhouse program expanded to yield an abundance of fresh greens and vegetables well before the field season began. Over the years, pick-your-own options for berries, peaches, apples, and pumpkins became central to the farm's identity, creating opportunities for families to forge connections with the land.

Today, March Farm remains a cherished gathering place for the community, offering a bounty of seasonal fruits and vegetables, farm-baked treats, and joyous events year-round. From the rustic charm of Pond Side Pines to the panoramic vistas of the Hill Top Orchard, it hosts concerts, yoga, exploration hours, and vibrant CSA programs that deepen the relationship between farmer and eater. Above all, March Farm stands as a living testament to legacy, resilience, and the belief that farming, at its heart, is a labor of love meant to be shared.
Hours: Monday–Sunday: 10:00 AM – 6:00 PM

Name: Maywood Farm
Farm Type: Produce, Eggs, Honey, Syrup, Flowers, Vineyard
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the southern tip of Litchfield County, Maywood Farm is a rare fusion of classic elegance, agricultural heritage, and environmental stewardship. The estate, though private, spans forty acres of meticulously cultivated gardens, vineyards, and fields that produce an impressive array of fruits, vegetables, herbs, and flowers. With a view that stretches to the Berkshire foothills, Maywood’s grounds are both cultivated and conserved — carefully balanced between aesthetic beauty and functional productivity.

What sets Maywood apart is not only its breathtaking setting and traditional architecture, but its commitment to sustainability and wildlife preservation. The estate employs environmentally sound practices including IPM (Integrated Pest Management), supports birdlife through bluebird trails and berry-producing plantings, and hosts beehives to encourage natural pollination. As members of Audubon International and the first Connecticut property to join the Rainforest Alliance's SmartWood forestry program, Maywood sets a standard for conscientious land management. Their agricultural methods follow guidelines set by the Northeast Organic Farming Association (NOFA), and their products reflect this care: from the rich soil comes fresh produce, maple syrup, honey, and exquisite wines.

While not open to the public year-round, Maywood opens its gates annually for a single day in August in support of the National Garden Conservancy, welcoming guests to tour the grounds and experience its splendor. In the meantime, their harvest is available through local outlets like the Bridgewater Village Store and select Connecticut wine retailers and restaurants. With roots in the land and an eye toward preservation, Maywood is a quietly enduring gem in the Connecticut countryside.
Address: Not a traditional retail farmstand — products available year-round at: Bridgewater Village Store, 27 Main Street South, Bridgewater, CT 06752

Name: McLean Farms
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the rural village of Cobalt, Connecticut, McLean Hill Farm & Gardens carries the legacy of four generations who have lovingly called this farm home. Owned and operated since 2009 by Buddy McLean, the farm's traditions are deeply interwoven with the East Hampton community. Buddy, who was raised on the land, has continued the family’s commitment to making the farm a welcoming space for the community to gather, connect, and nourish body and soul.

With a strong emphasis on sustainability, McLean Hill Farm & Gardens employs organic growing practices to cultivate fresh, locally sourced produce through their popular CSA program. Their mission revolves around strengthening community ties, fostering environmental stewardship, and providing a consistent and healthy food source to neighbors. Each week, customers receive vibrant, seasonal vegetables alongside updates and personal touches from Buddy himself.

Beyond produce, McLean Hill Farm & Gardens is a hub of activity and celebration. The farm hosts seasonal events, farm-to-table dinners, photo shoots, yoga sessions, and educational tours designed to bring people closer to the rhythms of agricultural life. Friendly, rooted in tradition, and forward-thinking in their environmental philosophy, the McLean family maintains a heartfelt vision: to be the kind of farm that your family returns to, again and again.

Name: Millstone Farm
Farm Type: Produce, Beef, Pork, Poultry, Lamb, Turkey, Eggs
Bio/Story:
Millstone Farm is a 71-acre regenerative farm in Wilton, Connecticut, devoted to fostering a vibrant local food system and restoring the health of the land through responsible, forward-thinking agriculture. The farm’s roots run deep into Wilton’s history, with the land first purchased by Dr. Vincent Tito in 1911. Since then, Millstone has transformed from a traditional farm into a beacon of innovation and sustainability, evolving with each generation while preserving its pastoral charm.

Under current stewardship since 2016, Millstone Farm has embraced a holistic approach to land management and food production. Their rotational grazing system integrates sheep, goats, chickens, llamas, and turkeys—each species contributing uniquely to the land's renewal. Their no-till vegetable beds, winter grazing rotations, and use of cover crops further enrich the soil while reducing erosion, pest pressure, and off-farm inputs. With year-round growing through greenhouses and hoop houses, Millstone offers a rich harvest that stretches from early spring into the depths of winter.

Millstone’s CSA program offers a flexible, credit-based model allowing members to shop at their own pace—be it for vibrant greens, heritage pork, wild-caught Alaskan salmon, or cozy wool goods. More than a farm, Millstone is a deeply rooted community hub where conservation meets culinary celebration. From their equestrian facilities and farmer’s markets to their mission of honoring heritage breeds and stewarding the land, Millstone Farm embodies the essence of “real food, raised right”—a testament to enduring values in a changing world.
Hours: Farm Stand (April–November): Saturdays, 10:00 AM – 2:00 PM

Name: Mitchell Farm
Bio/Story:
Mitchell Farm is a rare testament to persistence and legacy, having fed families since 1759. Currently operated by the 9th and 10th generations of the Mitchell family, the farm stands as a living connection to centuries of agricultural tradition. Nestled in Southbury, Connecticut, it has evolved gracefully with time while maintaining the heart of its founding values—fresh food, local roots, and year-round dedication.

At the core of Mitchell Farm's offerings is its renowned sweet corn and a variety of fresh vegetables, grown and harvested with care. These products are available both at their self-serve farm stand, open daily until 4 PM, and at local farmers markets throughout the region. The farm also provides farm fresh eggs, hay bales, firewood, and stone, serving not just local families, but hotels, restaurants, and grocery stores across Connecticut who value quality straight from the land.

Guided by a mission of transparency and community, Mitchell Farm encourages customers to 'know exactly where your food comes from.' Their philosophy is rooted in fostering trust and nourishment—not just through food, but through longstanding relationships with neighbors and businesses alike. In every ear of corn and every crate of produce, there lies a story centuries in the making.
Hours: Open daily until 4 PM, self‑serve

Name: Mountain Dairy
Bio/Story:
For over ten generations, the Stearns family has been a steadfast presence in the eastern Connecticut farming community, cultivating a legacy rooted deeply in tradition and craftsmanship. Their farm, proudly situated in Storrs, CT, is home to Mountain Dairy, a name synonymous with high-quality, locally produced milk. Every bottle of milk makes its way from the farm to the customer with a reverence for both the product and the process, echoing the same dedication that began generations ago.

At the heart of Mountain Dairy’s mission is an unwavering commitment to providing 'simply delicious' milk. This isn’t just a slogan—it encapsulates a daily routine that begins at 3 a.m. with the first milking and doesn't end until the last delivery truck returns. The family’s hands-on approach ensures that each step of production, from cow to container, is handled with care, ensuring optimal taste and freshness. The farm’s adherence to time-honored methods stands as a quiet testament to their belief in doing things the right way—not the fast way.

With a thoughtful eye toward community and tradition, Mountain Dairy has expanded its offerings to include home delivery to a wide swath of Connecticut towns. Through partnerships with local companies, they now bring not just milk but butter, eggs, yogurt, granola, and more directly to customers’ doors. This curated touchpoint between farm and family guarantees that their long-standing values of trust, integrity, and excellence continue to nourish generations to come.
Hours: Retail store Sat & Sun 10 AM–5 PM (closed Mon–Fri)

Dairy

  • 1% milk
  • Skim milk
  • Half and half
