  • Chocolate whole milk
  • 1% chocolate milk
  • Eggnog

Name: Mountain View Farm
Bio/Story:
Tucked into the hills of Kent, Connecticut, Mountain View Farm is a family-run oasis of certified organic abundance. The land itself has a deep-rooted agricultural legacy, dating back to the 1700s when it first operated as a working farm. In the late 1800s, it came to life as both a farm and boarding house under Lena and William Durfee. Today, that history breathes through every row of heirloom tomatoes, every fragrant bouquet, and every jar of maple syrup lovingly bottled on-site.

At the heart of the operation are Maria and Vincent LaFontan, stewards of the soil and spirit of Mountain View. With just three acres in active production and a network of hoop houses, the LaFontans embrace the philosophy of farming as a craft—prioritizing flavor, diversity, and soil health. They employ crop rotation and enrichment techniques to ensure not just high yields, but truly exceptional food. Beyond produce, the farm is home to a flourishing flock of free-range laying hens and seasonal pigs, and also crafts small-batch jams, pickles, and herbal goods.

The farmstand at Mountain View is open daily from April through November, a welcoming stop for locals and visitors alike. Their vibrant offerings can also be found at the New Milford Farmers Market and on the tables of select area restaurants. Whether you're savoring a warm peach, sampling a spicy pickled scape, or simply strolling their stand on a summer day, Mountain View Farm offers a taste of New England at its most heartfelt and honest.
Hours: Farm Stand open daily, April through November

Name: Muddy Roots Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the heart of Connecticut, Muddy Roots Farm is a testament to sustainable agriculture rooted in tradition. Devoted to honoring the past while forging a sustainable future, the farm champions clean, nutrient-dense food grown with deep respect for the land. The foundation of their work is a commitment to transparency, honesty, and responsible stewardship, values wrapped tightly into every decision made on the fields and pastures.

At Muddy Roots Farm, animals are raised with compassionate care and given space to thrive outdoors on fresh pasture. Their poultry and vegetables are cultivated with practices that are as organic and natural as possible, reflecting a deep commitment to ecological integrity. Membership in CT-NOFA underscores their alignment with environmentally friendly methods, and a strong biosecurity focus ensures the health of their animals and the safety of their food production.

Muddy Roots offers a vibrant CSA program, inviting community members to share in both the risks and rewards of seasonal farming. Weekly vegetable boxes and pre-ordered chicken pickups allow families to enjoy wholesome, high-quality food while supporting a small, principled family-run farm. Every bite tells a story of dedication—to the soil, the animals, and the people they feed.
Hours: Open daily

Name: Mystic Oysters
Bio/Story:
At Mystic Oysters, the devotion to sustainable aquaculture is evident in every shell harvested from the nutrient-rich waters of Fishers Island Sound. The farm delicately balances time-honored traditions with modern innovation, creating a rare harmony between old-world craftsmanship and cutting-edge techniques. Their commitment to high-quality, responsibly cultivated oysters drives everything they do—from hatchery improvements to attentive harvesting practices.

Nestled in historic downtown Mystic, Connecticut, Mystic Oysters draws from its idyllic maritime surroundings and rich aquacultural heritage. Operating under the Noank Aquaculture Cooperative, the farm maintains a close connection to the community and local ecosystems. Their location, where the Mystic and Thames Rivers meet the Atlantic, imparts a unique brininess to their oysters—resulting in three distinct offerings: the Mystics, the Rams, and the Copps—each reflecting the nuanced terroir of Long Island Sound.

More than just purveyors of shellfish, the people behind Mystic Oysters are stewards of both land and sea. Their mission is rooted in environmental responsibility and flavor authenticity, ensuring that every oyster delivers a true taste of coastal Connecticut. With pride in their craft and respect for nature, Mystic Oysters offers a fulfilling experience for both the palate and the planet.
Hours: Mon–Thu 8 AM–4 PM; Fri 12 PM–4 PM; Sat 9 AM–2 PM; closed Sun
Food Items:
Seafood

  • Oysters

Name: Narrow Lane Orchard
Bio/Story:
In 2004, Stephen and Sharon Grenier took a significant step to preserve a piece of Rhode Island’s rural landscape by purchasing Narrow Lane Orchard. Their goal was to rescue the 30-acre plot from being transformed into housing developments. With a strong vision and deep-rooted commitment to agriculture, the Graniers turned the property into a flourishing fruit orchard that now stands as a testament to intentional stewardship and community-minded farming.

Over the past two decades, Narrow Lane Orchard has steadily evolved to serve a growing customer base while remaining true to its pastoral charm. The orchard now offers over 20 varieties of fruit, including apples, peaches, nectarines, blueberries, blackberries, and kiwi berries. During the harvest season, guests are invited to pick their own fruit, encouraging a hands-on connection with the land. For added adventure, a mile-long nature trail winds through the property, ending with a quirky photo opportunity beside a life-sized Sasquatch sculpture.

As much as it is a destination for fresh fruit, Narrow Lane Orchard is also a space where nature, family tradition, and local pride merge. Stephen and Sharon have created more than just a farm—they’ve cultivated a beloved community landmark. From the orchard’s diverse fruit selection to the carefully maintained grounds, every aspect reflects their dedication to offering something meaningful to every visitor.
Hours: Aug‑Oct daily 10 AM‑5 PM

Name: New Boston Beef
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the Fabyan village of Thompson, Connecticut, New Boston Beef, LLC is the creation of Jonathan Eddy, who proudly operates the farm known as Fabyan Farm. The business embodies a commitment to local agriculture and quality meat production, offering USDA-inspected, all grass-fed beef raised without added hormones or antibiotics. The land that supports the farm extends into Massachusetts, where the fertile banks of the Quinebaug River provide rich hay fields for the animals' nourishment.

Rooted in a town rich in historical tapestry, New Boston Beef pays homage to its location in Thompson—a village with borders touching both Massachusetts and Rhode Island. The region’s identity stems from a mosaic of historic villages, with Fabyan once known as “New Boston,” a name revived and honored through the farm’s identity. This connection to place is more than aesthetic; it's integral to the farm’s philosophy of staying deeply tied to the land and its traditions.

Jonathan and Sarah Eddy, the stewards of New Boston Beef, bring a personal touch to their operation. They complement meat production with kitchen offerings and baked goods, bringing full-circle hospitality to their farmstand and market engagements. With a presence at regional farmer’s markets including Coventry and Ellington, they bridge the gap between quiet rural heritage and the wider community, offering not just food, but a story of place, purpose, and passion.
Address: 9 Fabyan Woodstock Road, North Grosvenordale, CT 06255

Name: New England Grass Fed
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the lush heart of Rhode Island, New England Grass Fed has been raising premium grass fed beef since 2011. The farm operates with a commitment to humane treatment, soil regeneration, and sustainable land stewardship, ensuring that every animal is part of a system that nurtures the environment as much as it feeds the community. Their process is rooted in a belief that food should connect people to the land and to one another.

At the helm is Martin Beck, a passionate founder who has spent over a decade fostering relationships with top-tier chefs, New England ranchers, and local beef enthusiasts. His vision extends beyond the farm, cultivating a network that values transparency, animal welfare, and culinary excellence. From the beginning, Martin has been committed to delivering beef of the highest ethical and gastronomic standards.

New England Grass Fed stands as more than just a farm—it is a mission-driven enterprise built on values of community wellness and joyful living. They proudly offer customers not only excellent beef but also a deeper connection to sustainable agriculture and responsible farming. Every purchase supports regenerative practices that enrich the land and honor the animals that nourish us.
Hours: Order Online
Food Items:
Meat

  • Various Steak Cuts
  • Braising Cuts / Slow Cooker
  • Burger Meat
  • Free Range Heritage Pork

Name: Ninigret Nectar Oysters
Bio/Story:
Behan Family Farms, operating under the banner of Ninigret Nectars, is rooted in the coastal town of Charlestown, Rhode Island. Since 2010, the farm has carved a name for itself in southern New England and beyond for its fresh, sustainably harvested oysters. Drawing from the pristine waters of Ninigret Salt Pond, the farm captures the essence of its marine surroundings in every shell, celebrating a heritage of ocean stewardship and culinary excellence.

At the heart of Behan Family Farms is a deep respect for nature and a commitment to sustainable aquaculture. Every oyster and clam is cultivated with care, ensuring that the bounty of the sea is preserved for future generations. The farm doesn't just provide seafood—it curates an experience, offering a raw bar that includes local little neck clams, jumbo shrimp cocktail, and their signature jalapeño mignonette, inviting the community to savor the flavors of the tide.

Beyond the salt pond, Behan Family Farms connects with its community through participation in some of the region's most beloved seafood festivals and events. From Newport to Providence, they bring the raw bar directly to the people, complemented by music, fine wine, and a sense of celebration. Each event is a testament to their mission: to serve nature’s freshest offerings, responsibly sourced and richly enjoyed.
Hours: No public hours

  • Organically grown clams
  • Jumbo shrimp cocktail

  • House made cocktail sauce

Name: Northern Farm & Flowers
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the picturesque town of Goshen, Northern Farm & Flowers embodies a deep-rooted passion for sustainability, regenerative agriculture, and local community. The Weigold family, whose legacy spans generations back to the late 1800s, has transformed their historic farmland into a flourishing haven for ethically and humanely raised meats, pastured poultry, and vibrant flower gardens. Richard, Cara, and Alden Weigold continue to honor their family's agricultural heritage, nurturing the land through responsible practices that preserve its beauty and fertility for future generations.

Northern Farm & Flowers is beloved not just for its fresh, delicious produce and premium meats, but also for its inviting and joyful atmosphere. Whether visiting to pick your own blooms in the cutting garden, exploring the thoughtfully curated farm market, or attending one of their engaging workshops or tastings, guests consistently encounter genuine warmth and knowledge from the farm’s dedicated team. This emphasis on quality and community has transformed Northern Farm & Flowers into a staple destination in the Litchfield Hills.

At the heart of Northern Farm & Flowers lies a steadfast commitment to transparency, education, and enriching the local ecosystem. Through offerings like their Flower CSA programs and unique farm-to-table events, the Weigolds have created a place where neighbors gather, learn, and build lasting relationships. Rooted firmly in both tradition and innovation, Northern Farm & Flowers celebrates agriculture as a vital, living tradition, demonstrating how mindful stewardship of the land yields not only nutritious foods and beautiful flowers, but also strengthens the bonds that unite a community.

Name: Off Center Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the heart of Woodbridge, Connecticut, Off Center Farm is a regenerative flower and herb farm that takes pride in nurturing both cultivated fields and native woodland foraged crops. Operating with a deep reverence for the local ecosystem, the farm bridges agriculture and wildcrafting to offer beauty, health, and flavor to its surrounding community. With each season, they bring forth the bounty of their land through a carefully curated mix of fresh botanicals and produce.

The vision behind Off Center Farm was brought to life by Kristyna and Becca, a pair of devoted farmer friends united by a passion for sustainable growing practices and community enrichment. Together, they cultivate not just the land but a shared sense of purpose—making it their mission to provide accessible, locally sourced items while fostering relationships through growing and sharing food and flowers.

Rooted in principles of regeneration and connection, Off Center Farm thrives as a destination where people can experience the rewards of mindful farming. Their farmstand, open on weekends, offers a selection of fresh cut flowers, herbs, and seasonal vegetables that embody their commitment to integrity, nature, and the local economy. Each product carries with it the story of the land and the dedication of the hands that brought it to life.
Hours: Fri–Sun 10 AM–6 PM

Name: Oracle Mushroom Co.
Bio/Story:
Oracle Mushroom Co., nestled in the forests of South Kent, Connecticut, is a small, gourmet mushroom farm devoted to cultivating fungi of exceptional quality and character. Founded and led by biochemist Spencer Lord, Oracle emerged from a deep reverence for nature and the transformative power of mushrooms—nutritional, medicinal, and otherwise. The farm bridges ancient wisdom and modern science, handcrafting each harvest with precision, sustainability, and love.

Spencer’s journey began not in agriculture, but in boyhood curiosity. Raised on a mountainside property in New Milford, his childhood was spent exploring the natural world, gathering mosses and newts, unknowingly building the foundation for a lifelong scientific fascination. This passion led him to a degree in Biochemistry and a minor in Biology, where he uncovered the profound interplay between organisms and the ecosystems they inhabit. But it wasn’t until an encounter with a wild reishi mushroom on his family’s land that his path crystallized: fungi were to be his life’s calling.

Through the solitude of the 2020 lockdowns, Spencer immersed himself fully into mycology, mastering wild foraging, cloning, species-specific cultivation, and the intricate balance of microbial life that sustains mushroom growth. Today, Oracle Mushroom Co. is both a farm and a movement—a dedication to reviving the ancient knowledge of fungi and making it accessible, beautiful, and practical for everyday life. Whether through fine dining menus or local farmers markets, Oracle’s mushrooms are a portal to deeper nourishment, connection, and natural wisdom.
Address: 110 Treasure Hill Rd, South Kent, CT 06785

Mushrooms

  • Lion’s Mane
  • Deep Blue Oyster Mushrooms
  • Golden Oyster Mushrooms
  • Chestnut Mushrooms
  • King Oyster Mushrooms
  • Seasonal mushroom varieties

Name: Our Kids Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the heart of its community, Our Kids Farm has cultivated a reputation for homegrown quality and personable service. With a passion for sustainable agriculture and a deep commitment to nurturing the land, this farm offers its visitors a truly local experience grounded in tradition and care.

Operating all year round, the farm welcomes guests daily, adjusting its hours seasonally to accommodate the rhythm of the land and its customers. Whether during the cool months of winter or the longer days of summer, Our Kids Farm remains a dependable destination for fresh offerings and a welcoming atmosphere.

In an effort to provide customers with transparency and planning convenience, the farm maintains a showcase of available vegetable and herb plants online. However, in-person sales ensure a hands-on, personalized shopping experience. This decision reflects their dedication to quality and the connection they maintain with their patrons and the community at large.

Name: Ox Hollow Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the heart of Litchfield County, Ox Hollow Farm has been a family-run beacon of sustainable agriculture since 1997. Founded by Mark Maynard, the farm grew from a mission rooted in health and integrity: to provide hormone- and antibiotic-free meat and produce to local communities. Drawing from over three decades of experience in beef farming, Mark cultivated a model grounded in conservation, rotational grazing, and self-reliance—growing their own feed, managing pastures holistically, and adhering to regenerative soil practices.

The farm's ethos is simple but resolute: local, natural, and honest. Mark and his partner Stephanie personally manage every detail, ensuring that all animals are raised humanely, seasonally pastured, and nourished on the farm’s own Non-GMO grains and hay. Their Angus beef, Berkshire pork, free-range chicken, and Dorper lamb reflect not just high-quality cuts but a commitment to soil, animal, and human health. In the colder months, animals are kept in open shelters with ample space, maintaining their comfort and well-being year-round.

Beyond livestock, Ox Hollow cultivates 23 acres of vibrant vegetable gardens using organic, Non-GMO seeds. With minimal spraying, hand-tended soil, and compost from their animals, every crop reflects the same care found in their meats. Their CSA program, farm stands, and regular presence at Connecticut and New York farmers markets embody their belief that fresh, local food should be accessible and trustworthy. Ox Hollow Farm is not just a place—it’s a promise kept, season after season.
Address: Farm Stand: 1474 Bantam Road (Route 202), Bantam, CT 06750 Barn Store: 478 Good Hill Road, Woodbury, CT 06798
Hours: Farm Stand: 7 Days a week, 11:00 AM – 5:00 PM, Barn Store: Saturday & Sunday, 11:00 AM – 5:00 PM

Name: Oxen Hill Farm
Bio/Story:
Oxen Hill Farm is a multi-generational, family-owned and operated USDA Certified Organic vegetable and flower farm with deep roots in Connecticut. The Suffield property has belonged to the Griffin family since the mid-1800s, tracing back to ancestors who emigrated from Northern Ireland. The East Granby parcel, used for most crop production, sits on land originally granted by the King of England in 1647—making the farm a living piece of colonial and agricultural history. Today, the 11th generation of the Griffin family carries forward this legacy with a commitment to sustainability, health, and community.

Originally launched as a CSA-focused operation in 2009, Oxen Hill Farm quickly became known for its diverse organic vegetable shares and vibrant, pick-your-own flower fields. The farm’s name pays tribute to “Spike and Tony,” two beloved oxen who once lived on the Suffield property, symbolizing strength, heritage, and the land’s enduring character. Each season, CSA members receive highly customizable shares and gain access to fields of fresh herbs and cherry tomatoes, strengthening the direct connection between farmer and consumer. Through these relationships, Oxen Hill not only feeds but nurtures a regional community of health-conscious families.

Their organic farming practices go well beyond USDA requirements. Every year, they undergo detailed inspections, record-keeping, and audits through Baystate Organic Certifiers. Now in their 14th year of certification and 17th year of organic management, the team at Oxen Hill stands as a model for transparency and ecological stewardship. More than a business, the farm is a lifestyle—one rooted in integrity, education, and shared abundance.
Hours: Tues & Thurs 2:00–6:30 PM, Sat 9:00 AM–12:00 PM

Name: Pat’s Pastured
Bio/Story:
Since its founding in 2002, Pat's Pastured has been a staple of ethical agriculture in New England. Centered in East Greenwich, Rhode Island, the farm has spent decades forging a deep commitment to animal welfare and environmentally sound farming practices. Known for its pastured meats and poultry, Pat's Pastured has become a trusted name among those seeking food they can trace—with pride and peace of mind—back to the land and animals from which it came.

The farm operates with a clear set of values guiding every aspect of its work: transparency, humane treatment of animals, and stewardship of the soil through regenerative agriculture. Patrons are not just customers—they are part of a shared mission for better food and a healthier planet. Every product is raised without shortcuts, from grass-fed beef to free-range eggs, always honoring the natural rhythms of the environment and the animals.

In addition to its revered livestock operation, Pat's Pastured also opens its fields to the community through educational programs and events like their Music & Dinner Nights—a fusion of good company, farm-fresh fare, and local culture. Whether it's a CSA share, a carefully curated meat bundle, or a Saturday trip to the farm store, customers are welcomed into a food system rooted in compassion, quality, and continuous growth.

Name: Penfield Farm
Farm Type: Beef, Pork, Poultry, Honey, Syrup, Eggs
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the heart of Portland, Connecticut, Penfield Farm is a testament to rural tradition and enduring family roots. This small-town farm has grown into a cherished staple of the local community, known not only for its high-quality meats but also for the immersive experience it offers visitors each Saturday. From the carefully raised animals to the bustling farm stand, every detail reflects a deep commitment to excellence and authenticity.

At the helm of the farm is Victoria Tchetchet, the farm manager who continues to foster Penfield’s reputation as more than just a place to buy food. It’s a destination—where customers are warmly welcomed and invited to take part in the rhythm of farm life. The farm stand, open Saturdays from 9am to 3pm, showcases a bounty including Aged Black Angus Beef, Berkshire Pork, lamb, chicken, and emu. Free range eggs have garnered a loyal following, selling briskly both at the stand and at Gardiner's Market in South Glastonbury.

Penfield Farm also distinguishes itself through its curated product offerings. Emu oil products—lotions, chapsticks, and soaps—crafted by Songline Emu are available, celebrated for their healing and cosmetic properties. Local honey from Full Bloom Apiaries rounds out the selection, reinforcing the farm’s connections to regional artisans and producers. With its blend of agricultural excellence and heartfelt community ties, Penfield Farm stands as a vibrant celebration of local food and farm culture.
Hours: Saturday 9 AM–3 PM

Name: Pesce’s Farm
Bio/Story:
Pesce's Farm has been a cherished part of Bolton, Connecticut since 1945. Founded by the Pesce family, the farm has grown generations of produce with dedication and care, becoming a landmark for fresh, local food. As a family-owned and operated farm, it maintains traditions rooted in over seven decades of agricultural passion and hard work.

The farm is known for its wide variety of seasonal fruits and vegetables, all grown on-site with a commitment to quality and sustainability. Beyond produce, Pesce's Farm also offers farm-fresh eggs, locally sourced dairy, and a selection of pantry staples including honey and preserves. Each item reflects a dedication to natural farming and supporting the surrounding community.

Pesce's Farm isn’t just a source of nourishment—it’s a place that carries the warmth of family tradition and neighborly connection. With a retail farm stand open multiple days a week, the Pesce family continues to provide customers with wholesome, homegrown food and a welcoming smile, honoring their long-standing legacy in Connecticut agriculture.
Hours: Mid‑June through Oct 31; Wed–Fri 10 AM–5:30 PM, Sat 9 AM–4 PM, Sun 9 AM–3 PM

Name: Pezza Farm
Bio/Story:
For over 75 years, Pezza Farm & Garden Center has remained a cornerstone of Rhode Island’s farming community. Family-owned and operated across four proud generations, the farm has grown steadily while staying true to its roots. With deep agricultural knowledge passed down through the decades, Pezza Farm continues to thrive through its dedication to quality, sustainability, and family tradition.

Every season brings something fresh to Pezza Farm, from the planting preparations of spring to the abundant harvests of summer. The farm boasts a wide array of offerings, including its own grass-fed beef and lamb, vibrant fruits and vegetables, and a celebrated array of baked goods. With locations in Johnston and East Greenwich, the farm maintains a strong presence in the community, welcoming visitors to enjoy both its fresh produce and an immersive family-farm experience.

More than just a marketplace, Pezza Farm is a destination—complete with flowers, garden essentials, hayrides, and seasonal events that make it a beloved local treasure. Recognized as Rhode Island’s Best Farm and Garden Center, Pezza Farm credits its success to a loyal customer base and the continued passion of its dedicated family team. Their mission: to nourish people, gardens, and community with integrity and heart.
Address: 2279 Plainfield Pike, Johnston, RI 02919 & 2657 South County Trail, East Greenwich, RI 02818
Hours: Johnston: Thu‑Mon 9 AM‑5 PM; East Greenwich: Daily 9 AM‑5 PM (closed Tue)

Name: Phantom Farms
Bio/Story:
Nestled in Cumberland, Rhode Island, Phantom Farms is a year-round destination imbued with charm, warmth, and a deep connection to the community it serves. Revered for its inviting atmosphere, the farm has cultivated a reputation not only as a bustling bakery and café but also as a cherished gathering place that celebrates the change of seasons with enthusiasm and tradition.

Guests are drawn to Phantom Farms for its delectable baked goods—including iconic muffins and celebrated pies like the signature Apple Pie and the decadent Fruits of the Forest—but they stay for the experience: cozy seating ideal for morning coffee, vibrant fall festivals brimming with seasonal fun, and a country store infused with comforting aromas and welcoming energy.

Beyond its bakery, Phantom Farms houses an expansive apple orchard featuring beloved varieties such as Macoun, Macintosh, and Honeycrisp. These offerings, alongside a flourishing garden center and a dynamic calendar of events, reflect the farm’s commitment to quality, hospitality, and creating memorable moments for every visitor who steps onto its grounds.
Hours: Daily 6 AM‑5 PM
Food Items:
Fruit

  • Macoun apples
  • McIntosh apples
  • Honeycrisp apples

Name: Pippin Orchard
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the heart of Cranston, Rhode Island, Pippin Orchard has long been a cherished pillar of the New England farming community. For decades, under the dedicated stewardship of owner Joe Polseno, this orchard has offered farm-fresh produce and a warm, welcoming spirit to generations of local families. The orchard, spanning over 17 meticulously maintained acres, is a testament to thoughtful cultivation and sustainable farming practices, including the strategic use of mulched grass to enrich the soil naturally.

Pippin Orchard is perhaps best known for its abundant and diverse selection of apples, ranging from Honeycrisp and Gala to Empire and Macoun. The trees are lovingly tended and pruned weekly, and the grounds are kept immaculate without the use of herbicides or artificial fertilizers—a rare commitment in today’s agricultural landscape. Guests are invited to enjoy pick-your-own apple experiences, with pricing set per bag, not per person or weight, ensuring a family-friendly outing in the orchard's lush rows of fruit trees.

Beyond apples, Pippin Orchard delights customers with a host of handcrafted goods. Inside the farm shop, customers find an array of fresh-baked pies, pastries, and the orchard’s beloved apple cider donuts. Gourmet muffins, farm-fresh eggs, and locally-made specialty items like preserves, jellies, syrups, honey, and ciders round out the offerings. Joe Polseno’s vision is clear: to create a space where quality, community, and tradition flourish—all rooted deeply in the fertile New England soil.
Hours: Daily 9 AM‑5 PM (seasonal)

Name: Quonnie Farms
Bio/Story:
Quonnie Farms began as a humble farm stand rooted in the heart of Charlestown, Rhode Island, quietly cultivating a tradition of local goodness. Over time, it evolved into a vibrant hub where farmers, bakers, and artisans converge around a shared vision of sustainability, craftsmanship, and community. Every element of Quonnie is thoughtfully curated, creating an experience that reflects deep connections to land and neighbors.

A charming blend of rural sensibilities and artisanal flair, Quonnie Farms offers a rich tapestry of locally produced goods. Visitors are welcomed by the scent of fresh bread, the flavor of regional cheese, and the opportunity to explore gardens where they can pick their own. With a market space, bakery, and inviting café, the farm not only celebrates seasonal bounty but elevates it through thoughtful presentation and care.

The soul of Quonnie Farms lies in its people—a collective of passionate growers and makers committed to nurturing both land and community. With an eye toward authenticity and purpose, the farm continues to grow, always guided by its mission of quality, connection, and care. In every loaf and leafy green, Quonnie tells a story of love for place and promise for the future.

Name: Radical Roots Farm
Bio/Story:
Founded in 2015, Radical Roots Farm was born from a passion for nourishing families with ethically raised, nutrient-rich meat. True to its commitment, the farm raises its animals in alignment with nature, using pasture and forest-based rotational grazing systems that honor both animal welfare and environmental stewardship. The owners hand-select the most resilient animals, ensuring quality and flavor in every product they provide.

Nestled across the towns of Canterbury and Sterling in Connecticut, Radical Roots Farm sets itself apart by refusing to use harmful chemicals or GMOs in any aspect of their operation. Their regenerative approach reflects a dedication not only to their craft but also to their community — delivering food they trust for their own family to the tables of others.

At the heart of Radical Roots Farm is a belief in transparency, sustainability, and responsible agriculture. Their mission is more than farming — it’s about reshaping how food is grown, shared, and respected. By reconnecting people to land and livestock, they cultivate not just nourishment but also mindful awareness and gratitude for the life behind every bite.

Name: Ridgway Farm
Bio/Story:
Ridgway Farm is a multigenerational family-run farm nestled in the hills of North Cornwall, Connecticut. Established in 1980 by Gordon Ridgway and his father Bruce, the farm was founded on a vision of changing the way food is grown—prioritizing taste, sustainability, and deep-rooted community values. Over the past four decades, it has evolved into a cherished local institution, known for its commitment to “beyond organic” methods, its preservation of heritage farming techniques, and its thoughtful stewardship of the land.

Gordon, alongside his wife Jayne and their three children, Elizabeth, Ian, and Rebecca, have made the farm a true home. Each family member contributes their own passions—from cattle care and flower arranging to market operations and tractor work. Their love for the farm is palpable in every detail, whether it's a bouquet of fresh flowers, a basket of heirloom tomatoes, or the quiet, humble presence of their 24/7 roadside stand. The farm not only raises produce and animals but also instills values of hard work, service, and harmony with nature—Gordon himself serving as Cornwall’s First Selectman and Jayne as an Advanced EMT.

In addition to producing organic vegetables and high-quality pasture-raised meats, Ridgway Farm is also known for its maple syrup, handmade flower arrangements, and community presence at local farmers markets. With the help of dedicated friends and seasonal workers, including artists, athletes, and lifelong neighbors, the farm remains a thriving example of local resilience and the enduring beauty of small-scale agriculture.
Hours: Farm stand & online ordering: 24/7 year round

Name: River Crest Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled in Milford, Connecticut, River Crest Farm is a small, community-oriented operation with a heartfelt commitment to sustainable practices and healthy living. Set along the scenic Oronoque Road, the farm has become a local hub for fresh produce and shared values, inviting neighbors to be part of something seasonal, rooted, and real. Its engagement through greenhouse sales and participation in the Downtown Milford Farmers’ Market highlights a mission-driven effort to bring farm-fresh offerings directly to the community.

Seasonal rhythm defines life at River Crest Farm. As summer arrives, the greenhouse opens its doors on Sundays, offering a selection of homegrown plants and vegetables. The farmstand reemerges alongside harvest peaks, showcasing what’s fresh and in season. Their Community Supported Agriculture (CSA) program has drawn in dedicated supporters, and the farm has even reached full capacity for its subscription list. This demand illustrates a powerful local trust in the farm’s quality, transparency, and authenticity.

Conservation and environmental responsibility are woven into the daily operations at River Crest. One notable example: the farm’s initiative to collect and reuse plant pots—a small but meaningful effort to reduce waste and promote circularity in agriculture. Though they've currently paused this practice due to overwhelming community participation, they're quick to direct supporters to other recycling avenues. More than just a provider of food, River Crest Farm cultivates a culture of care—for land, for people, and for the possibilities that grow between them.
Hours: Greenhouse open Sun 1 PM–4 PM

Name: River Ridge Farm and Market
Bio/Story:
Located in the heart of Connecticut, River Ridge Farm and Market embraces a regenerative, no-till approach to agriculture that prioritizes the health of the soil and community alike. The farm cultivates more than 200 varietals of fruits, vegetables, and flowers each year, combining passion with experimentation to offer a wide array of seasonal produce. Deeply committed to sustainable and organic principles, River Ridge Farm manages every acre in alignment with USDA organic standards, with plans for full certification in the near future.

Beyond their fields, River Ridge extends its mission through The Middletown Market, a year-round hub for local, responsibly produced food. Here, customers can find River Ridge-grown items alongside carefully sourced meats, dairy, pantry staples, and more from other New England farms. The farm’s CSA program also operates through this store, providing flexible access to fresh food in a way that empowers community choice and supports regional agriculture.

In addition to their own farmland, River Ridge stewards Rose’s Berry Farm in Glastonbury, applying the same organic and regenerative ethos. Seasonal berry harvests, greenhouse seedlings grown in biologically active Vermont compost, and a commitment to chemical-free farming underline their genuine care for land and health. With a vision rooted in ecological resilience, River Ridge Farm and Market stands as a thoughtful, transparent steward of both food and farmland.

Name: Riverbank Farm
Bio/Story:
Riverbank Farm, situated amidst the scenic landscape of Roxbury, Connecticut, carries a storied agricultural legacy that dates back to colonial times. Over the centuries, this fertile land has nurtured generations of farming families who once raised dairy cows and cultivated essential crops. Today, Riverbank Farm thrives as a certified organic operation, enriched by the nutrient-rich soil of the Shepaug River valley, proudly producing an impressive array of vegetables, herbs, and vibrant cut flowers without the use of synthetic fertilizers, pesticides, or herbicides.

At the heart of Riverbank Farm is the dedicated partnership of owners David and Laura Blyn. David’s journey to the farm began in 1989 when, initially captivated by the land's beauty while intending to pursue carpentry, he planted his first modest half-acre garden. By 1991, his passion had blossomed into full-time farming. Laura, who joined David after their serendipitous meeting during a produce delivery in the summer of 1996, brought with her deep agricultural knowledge and a shared enthusiasm for sustainable living. Together, the couple has weathered countless challenges—harsh weather, wildlife incursions, and long, demanding days—to establish a flourishing, resilient farm that reflects their profound love for the earth and each other.

Beyond cultivating crops, David and Laura have created the Riverbank Farm Kitchen, an innovative culinary endeavor that transforms their fresh harvests into delicious vegetarian dishes and fermented specialties. Their commitment to sustainable agriculture also extends to nurturing future farmers through a comprehensive apprenticeship program, equipping enthusiastic learners with the skills needed to run their own sustainable market gardens. David and Laura firmly believe that the bounty of Riverbank Farm nourishes not only the body but also fosters a deep, lasting connection to the land.
Hours: Farmers Markets: Westport, Darien, Greenwich, Old Greenwich, New Canaan, New Milford, New Haven Edgewood Park; Westport Winter Market, Wooster Square Winter Market; Available at Stores and Restaurants: New Morning Natural Store, Woodbury, CT

Name: River’s Harvest Farm LLC
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the Connecticut River Valley, River’s Harvest Farm has been a cornerstone of Middletown’s agricultural community for over two decades. What began as a modest homestead garden in the early 2000s has since blossomed into a vibrant, diversified farmstead known for its commitment to sustainable practices and land stewardship. Founded by the Miller family, the farm is rooted in a vision of nurturing both the soil and the local community, growing each harvest with integrity and care.

Today, River’s Harvest Farm continues to uphold its original mission: to provide fresh, local food grown without synthetic chemicals or corporate influence. Their approach centers on regenerative agriculture, using composting, rotational grazing, and cover cropping to maintain a healthy ecosystem. The Millers prioritize transparency and ethical farming, often welcoming visitors to tour the fields and learn more about where their food comes from.

Equally passionate about feeding bodies and minds, the farm also plays an active role in community education initiatives. They partner with local schools to teach students about seasonal crops and environmental stewardship, and regularly host farm dinners and workshops. Whether it's a crate of heirloom tomatoes or a loaf of fresh sourdough, every item from River’s Harvest Farm speaks to a deeper philosophy: that food grown with intention nourishes far more than the plate.
Hours: Open every day 9 AM–5 PM

Name: Rocky Brook Orchard
Bio/Story:
Nestled on Aquidneck Island in Middletown, Rhode Island, Rocky Brook Orchard stands as the original pick-your-own apple orchard in the area. The orchard has blossomed into a beloved seasonal destination, inviting community members and visitors alike to explore its vibrant rows of fruit trees. With over 80 varieties of apples—including many rare selections—the orchard continues to expand its offerings as new trees mature.

Family-run and deeply rooted in local tradition, Rocky Brook Orchard is more than just a farm; it's a place for discovery and connection. Guests are encouraged to roam the grounds in search of favorite apple varieties, or perhaps stumble upon a new one to love. The experience is inclusive and family-friendly, with many of the trees thoughtfully pruned to be accessible to even the smallest of hands.

Beyond its bountiful harvests, the orchard embodies a warm invitation to slow down and savor the simpler joys of autumn. Whether visitors arrive solo, in pairs, or as a group, they are welcomed with open arms—and even encouraged to stay a while with a picnic under the trees. The orchard does not accommodate pets, but it remains a cherished local escape for fruit lovers and outdoor enthusiasts alike.
Hours: U‑pick Fri‑Sun 10 AM‑4:30 PM

Name: Rocky Point Blueberry Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled just down the road from the scenic Rocky Point State Park in Warwick, Rhode Island, Rocky Point Blueberry Farm is a vibrant, family-run haven for fruit enthusiasts. Known for its exceptional picking experience, the farm offers seasonal visitors the chance to immerse themselves in the simple joy of harvesting fresh blueberries and unique seasonal treasures like pawpaws. For families and locals alike, the farm provides more than just produce—it’s a welcoming retreat rooted in community spirit.

The farm operates with a straightforward and warm philosophy: make fresh, flavorful fruit accessible to all while respecting the rhythms of nature. Their blueberries, praised for perfectly balancing sweet and tart notes, are available both for picking and pre-picked, catering to a range of customer preferences. With seasonal opening hours tailored around ripening cycles, the farm maintains a sustainable and customer-friendly model.

Rocky Point Blueberry Farm also brings people together with festive events like the annual Pumpkin Walk and Carving Contest, fostering a sense of celebration around the changing seasons. They communicate frequently through their Facebook page and invite direct interaction via email or on-farm visits. Through every bushel and berry, the farm continues to cultivate joy, tradition, and connection year after year.
Hours: July–mid‑Aug; Mon‑Thu 7 AM‑12 PM (Thu also 4 PM‑dusk); Sat 7 AM‑3 PM (Jul) or 7 AM‑1 PM (Aug); Sun 7 AM‑12 PM; closed Fri

Fruit

  • Pawpaws (fresh)
  • Frozen pawpaw pulp

Name: Rogers Orchards
Bio/Story:
Rogers Orchards stands as one of Connecticut’s oldest and most enduring family farms, rooted in the fertile hills of Southington since 1809. What began with Chauncey Merriman—a Revolutionary War veteran and early settler—has blossomed over eight generations into a thriving orchard that bridges heritage and innovation. His legacy was built on a deep connection to the land, and that ethos has been passed through centuries of family stewardship. From the early days of planting apple trees along Shuttle Meadow Lake to today’s ecologically certified practices, Rogers Orchards has remained steadfast in its commitment to cultivating wholesome, locally grown fruit.

The spirit of ingenuity has long defined the Rogers-Merriman family. From “Old Pickles” and his thousand Baldwin apple trees to Elijah Rogers’ bold decision to plant thousands of peach trees in Connecticut soil, each generation has dared to try something new. In the 20th century, Harold Rogers experimented with automated vending for apples, while his son “Bud” expanded the farm’s reach through a pioneering electric farm store. John Rogers built the bakery that now draws loyal customers year-round, and today, the family continues to evolve under the leadership of Peter Rogers, Greg Parzych, and Jeff Rogers—who returned home to launch Long View Ciderhouse, a small-batch cider operation that uses only fruit grown on the family’s land.

Now spanning 275 acres and offering over 20 apple varieties and 15 kinds of peaches, Rogers Orchards is not only a place to pick your own fruit, but a true cultural and agricultural institution. Its farm stands brim with orchard-fresh produce, fragrant baked goods, local delicacies, and beautifully curated gift baskets. As a proud Eco Apple® and Eco Peach™ grower, the farm leads with a whole-systems ecological approach that supports pollinators, biodiversity, and the long-term health of the land. More than just a family business, Rogers Orchards is a living story—of seasonal rhythms, community ties, and an enduring dedication to nourishing both land and neighbor.
Address: Sunnymount Farm: 2876 Meriden-Waterbury Turnpike, Southington, CT 06489 Shuttle Meadow Farm: 336 Long Bottom Rd, Southington, CT 06489 Cider Truck: 36 Long Bottom Rd, Southington, CT 06489

Name: Roots Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled in Tiverton, Rhode Island, Roots Farm is a certified-organic vegetable farm that champions both tradition and innovation. With a deep-rooted commitment to nutrient-dense and flavor-rich crops, the farm grows exclusively using no-till, regenerative, and human-scale methods. Their process centers on cultivating healthy soil, the foundation of a thriving and sustainable agricultural ecosystem.

The farm is a year-round source of organic vegetables, made available to the community through multiple channels: local farmers markets, a robust online store, and a seasonal farmshare program. These avenues help ensure that high-quality, organic produce is accessible to as many people in the surrounding community as possible.

At the heart of Roots Farm is a philosophy that views farming as both a practical necessity and a revolutionary act. With every crop they tend, they aim to inspire a deeper appreciation for food grown with integrity and care. The farm is not only a place of production but a cornerstone of community nourishment and ecological responsibility.

Name: Rose Orchards
Bio/Story:
Nestled in a tranquil outdoor setting, Rose Orchards Farm offers a charming and family-friendly atmosphere. The farm welcomes visitors of all ages to experience the joy of the outdoors, with a special focus on delightful, hands-on fun for children. Feeding the farm animals is a cherished activity here, adding a wholesome touch to every visit.

From U-Pick produce to a homey creamery and bakery, Rose Orchards Farm caters to a variety of farm-to-table interests. Guests can enjoy the fresh flavors of the season while strolling through scenic surroundings. Families are invited to celebrate birthdays, attend events, and even explore educational field trips on site.

At its heart, Rose Orchards Farm is a celebration of community, nature, and sustainable fun. The farm’s ongoing commitment to sharing agricultural life with visitors reflects a deep-rooted mission to connect people with where their food comes from and the beauty of rural traditions.

Name: Rose's Berry Farm
Bio/Story:
Established in 1908 and rooted in the fertile hills of South Glastonbury, Rose’s Berry Farm has long been a cornerstone of Connecticut’s agricultural tradition. For over a century, the Rose family nurtured the land, offering generations of families the joy of picking berries, apples, and pumpkins in the scenic embrace of Matson Hill. Famous for its "Breakfast-With-A-View," Rose’s became not just a place to gather food, but to gather memories—a sanctuary of seasonal abundance and rural charm.

In 2022, the Gondek Family became the proud stewards of this beloved farm, bringing with them six generations of Glastonbury roots and a deep dedication to sustainability. Under their leadership, the farm transitioned to being entirely pesticide and glyphosate-free, reaffirming its commitment to environmental care and the health of the community. Their vision carries the legacy of the Roses forward, balancing reverence for the past with an unshakable hope for a greener future. They have also partnered with River Ridge Farm and Market—an organic, no-till farm in Portland, CT—to manage seasonal berry and fruit production using regenerative practices that align with their shared values.

More than just a place to pick fruit, Rose’s Berry Farm is an evolving hub of seasonal joy and community engagement. From yoga at their September Market to flower picking in summer, every event is an invitation to slow down and reconnect with the land. With their eyes set on preserving the farm in perpetuity through development rights sales and thoughtful stewardship, the Gondeks continue to grow more than food—they cultivate heritage, connection, and a sustainable future for all.

Name: Rosedale Farms & Vineyards
Bio/Story:
Set against the backdrop of Simsbury’s rolling hills and nourished by the rich soils of the Farmington River Valley, Rosedale Farms & Vineyards has stood as a beacon of Connecticut agriculture since 1920. Now stewarded by the fifth generation of the Epstein family, Rosedale is far more than a farm—it is a living, breathing celebration of seasonal abundance, culinary heritage, and community connection.

Across the farm’s vibrant acreage, you’ll find a dazzling array of just-picked produce: sun-warmed heirloom tomatoes, fragrant basil, golden sweet corn, heritage apples, vine-ripened melons, and the kind of grapes that still carry the memory of the soil. These ingredients don’t just feed— they elevate. The farm’s produce is beloved by top local chefs and found in celebrated dishes across Connecticut.

Rosedale’s award-winning vineyard brings even more to the table, with over a dozen handcrafted wines—from dry whites and bold reds to playful rosés and subtly sweet blends—each made with estate or regionally sourced grapes and the same care that defines everything grown here. Tastings, flights, and weekend wine-by-the-glass events make the vineyard a destination in itself, while a scratch bakery and farm store round out the experience with pies, preserves, and carefully curated local goods.

Beyond its daily offerings, Rosedale is also home to beloved seasonal traditions: sunflower strolls, corn mazes, farm fests, live music, and elegant Chef-to-Farm dinners in partnership with Max Hospitality. It’s a place where weddings unfold under a canopy of grapevines, families pick raspberries in the summer sun, and every visit becomes a story worth remembering.

At Rosedale, every apple, every bottle, every bloom carries the imprint of time, tradition, and a family’s enduring devotion to the land. Visit once—and you’ll understand why it’s been a cornerstone of Connecticut farming for over a century.
Hours: 9am-6pm daily

Name: Russo's Roots
Bio/Story:
Nestled on 26 acres in the rolling hills of Canterbury, Connecticut, Russo’s Roots is a Certified Organic vegetable farm that blends tradition, curiosity, and stewardship into every row it cultivates. The land itself carries echoes of the past, once home to a Finnish chicken farm in the 1930s with its now-rare two-story coop still standing. Since 2015, farmers James Russo and Libby Tarleton have been transforming rocky pastures into thriving fields teeming with organic vegetables, restoring the soil through composting, cover cropping, and regenerative practices to breathe new life into old land.

James Russo is a first-generation farmer whose passion for growing began in the Pioneer Valley of Massachusetts and carried him through years of experience across the Hudson Valley and Long Island. There, he co-managed a 65-acre CSA feeding over 2,000 members. Libby, too, found her calling in agriculture after college, first working in vegetable fields, then among the ordered rows of Long Island vineyards. When the time came to build something of their own, they returned to vegetables—and to Connecticut—with a shared vision rooted in sustainability, flavor, and community.

Now in their tenth growing season, Russo’s Roots offers a wide range of Certified Organic vegetables—from everyday staples like carrots and tomatoes to adventurous offerings like ginger, red napa cabbage, and puntarelle. Through a popular CSA program, a vibrant farm stand, and a loyal presence at the Willimantic Farmers Market, the farm nourishes both body and soul. James and Libby’s thoughtful cultivation methods and deep reverence for the land result in produce that is not only beautiful and delicious, but truly restorative—for the eater, the soil, and the spirit of local farming.
Hours: Farm Stand Open: 9am-1pm on weekends

Name: Salmon Kill Farm
Bio/Story:
Salmon Kill Farm is a deeply personal endeavor, born not of a business plan, but of curiosity, instinct, and a respect for land and legacy. Located in Salisbury, Connecticut, the farm began when a family stumbled upon a historic homestead with bricks made from Salmon Kill Creek silt. What followed was an unhurried, beautiful unfolding—a daughter organizing the purchase of donkeys at age ten, goats introduced to manage invasive plants, chickens arriving years later, and an orchard planted with hopes bees might one day arrive. In time, bees did come—via their own apiary—and the once quiet plot grew into a certified organic and Certified Humane farm known for its award-winning honey, rainbow-hued eggs, and garden-to-pantry seasonal offerings.

Every product from Salmon Kill Farm reflects an intentional choice. Their honey is raw and unpasteurized, preserving the floral complexity of the native wildflowers, clover, fruit trees, and herbs that the bees forage on. Their chickens roam freely, live long, healthy lives, and produce marigold-yolked eggs in a kaleidoscope of colors—ivory, blue, green, brown, peach—each one unique. Their orchard and garden yield a mix of classic and uncommon fruits and vegetables, which they transform into small-batch chutneys, jams, and hot sauces. Everything is grown with care, harvested with reverence, and made with the simplest, purest ingredients.

Salmon Kill Farm is more than just a farm—it’s a statement. A quiet, daily commitment to regeneration, slow growth, and food that honors the land it comes from. Guided by farmers like Debra Bain and Claire Lasseur, the farm is held together by relationships—between people, animals, and soil. Their story is living proof that sustainable farming isn't built overnight, but grown slowly with love, humility, and the wisdom of trial and error.

‍

Name: Sanford Farm
Bio/Story:
Founded in 1978, Sanford Farm has become a cornerstone of sustainable agriculture in Exeter, Rhode Island. From the beginning, the farm was built on a mission to promote health through responsible stewardship of the land and careful, ethical treatment of animals. Founder Ted Sanford has led this commitment with passion and persistence, cultivating an environment where quality and sustainability walk hand in hand.

At the heart of Sanford Farm’s operations is a deep dedication to producing premium 100% grass fed, dry aged beef. By raising Angus-Hereford Cross cattle with the utmost care, the farm ensures that both the wellbeing of the animals and the quality of the final product are never compromised. The result is a rich, flavorful beef that reflects both the natural diet of the herd and the thoughtful craftsmanship behind every step of the process.

Sanford Farm's guiding principle lies in its embrace of what it calls the #sustainableMOOvement — a commitment to earth-forward practices and mindful food production. Rooted in the community and driven by purpose, the farm stands as a proud example of how tradition and innovation can come together to nurture a healthier future for both people and planet.

Name: Scantic Valley Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled in scenic Somers, Connecticut, Scantic Valley Farm has cultivated a heritage rooted in sustainable and conscientious farming. At the heart of its operation is a commitment to wholesome, naturally raised products, with a focus on hormone- and antibiotic-free meats. Visitors return season after season, drawn not only by the fragrant fruit offerings but also by the trust placed in the farm's transparent and ethical practices.

The farm specializes in small-batch production of Belted Galloway Beef and Heritage Pork, carefully raised to ensure both flavor and integrity. Strawberry and blueberry picking mark the height of the warm months at Scantic Valley, with sweet, sun-ripened fruit drawing families and neighbors together amid the fields. The farm also plays host to seasonal Flash Markets, planned throughout the spring, providing customers with access to fresh-cut meats and harvest delights.

What sets Scantic Valley Farm apart is its emphasis on connection—between people, animals, and the land. The folks behind the operation invite patrons to follow the feathered flag at the strawberry field, find daily updates via the Berry Hotline, or simply drop by to enjoy fresh flowers and flavorful cuts. It’s a joyful intersection of community, tradition, and responsible farming, harvested daily in every sense of the word.
Hours: Mon–Fri 8 AM–6 PM, Sat 8 AM–5 PM, Sun 8 AM–3 PM

Name: Schartner Farms
Bio/Story:
Founded in 1902, Schartner Farms has been a steadfast presence in the agricultural landscape of Rhode Island for well over a century. Located on 150 acres in the scenic town of Exeter, this multi-generational farm has grown alongside the community it serves, evolving from humble beginnings into a robust farming operation that blends traditional practices with modern offerings.

Today, Schartner Farms is far more than just a place to pick up produce. Visitors are welcomed by a full produce department, complemented by deli and cheese sections, a bakery brimming with fresh baked goods, and a signature line of jams and gourmet items. The farm’s expansion over the years includes a greenhouse, nursery, and gift shop, making it a destination for not only fresh food but also home and garden inspiration. Whether it’s pumpkin pies in the fall or freshly harvested vegetables from the fields each morning, the farm embodies the rhythms of the seasons.

At its core, Schartner Farms remains committed to offering high-quality, local goods while fostering a genuine connection with the land and its customers. The farm stand continues to be a community cornerstone where residents can experience the rich bounty of Rhode Island’s growing season. It’s a place where tradition meets freshness, and where every item sold tells the story of a farm deeply rooted in its purpose.
Hours: Call ahead for picking hours; no regular schedule

Name: Scotts Farm & Greenhouses
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the fertile Connecticut River Valley, Scotts’ Farms is a cherished family-run operation with a longstanding presence in the region. The farm prides itself on operating two distinct locations: Scotts’ CT Valley Orchards in Deep River and Scotts’ Farm & Greenhouses in Essex. Each site offers a unique contribution to the local agricultural landscape and embodies the family’s enduring commitment to cultivating high-quality, seasonal crops with an authentic, community-focused spirit.

Rooted deeply in tradition and faith, Scotts’ Farms weaves strong values into the fabric of its daily operations. A guiding verse from Proverbs — honoring the Lord with the first fruits — underscores their devotion to stewarding the land with purpose and gratitude. The farm's hours and activities adjust with the seasons and weather, signaling a harmonious rhythm with nature and a deep respect for the land they cultivate.

Whether visitors are coming to pick their own blueberries at the Deep River location or shop at the greenhouses in Essex, they experience more than just a transaction — they partake in a legacy of family farming. Scotts’ Farms continues to be a meaningful destination for those seeking fresh produce, rural beauty, and a tangible connection to the land and faith-driven values that sustain it.

Name: Scott’s Yankee Farmer
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the heart of Connecticut, Scott’s Yankee Farmer is a cherished multigenerational farm dedicated to bringing fresh, locally grown produce directly to the community. Passion for sustainable farming and a deep-rooted commitment to agricultural tradition are evident in every crop they grow and every product they share with visitors. With expansive fields filled with vibrant fruits and vegetables, it’s a place where the bounty of nature meets New England hospitality.

Owned and operated by the Scott family, the farm's mission is grounded in authenticity and transparency. They proudly list every item they grow, from garlic scapes and tomatoes to lush peaches and sweet summer berries. Visitors come not just to shop, but to engage in the timeless tradition of picking their own produce—a true celebration of the earth’s seasonal rhythm. The family’s hands-on approach and attention to quality keep customers returning season after season.

In addition to its diverse produce offerings, Scott’s Yankee Farmer enhances every visit with handmade donuts available on weekends, pairing the charm of traditional baking with the pleasure of farm-fresh flavor. Their consistent communication through newsletters and social media shows a community-first mindset. At Scott’s Yankee Farmer, farming is not only a livelihood—it’s a legacy rooted in hard work, integrity, and the joy of sharing a harvest well grown.
Address: 436 Boston Post Rd, East Lyme, CT 06333

Name: Secchiaroli Farm
Bio/Story:
Founded in 1911 by Alessandro Secchiaroli, Secchiaroli Farm has its roots in the rich agricultural heritage of Waterford, Connecticut. What started as a modest piggery has steadily grown over the decades under the stewardship of four generations of the Secchiaroli family. From the very beginning, the farm has maintained a deep commitment to quality, care, and tradition, becoming a trusted name in local livestock production.

Today, the farm is owned and operated by Jonathan Secchiaroli, Alessandro’s great-grandson, who has embraced the family’s legacy while infusing it with modern sensibilities. Guided by principles of sustainability and natural farming, the Secchiarolis provide honest and reliable customer service alongside top-tier livestock offerings. Their dedication to humane, responsible methods ensures that their products meet the highest standards for quality and integrity.

Over more than a century, Secchiaroli Farm has become more than just a place of business; it represents a lineage of dedication, resilience, and authentic connection to the land and community. With a focus on raising swine naturally and sustainably, the farm continues to serve as a beacon for thoughtful agricultural practices in the region.

Name: Shaggy Coos Farm
Farm Type: Dairy, Beef, Eggs, Poultry, Pork, Turkey
Bio/Story:
Tucked in the quiet town of Easton, Connecticut, Shaggy Coos Farm stands proudly as New England’s southernmost dairy—an operation built on principles of integrity, transparency, and deep care for animals and land. Founded and operated by Brittany, a passionate agriculturalist and mother, Shaggy Coos is a shining example of sustainable, small-scale farming. With a degree in Large Animal Science from Delaware Valley University and a master’s in Environmental Science, Brittany brings both heart and expertise to her farm. Her dedication has earned her the prestigious Alumni Achievement Award in Animal Science from her alma mater, and she actively uplifts her community through her work with the Fairfield Farm Bureau and local agricultural schools.

Alongside her trusted farm manager Rose—also a Del Val graduate and spirited 4-H leader—Brittany raises a variety of livestock in a humane, free-roaming environment. Every cow, pig, chicken, and turkey is raised with the utmost care, fed an all-natural diet, and given the freedom to thrive outdoors. The farm’s honor system store, open daily from 7 to 7, offers a nostalgic, self-serve experience filled with everything from hand-bottled cream-line milk and rich gelato to pasture-raised meats and eggs—all produced on-site with an old-world charm and modern ethical standards.

Shaggy Coos is more than a farm—it is a deeply personal mission to produce traceable, nutrient-rich food for future generations. Brittany farms for the future, for the land, and for her young son Kip, who will grow up knowing the rhythm of real farming. With cows named Clover, Tilly, Vienna, Indie, and Triscuit grazing happily in the pastures, every product that leaves the farm is a testament to the values of respect, quality, and quiet resilience. Shaggy Coos invites you to return to a simpler way of eating—one built on trust, care, and the enduring beauty of local food.
Hours: Open every day, 7:00 AM – 7:00 PM

Name: Shortt’s Farm
Bio/Story:
Founded in 1995 by Jim Shortt and his late mother Dolly, Shortt’s Farm began as a modest 4-acre farmstead nestled on Riverside Road in Sandy Hook. Their vision was simple yet powerful: to grow honest, nourishing food while offering a community gathering place rooted in tradition. Over the years, the Shortt family expanded the property, transitioning from a garden center to a fully functioning organic farm and CSA hub, keeping the original spirit of local, hands-on farming alive.

The farm has steadily grown through the decades, with notable expansions in 2008 and again in 2021, adding acreage and increasing their capacity to grow an impressive array of USDA-certified organic produce. Today, Shortt’s Farm is stewarded by Jim and his wife Sue, who are not only deeply committed to the land, but also to the future—building a legacy for their two sons and a farm that will hopefully carry into the next generation. Their popular CSA program connects local families to the harvest each week, while partnerships with small producers in the region enrich their offerings with meat, dairy, and pantry items.

The farm remains a cherished part of the Newtown and Sandy Hook communities, hosting an honor-based store, a bustling ice cream shop featuring Big Dipper homestyle scoops, and a presence at the Newtown Farmers’ Market. Whether picking up a CSA basket, chatting about heirloom tomatoes, or grabbing a cone after visiting the goats, Shortt’s Farm offers a warm, timeless experience—a true family operation grounded in integrity, stewardship, and love for the land.
Hours: Farm Store & Ice Cream Shop: 10:00 AM – 9:00 PM, every day

Name: Silverman’s Farm
Farm Type: Produce, Dairy, Honey, Syrup, Flowers, PYO, Orchard
Bio/Story:
Silverman’s Farm is a cherished family destination and working farm in Easton, Connecticut, founded in the early 1920s by Ben Silverman. A New York City native with a passion for gardening, Ben moved to Connecticut as a young man and eventually saved enough to purchase his first parcel of land on Sport Hill Road. His initial endeavor was a cider mill—one that became a local staple for over six decades. Ben lived modestly on the farm, slowly expanding the property and raising a family while building a reputation for hard work and agricultural excellence.

Through the mid-20th century, Silverman’s Farm flourished as a classic “truck farm,” growing a vast array of fruits and vegetables for local families who preserved them for the long New England winters. Ben and his wife Rose raised eight children, and their youngest son, Irv, grew especially passionate about fruit production. Irv took over the farm in the 1970s and ushered in a new era, transforming the property into a pick-your-own orchard and agritourism destination. Scenic tractor rides, a charming petting zoo, and educational school tours turned the farm into a seasonal tradition for countless Connecticut families.

Today, Silverman’s is still proudly operated by Irv and his extended family, who continue to blend heritage and hospitality into every corner of the farm. From rows of heirloom apples to bustling farm markets and whimsical animal enclosures, Silverman’s offers the quintessential farm experience. Generations of visitors return each year not just for the produce or pies, but for the sense of warmth and nostalgia that only a farm like this can provide. It is a living testament to a century of care, rooted in the Silverman family’s love for land, food, and community.

Name: Simpaug Farms
Bio/Story:
Spanning 250 acres of fertile Connecticut countryside, Simpaug Farms is a family-owned farm in Suffield dedicated to growing real food with care. Committed to sustainable and natural farming practices, Simpaug is not certified organic but proudly uses organic methods to cultivate a diverse mix of vegetables, fruits, and pastured meats—ensuring their offerings nourish both people and the land. Their fields yield everything from arugula to tomatoes, and their Black Angus beef and heritage pork are raised with integrity and respect for the animals.

The farm is a labor of love and community. With a roadside stand brimming with eggs, seasonal produce, and a variety of responsibly raised meats, Simpaug offers a tangible reminder of what farming used to—and should—look like. Their pricing is fair, their quality uncompromising, and their presence at local markets reflects a deep-rooted dedication to accessible, nutrient-dense food. Visitors are welcome not just to shop, but to engage—with farm tours, private events, and even weddings hosted among their rolling fields.

More than just a producer, Simpaug Farms is a steward of the land and a beacon of agricultural possibility. In an age of industrialized food, they offer an honest, hands-on alternative—where customers can see where their food comes from and meet the people who grew it. Whether you come for the eggs, the steaks, or the sweet crunch of fresh-picked blueberries, you'll leave feeling reconnected to something elemental, seasonal, and good.

Name: Slate Hill Cattle Company
Bio/Story:
Slate Hill Cattle Company is deeply rooted in a commitment to ethical ranching and sustainable agriculture. At the heart of their mission lies a dedication to raising high-quality Pinzgauer beef — a breed renowned for its resilience and superior meat quality. By prioritizing animal welfare and integrating humane treatment into every aspect of their care, the farm ensures that its cattle live naturally, in spacious environments with a stress-free, health-conscious approach to feeding and management.

The farm embraces regenerative agriculture as a guiding philosophy. Through rotational grazing practices, Slate Hill promotes soil health, biodiversity, and the rejuvenation of pastures. These methods not only support sustainability but help establish a thriving ecosystem that benefits both livestock and land. Every animal is raised with intention, and every part of the animal is respected — including the transformation of suet into grass-fed tallow, a versatile byproduct used in cooking, candle-making, and skincare.

Innovation plays a vital role in the farm’s vision for the future. Slate Hill Cattle Company blends modern technologies with timeless agricultural techniques to improve efficiency and herd health. Their aspirations include reducing carbon output, engaging with the local community through educational programs, and further advancing regenerative practices. Through this synergy of tradition and progress, Slate Hill stands as a conscientious steward of the land, setting the standard for ethical and sustainable cattle farming in the modern era.
Hours: Tue & Thu 3 PM‑6 PM; Sat 12 PM‑5 PM

Name: Smith’s Acres
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the heart of Niantic, Connecticut, Smith’s Acres has become a cherished cornerstone of the local agricultural community. With a prominent location on West Main Street, this family-owned and operated business has built its reputation by providing quality plants, produce, and floral arrangements. The farm’s dedication to freshness, customer service, and horticultural expertise has cultivated a loyal following that spans generations.

At the helm of Smith’s Acres are individuals deeply rooted in a love for farming and community. From offering a broad assortment of seasonal goods to hosting events that bring people together, the team works tirelessly to create a place that blooms with vibrancy and warmth year-round. Their passion is evident in every curated flower bouquet and every crate of locally grown produce brought to market.

Smith’s Acres exemplifies the values of sustainability, beauty, and service. More than just a garden center, it acts as a gathering place where patrons come not just to shop, but to be inspired. Their whimsical floral displays, friendly faces, and evident care for what they grow echo a mission that’s as heartfelt as it is simple: to help things grow—plants, people, and community alike.

Name: Smyth’s Trinity Farm
Bio/Story:
Smyth’s Trinity Farm in Enfield, Connecticut is a true rarity in the world of modern dairying—a family-owned operation where the milk never leaves the property. For nearly a century, the Smyth family has tended this land with devotion, evolving it from a humble Depression-era farmstead into a fully integrated dairy where milk is still bottled on-site. There are no tanker trucks here. Every drop of milk, every carton of yogurt, and every round of butter begins and ends its journey on the farm. That uncompromising commitment to quality and transparency has earned Smyth’s Trinity Farm deep respect throughout the region—including the 2016 Green Pastures Award, naming it Connecticut’s Dairy Farm of the Year.

At the heart of the farm is a family whose roots run deep in both the soil and the community. Today, the third generation—siblings Anne Dugas and Sam Smyth—lead the day-to-day operations with vision and vitality. Anne, who manages the farm and herd, represents a new era of women in agriculture, supported by her husband Jeremy and their children, who are already active in 4-H and FFA. Sam oversees wholesale and home delivery logistics, and also manages over 70 acres of hay to feed the farm’s grass-fed, pasture-raised cows. Together with their parents, Mike and Dale Smyth, who built the farm’s processing facility in the 1990s, they carry on a legacy of stewardship that blends tradition with thoughtful innovation.

Smyth’s Trinity Farm is more than a place to buy milk—it is a living system of care, community, and connection. The farm's “Milk and More Store” welcomes locals six days a week, while the home delivery service brings fresh milk, yogurt, and eggs to families across north-central Connecticut and western Massachusetts. Customers also find them at farmers’ markets in Ellington, Springfield, and New Haven. Whether it’s a bottle of rich, creamy milk or a dozen farm-fresh eggs, each product reflects a quiet excellence that comes only from knowing—and loving—every step of the process.
Hours: Monday–Friday: 6:00 a.m. – 6:00 p.m. Saturday: 6:00 a.m. – 4:00 p.m.

Name: Soeltl Farm
Farm Type: Beef, Poultry, Turkey, Pork, Eggs, Honey, Dairy
Bio/Story:
Tucked amidst a pastoral landscape, Soeltl Farm proudly identifies as 'Purveyors of Epicurean Livestock,' an appellation that reflects their dedication to quality and flavor. With an emphasis on traditional farming methods and animal welfare, the farm offers a finely curated selection of meats, dairy, and specialty pantry items, appealing to conscientious consumers and culinary enthusiasts alike. Their ethos appears rooted in a respect for the land and the animals they raise, with every offering shaped by an appreciation for good food and artisanal integrity.

The farm maintains a broad spectrum of livestock, from chickens, turkeys, ducks, and geese to veal, beef, and pork, showcasing a commitment to diversity and sustainability. In addition, Soeltl Farm features dairy offerings from both cows and goats — a rare pairing that speaks to the farm's breadth of animal husbandry. Egg production also plays a role in their offerings, further rounding out a selection that blends practicality with gourmet flair.

True to their artisanal branding, Soeltl Farm extends beyond the basics to present a selection of carefully crafted sweets and condiments. Among their pantry treasures are honey and cajeta — a rich, caramel-like confection made from goat’s milk — hinting at their dedication to both provenance and indulgence. These details, while sparse, provoke a sense of rustic refinement, suggesting a farm where heritage practices meet passionate craft.

Name: South Haven Farm
Bio/Story:
South Haven Farm is rooted in a shared vision of cultivating sustainable, high-quality produce for the greater New Haven community. At its core, the farm is committed to environmentally conscious growing methods, adhering to organic standards though choosing not to pursue official certification. This hands-on dedication is visible in every leafy green and vibrant bloom nurtured in their soil.

Operating out of Orange, Connecticut, the farm opens its gates to the public each Saturday for an on-site farm stand, and brings its offerings to Edgewood Park Farmers Market every Sunday. Their emphasis on fresh, locally grown vegetables, microgreens, and flowers resonates strongly with a community eager for authenticity and direct access to their food sources. Seasonal events like “Build Your Own Bouquet Nights” further deepen their connection to the people they serve.

Driven by a love for the land and a desire to foster community engagement, South Haven Farm embodies a grassroots approach to ethical agriculture. Whether through their weekly markets or lush seasonal floral experiences, the farm stands as a vibrant thread in Connecticut’s local food and farming tapestry.

Name: Staehly Farm & Winery
Bio/Story:
Founded in 1985 by Chris Staehly, Staehly Farm began as a simple cut-your-own Christmas tree operation nestled in East Haddam, Connecticut. Over the years, the farm steadily grew, evolving into a vibrant year-round business. By the early 2000s, greenhouses and a farm stand had been added, marking the farm’s expansion into new crops and deeper community offerings.

In 2014, Staehly Farm entered an exciting new chapter with the launch of its farm winery. Specializing in premium fruit wines crafted from their own orchards, the winery reflects a deep commitment to quality and tradition. The tasting room on Town Street and the Yankee Cider Barn Tap Room on adjacent Petticoat Lane offer guests a warm, rustic setting to enjoy the fruits of the farm — literally — through wine and hard cider.

Today, Staehly Farm & Winery remains a true family-run business, operated by Chris, his wife Gail, and their son Kevin. The Staehlys have built more than a farm; they’ve created a legacy of dedicated farming, thoughtful expansion, and community spirit that honors the rhythms of the seasons and the pleasures of agricultural life.
