Name: Stamp Egg Farm
Bio/Story:
Established in 1937 by Marie Stamp, Stamp Egg Farms has long stood as a proud family-run farm rooted in tradition. Located in Johnston, Rhode Island, the farm has sustained its legacy across three generations, holding firmly to the foundational principles that began with Marie’s vision. The farm remains deeply committed to sustainable practices and humane animal care, running its operations with integrity and timeless care.

The heart of Stamp Egg Farms lies in its flock of 3,000 free-roaming chickens, all nurtured on a wholesome vegetarian diet, free from hormones and steroids. With cage-free indoor coops and ample space, the chickens are cared for with attentiveness and respect. Eggs are hand-picked with care each morning and delivered fresh—often the very same day—to local bakeries, diners, and markets, ensuring flavor and freshness that industrial models can’t match.

Every aspect of farm life, from the early morning egg gathers to the mid-afternoon deliveries, is powered by family effort and love. With a commitment to preserving the rhythms of traditional farming, the Stamp family continues to deliver quality, honesty, and warmth in every dozen eggs. It’s a way of life they cherish, and a promise they renew with every carton sealed.

Name: Star Light Gardens
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the heart of Durham and Middlefield, Connecticut, Star Light Gardens is a dedicated organic farm focused on providing fresh, high-quality produce throughout all four seasons. The farm places a strong emphasis on sustainable growing practices, underscoring their commitment to environmental stewardship and community nourishment.

As a Certified Organic farm, Star Light Gardens prides itself on transparency and care in every stage of its operation. Their cultivation methods are designed to maintain the health of the soil and the vitality of their crops, resulting in flavorful, nutrient-rich food that reflects the rhythms of the land and the integrity of their mission.

Beyond farming, Star Light Gardens fosters a deep connection with the surrounding community through their CSA program, online store, and regular blog posts. They welcome customers to engage not just with their food, but with the stories and practices that shape it. The farm's vision is rooted in care—for the earth, for good food, and for meaningful relationships with the people they serve.

Name: Steere Orchard
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the heart of Rhode Island, Steere Orchard has been cultivating apples and peaches since the 1930s, establishing itself as a cherished destination for fruit lovers across generations. The orchard’s long-standing legacy is rooted in a dedication to traditional farming methods and a passion for harvesting the finest local produce.

Visitors to Steere Orchard are welcomed with the opportunity to engage in the cherished tradition of pick-your-own apples during the fall season. This hands-on experience allows guests to connect with the land and enjoy the freshness of fruit straight from the branch. The orchard’s peach season, running from August to September, also attracts eager patrons seeking the juiciest summer flavors.

With decades of history tied to the regional landscape, Steere Orchard remains a staple in the local agricultural community. Through its seasonal offerings and steadfast commitment to quality, the farm not only provides fresh fruit but also fosters connection—with nature, with heritage, and with the rhythms of the harvest calendar.

Name: Stefan Farms
Bio/Story:
Stefan Farms is a family-run farm nestled in Windsor, Connecticut, rooted in a deep commitment to health, sustainability, and community. The farm is operated by Mark, affectionately known as “The Farmer,” and Susanne, his wife, who describes herself as a farmer, herbalist, educator, and mother. After Mark's military service, the couple began farming to supplement their own food supply, leasing land they still work today. Over the years, their labor of love has grown into a robust operation serving their local community through CSA shares, farmers markets, and direct retail.

Guided by what Susanne calls a “Minimalistic-Alternative” approach, the farm champions non-GMO agriculture, avoids harsh chemicals, and favors soil health as the foundation for healthy produce. Their philosophy is simple but profound: healthy soil yields healthy plants, which in turn nourish healthy people. This integrity is reflected in their transparent farming practices and personal interactions with customers. Every vegetable is grown with care, and every customer interaction is treated as a moment of shared connection and education.

The family’s CSA program is not only generous and flexible but deeply personal. Rather than pre-packaged boxes, members choose their produce directly from the farm’s market tables, empowering them to select what they love and learn about new items. This market-style CSA runs from July through November and includes full, half, and fall share options. Susanne also uses the platform to share recipes, herbal knowledge, and reflections on homeschooling and parenting, making Stefan Farms feel more like a movement than just a farm. It's no surprise many customers describe the experience as nourishing both body and soul.
Hours: July–October: Thursdays 3–6 PM & Saturdays 12–3 PM November: Saturdays 12–3 PM

Name: Stone Gardens Farm Market
Bio/Story:
Stone Gardens Farm Market is the culmination of decades of care, family heritage, and a passionate commitment to feeding the local community. Owned by Fred and Stacia Monahan, the farm began as a roadside vegetable stand in Shelton, CT, and has grown into a full-scale, multi-generational operation offering everything from pasture-raised meats and fresh produce to prepared meals and grocery staples. The Monahans’ journey began in 1996, when they met working at neighboring farms. By 1998, newly married and full of ambition, they started Stone Gardens Farm with just a few acres and a shared vision of raising livestock and vegetables without the demands of industrial dairy life.

Their dream has evolved into a vibrant farm ecosystem, where each member of the Monahan family plays a role. Tommy, their oldest son, is a USDA-certified butcher who processes all meats onsite. Billy, their middle child, is a skilled welder who maintains farm machinery, and their daughter Sophie tends to the flowers, feeds the animals, and helps with the harvest. Beyond the immediate family, the farm is supported by a deeply connected network of friends, relatives, and community members, many of whom have worked on the farm through personal ties. This network brings a genuine sense of warmth and continuity to every aspect of their work.

Today, Stone Gardens Farm Market stands proudly in Huntington Center, offering a thoughtfully curated blend of farm-raised meats, seasonal produce, prepared dishes, pantry goods, and products from other local farms. Though the location has changed over the years—from a roadside stand to a full-fledged market—its soul has remained constant. Every item on the shelf reflects a labor of love, a respect for the land, and a belief that food should nourish not just the body, but the community. Stone Gardens is not just a market—it is a testament to tradition, integrity, and the enduring value of real food grown by real people.

Name: Stone Hill Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the rural landscape of Plainfield, Connecticut, Stone Hill Farm is a family-run operation focused on sustainable and ethical farming practices. Owned and managed by Jennie and Dan, alongside their three children, the farm is a testament to their shared commitment to providing wholesome food and respecting the natural ecosystem.

At the heart of their operation is 100% grassfed, pasture-raised beef. The care and attention given to their livestock reflect not only their dedication to raising healthy animals but also their desire to offer high-quality meat to their community. The emphasis on grassfed practices ensures a product that is both nutritious and environmentally responsible.

Stone Hill Farm is more than just a place of agriculture; it is a labor of love, nurtured by a family who believes in sustainability, transparency, and conscientious stewardship of the land. With an open invitation to connect, Jennie and Dan are approachable ambassadors of a lifestyle rooted in honesty, hard work, and a deep respect for nature.

Name: Stonewall Apiary
Bio/Story:
Nestled in Hanover, Connecticut, Stonewall Apiary is a passionate family-owned operation committed to the art and science of beekeeping. With approximately 350 honeybee colonies spread across eastern Connecticut, the apiary prioritizes the health of its bees above all. The philosophy is simple: healthier bees are more productive and sustainable, forming the cornerstone of everything they do.

Stonewall Apiary offers a diverse array of honey and beeswax products that showcase the fruits of their bees’ labor. From traditional liquid honey to creamed, comb, and chunk varieties, every jar tells a story of thoughtful care and deep-rooted expertise. Beyond honey, they craft soothing honey butter, elegantly simple beeswax candles, restorative hand salves, and practical wood polishes, all derived from their thriving hives.

Their commitment extends beyond commerce. By engaging with local communities through farmers markets and supporting pollination throughout many Connecticut towns, they champion both environmental stewardship and local ecosystems. Stonewall Apiary is more than a business—it’s a vibrant testament to the enduring relationship between people and pollinators.

Name: Stone Acres Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the rolling hills of historic Stonington, Connecticut, Stone Acres Farm spans sixty-three acres of natural beauty, cultivated fields, and heritage. With roots stretching back to 1765, the farm has stood as a testament to the enduring spirit of New England agriculture. Originally encompassing 225 acres and once serving as a dairy operation, Stone Acres has maintained continuous agricultural activity since before the Revolutionary War, making it a landmark of East Coast farming tradition.

Today, Stone Acres Farm thrives as a working farm that embraces sustainable practices and celebrates the relationship between land and community. Its mission is grounded in environmental stewardship and culinary education, with crops grown in harmony with natural ecosystems. From vibrant vegetable gardens to native flower beds that support biodiversity, the farm fosters a holistic agricultural model rooted in flavor, adventure, and ecological integrity.

Beyond its fields, Stone Acres Farm serves as a dynamic community hub. Whether through farmstand offerings, seasonal farm dinners, or workshops hosted by the Yellow Farmhouse Education Center, the farm champions the preservation of cultural, agricultural, and culinary heritage. Every initiative—be it growing greens or hosting guest chefs—is infused with reverence for the land's legacy and a vision for a more sustainable future.
Hours: Mon–Fri 10 AM–6 PM; Sat–Sun 9 AM–6 PM
Food Items:
Vegetables

Name: Strong Family Farm
Bio/Story:
Strong Family Farm stands as a vibrant community nonprofit farm, dedicated to preserving agricultural education and history. Nestled in the heart of Connecticut, the farm is an innovative blend of hands-on activities, youth education programs, and seasonal events. From summer camps to civil war reenactments, the farm brings generations together to learn, grow, and celebrate rural heritage.

The farm is deeply rooted in its community, supported by donations, members, and local sponsors who believe in the mission of sustainable agriculture. Their programs, such as the Backyard Chicken Program and community garden bed projects, engage individuals of all ages in active learning and productive farming practices. The recent completion of their Raised Garden Bed Replacement Fundraiser demonstrates the farm's commitment to growth and resilience, thanks to the concerted efforts of generous donors and partners like Sustainable CT.

Making good on their promise to offer local, healthy produce, Strong Family Farm operates a seasonal farm stand brimming with Connecticut-grown goods. Visitors can shop for fresh eggs, local vegetables, handmade baked goods, kettle corn, and sweet ice cream sandwiches while immersing themselves in the friendly atmosphere of this cherished community hub. Strong Family Farm continues to thrive as a place where past, present, and future meet through cultivation, community, and care.
Hours: Thu–Fri 1 PM–6 PM; Sat & Sun 10 AM–3 PM

Name: Stuart Family Farm
Bio/Story:
Stuart Family Farm stands as a deeply rooted legacy of sustainable farming in western Connecticut, tracing its origins back to 1929 when Henry Stuart first purchased the land. Nearly a century later, the family continues to farm with profound integrity across 800 acres of preserved land spanning New Milford, Bridgewater, and Roxbury. With a steadfast commitment to regenerative agriculture, they raise grass-fed, grass-finished Red Angus cattle, pastured Freedom Ranger chickens, and heritage-breed pork with humane, holistic care at the center of every practice.

The farm is proudly Animal Welfare Approved and was the first independent family farm in Connecticut to earn Certified Grass Fed status by A Greener World (AGW). Every animal is nurtured with mindful husbandry—grazing on organic hay and pasture grown right on the farm, without exposure to hormones, antibiotics, or GMOs. Their beef is USDA inspected and processed at Animal Welfare Approved facilities, ensuring complete transparency and ethical standards from pasture to plate. Customers can purchase meat by the cut or in bulk, and each product reflects the farm’s meticulous standards for health, flavor, and humane treatment.

At Stuart Family Farm, the values run deep—care for the land, reverence for the animals, and gratitude for the loyal customers who support their vision of clean, local nourishment. Whether it’s the richness of their beef, the savory flavor of their pork, or the unmatched texture of their pastured poultry, every offering is a testament to the family’s dedication to doing things the right way. With glowing praise from chefs and families alike, the Stuarts continue to inspire trust, health, and connection through food grown with conscience.
Hours: Saturdays: 10:00 AM – 4:00 PM Sundays: 12:00 PM – 4:00 PM

Name: Studio Farm Products
Farm Type: Produce, Beef, Poultry, Pork, Eggs, Flowers
Bio/Story:
Studio Farm is a multi-generational family operation dedicated to sustainable farming and nourishing their community with clean, responsibly grown food. Tucked across three vibrant properties, the farm is a collaborative venture where every family member takes part in tending the land — planting, weeding, pruning, digging, picking, and plucking with care and intention.

Embracing organic growing methods, Studio Farm cultivates a variety of fruits and berries, primarily sold through local farmers’ markets, their own CSA, and a farm stand. Leftover produce doesn’t go to waste; instead, it's transformed with heart and tradition into homemade jams the very same evening, bridging the field and kitchen with minimal waste and maximum flavor.

Their commitment extends to animal husbandry as well, offering pasture-raised beef, pork, chicken, and eggs. Every aspect of production, from pasture to preserves, reflects their values of stewardship, family involvement, and a deep love for working the land. Studio Farm isn't just a place of food production — it's a living expression of thoughtful, hands-on agriculture.

Name: Sub Edge Farm
Bio/Story:
Sub Edge Farm is a working landscape in the heart of Farmington and Avon, where food, family, and community come together. Owned and operated by Rodger and Isabelle Phillips, the farm blends organic farming practices with deep respect for the land's heritage. What started as a vision rooted in soil and stewardship has become a thriving hub for fresh vegetables, pasture-raised meats, and meaningful connection.

The farm grows over 150 varieties of vegetables, herbs, flowers, and small fruit, all without synthetic inputs or GMOs. Their livestock—grass-fed Belted Galloway cattle, Berkshire hogs, and pasture-raised hens—live as nature intended, with space to roam, forage, and grow slowly. This isn't just food grown with care; it's food grown with conscience.

Through their CSA program, farm shop, and long-standing partnerships with local chefs and restaurants, Rodger and Isabelle have created more than a farm—they’ve built a place where people come to connect with what nourishes them. Sub Edge hosts seasonal farm dinners, cooking workshops, and events that turn harvest into celebration. Whether you’re picking up your weekly share or toasting under string lights on a summer evening, you feel the same thing: this is a farm that feeds more than just hunger.
Hours: Tuesday–Saturday: 10 AM – 6 PM Sunday: 10 AM – 3 PM Monday: Closed

Name: Sun One Organic Farm
Bio/Story:
Sun One Organic Farm is a small but vibrant farmstead nestled within the rolling, fertile hills of Bethlehem, Connecticut. The Maddox family has tended this land since the 1890s, and it has remained a constant in the local agricultural landscape for over a century. Originally a dairy operation known as Three Springs Farm, it evolved into Sun One Organic Farm in 1998 when Rob Maddox inherited the land and reimagined its purpose with a deep commitment to sustainable farming and environmental ethics.

Rob Maddox brings a rare combination of political acumen, business expertise, and environmental passion to the farm. With an MBA from the University of Connecticut and years of service in local and state government, Rob pivoted toward green energy initiatives before returning to his roots in Litchfield County. That same devotion to ecological responsibility now guides every aspect of Sun One's operations. Under his stewardship, the farm employs no-till organic practices and works tirelessly to grow nutrient-dense produce that nourishes both people and the planet.

But Sun One is more than just a farm—it’s a community space, creative haven, and deeply personal expression of place-based living. With Airbnbs including a thoughtfully restored silo and a tranquil geodesic dome, visitors are invited to step into a slower rhythm and connect with the land. The farm also hosts weddings, events, and immersive internships, offering others a chance to live and learn within its ecosystem. Every inch of Sun One is a testament to Rob’s vision: that authenticity, care for the earth, and the sharing of beauty are at the heart of a life well-lived.

Name: Sunny Meadow Farm
Bio/Story:
Sunny Meadow Farm, nestled in the picturesque town of Bridgewater, Connecticut, embodies a profound dedication to sustainability, humane animal care, and environmental stewardship. At the heart of the farm is an unwavering commitment to cultivating produce free of pesticides, raising animals humanely, and preserving the natural integrity of the land. Every crop planted, animal raised, and drop of maple syrup bottled reflects an earnest passion for offering fresh, wholesome foods directly to the community.

The farm's day-to-day operations are skillfully overseen by Jon Lindblom, an experienced local farmer who brought over a decade of agricultural expertise and CSA management to Sunny Meadow Farm. Jon's devotion to sustainable practices ensures that the farm produces some of the finest pasture-raised poultry in the region, alongside an array of fresh seasonal vegetables and fruits. Under his careful supervision, the farm also crafts pure maple syrup, a cherished local delicacy made from sap harvested each winter from the farm's maple trees.

In addition to produce and poultry, Sunny Meadow Farm maintains a delightful menagerie of animals including sheep and goats. Managed tenderly by Helen Blackwood, the livestock program showcases a harmonious approach to animal husbandry. Sheep of the Texel breed graze peacefully alongside their playful goat companions, each receiving specialized diets to match their natural behaviors—sheep grazing the pasture grasses, and goats browsing twigs and leaves. This attentive, respectful care results in animals that thrive, providing a charming, vibrant addition to the farm's overall ethos of conscientious farming.

Name: Sunset Farm
Bio/Story:
Hickory Hill Milk is a multi-generational family-owned dairy farm rooted in the scenic countryside of Argyle, New York. Established with a devotion to traditional farming practices and a forward-thinking outlook, the Smith family has created a business that honors its agricultural heritage while adapting to the evolving needs of today's consumers.

From the very beginning, Hickory Hill has been passionate about producing the highest quality dairy products. Their Grade A offerings—from creamy milk and rich eggnog to artisan-style Greek yogurt and cheddar—are made with diligence and an obvious reverence for the land and animals they steward. Their commitment to freshness and minimally processed products is evident in every offering they proudly stock.

Community and connection are at the heart of Hickory Hill Milk’s mission. Through their farm store and local outreach, they aim to provide nourishing food while educating others about local agriculture and sustainability. Their shelves, lined with not only dairy but also jams, jellies, and farm apparel, reflect a heartfelt effort to share their farm’s bounty and story with everyone who visits.

Name: Sunset Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the heart of Narragansett, Sunset Farm stands as one of Rhode Island’s enduring agricultural icons, with over 150 years of history behind its name. As one of the last working farms in the area, it has become a beloved pillar of the community, cherished for its commitment to high-quality, farm-fresh offerings. The farm’s legacy intertwines deeply with the region, sustaining traditions of farming excellence while nourishing generations of Rhode Islanders.

Sunset Farm is renowned for its dedication to sustainable, humane farming practices. Their all-natural, pasture-raised beef has earned the respect and loyalty of local families and food enthusiasts alike. Customers trust Sunset Farm not only for its rich flavors and tender cuts but also for the peace of mind that comes from knowing their food is responsibly raised. The farm’s produce is equally revered—found not only at their busy farm stand but also in many of the area's restaurants and grocery stores.

Beyond the fields and farmstand, Sunset Farm cultivates a spirit of community and hospitality. Guests are welcomed like family, whether stopping by for freshly baked pies, sampling the famous chocolate chunk cookies, or attending seasonal events. With a blend of tradition, transparency, and a genuine love for the land, Sunset Farm continues to define what it means to farm with purpose and pride in Rhode Island.
Hours: Daily 9 AM‑6 PM

Name: Sunset Orchards
Bio/Story:
Sunset Orchard stands as a testament to over a century of agricultural heritage in Rhode Island. Founded in 1910, it has long been a cherished destination for families and individuals seeking the bounty of fresh, locally grown fruit and seasonal treats. What began as a humble orchard has grown into a well-loved institution, deeply embedded in the fabric of the community.

With a distinct focus on apples and peaches, Sunset Orchard takes pride in its carefully nurtured trees and the quality of its harvest. Each season, visitors are welcomed to explore the land, partake in the harvest, and enjoy the fruits of generations of care and cultivation. Whether it’s strolling through sun-dappled rows of trees or selecting a sweet treat from the farm stand, the experience reflects a commitment to simple, farm-fresh living.

At its core, Sunset Orchard cherishes tradition, sustainability, and a deep respect for the land. The farm's doors open rain or shine, reflecting their dedication to customers and the belief in better food sources. The orchard explicitly honors food safety regulations and community trust, reminding all that no dogs are permitted, as per state guidelines. Offering more than just produce, Sunset Orchard provides a space for creating meaningful memories amid the rhythms of the harvest season.
Address: 240 Gleaner Chapel Rd, North Scituate, RI 02857

Name: Sweet Wind Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled along Route 179 in East Hartland, Connecticut, Sweet Wind Farm is a multi-generational haven of homegrown abundance and cherished traditions. Founded and lovingly run by the Case family, the farm’s heartbeat is its rich maple sugaring heritage, dating back more than 50 years. It all began with Arlow Case Jr., who as a young boy, learned the art of syrup making from his parents in a backyard sugarhouse affectionately called “Arlow’s Sugar Shack” in Granby, CT. Today, that tradition lives on through a modern sugarhouse built in 2005, where the family still boils sap harvested from a sprawling sugarbush spread across seven towns in two states.

But Sweet Wind Farm is far more than a sugaring operation. Susan Case brings her love of plants, flowers, and education to the farm’s daily rhythm. From cultivating vibrant blooms and greenhouse treasures to creating specialty foods and leading classes, her imprint is felt in every corner of the land. Together, Arlow and Susan tend the soil, plant and harvest crops, sell at markets, and welcome the community to their sugarhouse and farmstand. From raspberries to rhubarb, zinnias to zucchini, everything is grown with deep care and without the use of chemical sprays or fertilizers.

Sweet Wind Farm isn’t just a business—it’s a living embodiment of stewardship, family, and connection to the land. Whether you visit for maple syrup during sugaring season, wander through their colorful flower displays in summer, or browse homemade goods at their roadside stand, you’ll find more than just food. You’ll find history, warmth, and the quiet joy of a family farm doing things the right way.
Hours: Open daily, 9:00 AM – 5:00 PM (subject to seasonal variation)

Name: Sweet Berry Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled in scenic Middletown, Rhode Island, Sweet Berry Farm is a cherished destination for locals and visitors alike. Originally built as a post-and-beam structure, the farm blends traditional charm with modern sustainability. Just minutes from downtown Newport, this community-oriented farm has become synonymous with crisp farm-fresh produce, bucolic charm, and an inviting atmosphere.

At the heart of Sweet Berry Farm’s mission is a commitment to sustainable agriculture. Their fields yield seasonal fresh fruits and vegetables, with a thriving pick-your-own program that begins with strawberries in June and continues through the fall harvest of apples and pumpkins. The farm’s dedication extends beyond the fields, with a market and café offering meticulously crafted sweets, gourmet dinners, and premium dairy treats sourced in part from local artisans.

More than just a place to shop or dine, Sweet Berry Farm functions as a community hub. From hand-picked blueberries to orchard-fresh peaches, everything they offer reflects a devotion to quality and care. Over the years, this dedication has earned the farm a host of accolades, including numerous local and regional awards celebrating its excellence in farm-to-table offerings and customer experience.
Hours: Late May–Dec: daily 8 AM‑6 PM

Name: Sweet Grass Creamery
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the heart of Preston, Connecticut, Sweet Grass Creamery is a fourth-generation farmstead creamery passionately devoted to producing some of the purest and most flavorful dairy products in the state. The farm's origins stretch back to 1898, when the Mattern family first settled on this land, driven by a belief in the value of hard work, stewardship, and community. Over the decades, the land evolved—from orchards to dairy cattle, from setbacks to rebirth—culminating in the founding of Sweet Grass Creamery, a small but mighty operation rooted in tradition and committed to excellence.

Today, under the leadership of Ed Mattern and his partner Carol Wojtkun, Sweet Grass Creamery is a full-circle dairy, managing every step of the process: from raising healthy, happy Jersey cows on lush rotationally grazed pastures to handcrafting milk, yogurt, and cheeses directly on-site. The creamery’s philosophy is simple yet profound—treat the land and animals with respect, and in return, you’ll be given milk that is naturally rich, nutritious, and delicious. Their Creamline milk is minimally processed using low-temperature pasteurization and is never homogenized or separated, preserving its full flavor and integrity, just the way nature intended.

What makes Sweet Grass Creamery especially remarkable is its dual dedication—to old-fashioned quality and modern sustainability. The farm uses no pesticides, antibiotics, or synthetic hormones, and partners with a vibrant community of local growers to offer not only their own artisan dairy but also fresh meats, eggs, produce, and pantry staples at their farm market. With every bottle of golden milk, every velvety spoonful of yogurt, and every wedge of handcrafted cheese, Sweet Grass Creamery invites you to savor a better, more beautiful way of eating—one deeply connected to land, animals, family, and the seasons.
Hours: Farm market daily 9 AM–6 PM

Name: The 4 Five Farm
Bio/Story:
Rooted in the fertile hills of Bloomfield, Connecticut, The 4 Five Farm is a family-run homestead that exemplifies the promise of regenerative, small-scale agriculture. Founded by the Duesing family—Kassie, Daniel, and their children Zoe, Charlotte, and Kingston—the farm began in 2020 with the leasing of Hawk Hill Farm through a partnership with Traprock Ridge Land Conservancy. Since then, the family has expanded operations to their own land on Duncaster Road and additional grazing pastures in Simsbury. United by a love for nature and a belief in soil health, The 4 Five Farm is a quiet force of integrity in modern farming.

At its heart, the farm is built on a deep respect for the animals they raise and the community they feed. Specializing in pasture-raised poultry and eggs, organically-fed chicks, and sustainably raised lamb and pork, the Duesings provide high-quality nourishment while remaining committed to ethical stewardship. Their roadside egg stand is open 24/7 on the honor system, a simple testament to the trust they extend to their customers. Meanwhile, their chick operation—complete with a thoughtful Rooster Reassurance policy—reflects the farm’s personal attention to each life they nurture.

With vegetables returning in 2025 and an eye toward continual growth, The 4 Five Farm is both a working farm and an ever-evolving family story. The land they lease and love is not just a place of production, but of learning, renewal, and connection. Whether you’re picking up chicks, placing a pork share order, or simply grabbing a dozen eggs from the porch stand, you’ll feel the warmth of a farm that grows more than food—it cultivates care, transparency, and a return to what's real.
Hours: Roadside Stand Open 24/7

Name: The Cow’s Coop
Bio/Story:
The Cow’s Coop is a heartfelt celebration of farm life, artisan craftsmanship, and a beloved herd of dairy cows. Tucked away in Canton Center on Perry’s Dairy Farm, this family-run business has built a reputation not only for its pasture-raised meats and farm-fresh eggs, but for its stunning line of handcrafted soaps. Each bar, made from nourishing cow and goat milk, carries with it a story—genuine, rustic, and full of care.

Open daily with a charming self-serve farm stand, The Cow’s Coop is more than a store—it’s an invitation into the rhythm of a working dairy farm. The shelves are stocked with Cabot Creamery dairy (proudly produced by their own cows), farm eggs, seasonal meats, small-batch soaps, and other locally sourced delights. The space is thoughtfully curated to reflect the richness of Connecticut’s countryside, offering visitors a taste of rural life in every product.

What sets The Cow’s Coop apart is its deep connection to the animals that make it all possible. The mission, beautifully etched into the heart of the brand, is simple yet profound: every bar of soap starts with a well-loved herd. That love shines through in every interaction, whether you’re picking up beef for dinner or designing custom soaps for a wedding. With authenticity, warmth, and community at its core, The Cow’s Coop is both a local treasure and a testament to the enduring spirit of small-scale farming.
Hours: Open every day: 8:00 AM – 8:00 PM (Self-serve farm stand)

Name: The Farm - Woodbury
Farm Type: Produce, Beef, Eggs, Dairy, Honey, Syrup
Bio/Story:
Nestled among the gentle hills and fertile river-bottom soils of northern Woodbury, Connecticut, The Farm is an agricultural haven devoted to growing diverse, non-GMO produce, vibrant flowers, and sustainably raised meats. Founded in 1988, The Farm has grown steadily, guided by a family deeply rooted in agriculture. The property spans approximately 180 lush acres, where fields of vegetables and flowers flourish alongside greenhouses teeming with carefully tended plants and transplants. Emphasizing a holistic, integrated approach, The Farm practices soil conservation, composting, and Integrated Pest Management to maintain environmental balance.

The farm’s dedicated stewardship is led by a passionate family team, now into its second generation of growers. Initially dairy farmers in Newtown, Connecticut, the family faced the pressures of rising land values in the 1980s and adapted by moving operations to Woodbury, continuing their farming tradition. Over decades, they've expanded carefully—not to become the largest farm, but rather to remain sustainable and secure for their growing families and community. Beyond vegetables, The Farm nurtures honeybees and operates a thriving sugarbush for maple syrup production under the Woodbury Sugar Shed brand, originating as a modest backyard hobby in 1982 and now producing hundreds of gallons of high-quality maple syrup annually.

Deeply connected to their local community, The Farm actively supports local educational programs, charities, and town initiatives. They foster agricultural education by employing local high school agri-science students, passing valuable skills onto the next generation. With offerings that span seasonal CSA programs, an accessible farmstand, and innovative pre-paid Harvest Cards, The Farm remains devoted to providing families with nutritious, locally-grown foods year-round. At the heart of it all is a steadfast mission: to cultivate not only exceptional produce but also a profound understanding and appreciation for the land that sustains us.

Name: The Farm Truck at Hein Farm
Bio/Story:
Tucked into a historic stretch of farmland in Farmington, Connecticut, The Farm Truck at Hein Farm is a vibrant, woman-owned operation that blends agricultural tradition with modern community connection. The land, farmed by the Hein family for over 200 years, found new life in 2020 when Jennifer Villa officially took the reins. A lifelong Connecticut resident and landscape designer by trade, Jennifer had long been passionate about plants, classic farm trucks, and locally grown food. In 2017, she launched Farmington Farm Truck—a mobile farmers market born of these loves—and by 2020, it blossomed into a full-fledged farm and permanent stand at 303 Meadow Road.

Today, Jennifer stewards 22 acres of farmland, actively growing on five, with a deep commitment to organic practices and soil health. Her vision includes a robust garden center, cut-your-own flower gardens, and a bustling farm stand filled with fresh produce—both homegrown and sourced from other Connecticut farms. The farm is also home to a flock of free-ranging, bell-wearing “jingle chickens,” who delight visitors young and old. Whether you're picking up heirloom tomatoes, cutting flowers in bloom, or enjoying a CSA share of local abundance, the farm is designed to reconnect people with the joys of real food and seasonal living.

Beyond growing food, The Farm Truck at Hein Farm cultivates community. Signature events like the Chickenstock Music Festival and Firefly Fridays draw crowds with live music, food trucks, hayrides, and more. Jennifer also honors the land’s legacy by supporting local nonprofits, youth programs, and creating the annual David and Martha Hein Agriculture Scholarship, awarded to Farmington High students pursuing agricultural paths. The farm is not only a place to shop or stroll—it’s a hub of education, celebration, and enduring stewardship, deeply rooted in the belief that local is not just better—it’s essential.

Name: The Pickin' Patch
Bio/Story:
Nestled at the foot of Avon Mountain with sweeping views of the Farmington Valley, The Pickin’ Patch at Woodford Farm is one of Connecticut’s oldest continually operating farms—boasting a rich agricultural legacy that spans over 300 years. Once a dairy and tobacco farm, The Pickin’ Patch has evolved gracefully into a beloved destination for flowers, produce, and family-friendly agritourism. Now operated by the latest generation of the same family, the farm remains a vital thread in the region’s fabric of seasonal celebration and local food.

From April through October, the farm stand and greenhouse are a hub of activity. The Pickin’ Patch offers a spectacular range of annual and perennial flowers, vegetable plants, and Pick-Your-Own opportunities for both fruits and vegetables. Come autumn, the farm comes alive with pumpkins dotting the fields, free hayrides on weekends, and the comforting smells of hot cider, donuts, and apple fritters. It's a festive and nostalgic setting that invites families to slow down and savor the season.

Beyond its scenic beauty and agricultural offerings, The Pickin’ Patch is built on generations of tradition and care. The legacy of long-time greenhouse manager Christine Jacob, whose presence helped shape the farm’s character for decades, speaks to the deep human roots behind the rows of plants and pumpkins. Whether you're picking zinnias in the summer or choosing the perfect jack-o’-lantern in October, visiting The Pickin’ Patch feels like stepping into a timeless slice of New England farm life.
Hours: 9:00 AM – 5:00 PM (in season; typically April–October)

Name: Three Sisters Farms
Bio/Story:
Nestled in Essex, Connecticut, Three Sisters Farms has been a cherished family endeavor since 1999. Led by Glenn and Stasia alongside their daughters—Anastasia, Nadia, and Kyra—and their sons-in-law, Roderick and Malcolm, this multigenerational team crafts a remarkable array of artisanal products. Their offerings are rooted in a commitment to natural, sustainable practices, using organic hive management techniques to produce some of the region’s most celebrated honey.

From its inception, the farm has stood out for its dedication to quality and authenticity. All of their goods—from golden, raw honey to soothing goat milk soaps and beeswax candles—are created by hand, reflecting years of honed craftsmanship and a passion for natural living. Their products are not only available through curbside pick-up and online ordering but also at select local retail partners in Essex and Old Saybrook, making their reach both personal and community-focused.

At its heart, Three Sisters Farms is more than just a purveyor of local goods—it is a reflection of family heritage, ecological mindfulness, and a heartfelt desire to share the abundance of the land. Through every jar, bar, and balm, the farm tells a story of care, connection, and the enduring beauty of doing things the right way.
Hours: By appointment, order online

Name: Tockwotten Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the heart of North Kingstown, The Farm Stand at Tockwotton Farm is a treasured family-run venture with roots reaching back to the 1970s. For decades, this small but passionate enterprise has dedicated itself to cultivating fresh produce for the local community. The farm operates with deep respect for the land, ensuring each harvest upholds their longstanding commitment to quality and environmental responsibility.

Though not certified organic, Tockwotton Farm proudly adheres to all organic farming guidelines — no pesticides, no chemicals, just naturally grown vegetables picked straight from the garden at the peak of freshness. Their stand reflects more than just a business; it's a labor of love where each carrot, tomato, and cucumber is the result of careful, mindful farming practices and an unwavering passion for honest produce.

Beyond its offerings, the farm serves as a communal hub during its seasonal operation from June through September. Locals and visitors alike are welcomed with warmth, encouraged to explore not just the bounty of the farm, but the values that have sustained it — integrity, dedication, and a timeless connection to the soil.

Name: Tonn's Marketplace
Bio/Story:
Tonn’s Marketplace is a vibrant, family-run farm and market in Burlington, Connecticut, proudly rooted in three generations of agricultural tradition. Founded over fifty years ago by Herbert and Arlene Tonn, the farm began as a humble roadside stand offering strawberries and soon flourished into a beloved community staple. Herbert cleared the land by hand, planted the earliest fruit trees, and built a greenhouse, setting the foundation for a legacy of fresh produce and heartfelt service that continues today.

Throughout the decades, the Tonn family has remained steadfast in their dedication to the land and their community. As the farm expanded into Terryville and began attending weekly farmers markets, it became a full-fledged family affair, with siblings and children pitching in. The late Paul Tonn, known for his tireless work ethic and deep love of farming, was instrumental in keeping the operation alive through challenging times. Today, his legacy is lovingly carried forward by Jordan and Aubri Tonn, along with their daughter Sienna, who warmly welcomes guests as they arrive at the bustling Marketplace.

Tonn’s Marketplace is more than just a farm—it’s a destination. With greenhouses bursting with tomatoes, orchards offering pick-your-own peaches and apples, and fields filled with crisp vegetables, the farm invites visitors to experience the richness of Connecticut agriculture firsthand. The addition of Farmstead Ice Cream, a concert stage, and a variety of community events including yoga, seasonal festivals, and holiday celebrations make Tonn’s a dynamic hub of food, family, and fun. Recognized as the Best Farm Stand in Connecticut for five years running, Tonn’s Marketplace continues to honor its roots while growing joyfully into the future.

Name: Toplands Farm
Bio/Story:
Toplands Farm, nestled on 600 pristine acres in Roxbury, Connecticut, is a working landscape rich in history, tradition, and community spirit. Originally a dairy farm, it was purchased in 1942 by A. Richard and Dorothy Diebold using a “lock, stock, and barrel” contract—acquiring everything from the land and livestock to the very furniture in the farmhouse. Over the years, the Diebold family cultivated a diverse array of crops and livestock, building a life deeply rooted in the rhythms of the land. Today, that same spirit endures in every corner of the farm, from the grazing cattle to the lovingly preserved antique equipment.

Now specializing in pasture-raised beef, pork, chicken, and eggs, Toplands Farm is committed to responsible, transparent agriculture. Their beef cattle graze freely across open pastures, supplemented with farm-grown hay and a modest amount of grain for optimal flavor and tenderness. Their Berkshire pigs, known for their depth of flavor and exquisite marbling, are raised with care and fed a mix of garden vegetables and natural grains. Even the chickens are thoughtfully housed in mobile coops and are part of a rotational grazing system that reflects the farm’s deep respect for both animals and land.

But Toplands Farm offers more than food—it is also home to the Double D Living History Farm, which maintains the largest collection of restored antique tractors and farm equipment in the Northeast. Founded by Dudley G. Diebold, who began collecting as a boy, the museum showcases over 300 machines, an operating sawmill, and countless historical artifacts, all lovingly preserved on-site. Through its living history displays, pasture-raised meats, and longstanding family legacy, Toplands Farm continues to nourish both body and spirit while honoring the agricultural traditions that shaped this corner of New England.
Hours: Meat Shop open 1PM - 4PM or shop online through website

  • Pork (Berkshire pigs – known for marbling, tenderness, and flavor)
  • Chicken (whole roasting chickens, pasture-raised in small batches)

Eggs

Name: Townline Farm
Bio/Story:
Tucked away on scenic Baldwin Road in Woodbridge, Connecticut, Townline Farm offers a picturesque blend of tradition, sustainability, and community spirit. With its roots planted firmly in the local soil, the farm has become a beloved destination for both residents of Woodbridge and visitors seeking authentic farm experiences. From its modest beginnings, Townline Farm has grown into a beacon of local agriculture, celebrating all that the Connecticut countryside has to offer.

At the heart of the farm’s daily rhythm is a commitment to sustainable farming practices. Townline Farm carefully cultivates its land using methods designed to both nourish the earth and provide the freshest, healthiest produce possible. With grass-fed livestock and an array of seasonal crops, the farm is an advocate for responsible stewardship and environmental mindfulness. Their dedication to local, clean food is evident in every offering at their farm stand.

Beyond the produce, Townline Farm serves as a gathering place for the community. Throughout the year, the farm hosts family-friendly events and educational activities that forge meaningful connections between people and the natural world. Whether you're picking up syrup from the farm stand or attending a fall festivity, each visit to Townline Farm offers not just nourishment, but an experience steeped in tradition and care.

Name: Treat Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the heart of Orange, Connecticut, Treat Farm is a small family-run operation steeped in tradition and a deep-rooted commitment to local agriculture. For generations, the farm has opened its gates to the community, pairing fresh produce and fruits with warm-hearted hospitality. Every summer, the bounty of the harvest is shared directly with customers through a vibrant farm stand that emphasizes freshness and quality straight from the field.

Autumn transforms the property into a festive celebration of the season. Known for its beloved corn maze and hayrides, Treat Farm becomes a gathering spot for families seeking wholesome experiences and a touch of countryside charm. Visitors return year after year to take part in traditions that Treat Farm has carefully cultivated over time.

At its core, the farm is driven by a passion for creating meaningful connections between land, food, and community. Treat Farm takes pride in bridging the gap between growers and guests, ensuring that everyone who stops by leaves with more than just produce—they leave enriched by the authenticity and care that defines this enduring Connecticut gem.

Name: Trusz Farms
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the heart of East Granby, Trusz Farms is a living piece of Connecticut’s agricultural legacy. Known historically as a thriving tobacco farm during the 1930s through the 1950s, the property is a cherished local landmark. For over a century, the Trusz family has lovingly stewarded this homestead, preserving its heritage while cultivating a vibrant, evolving future.

Today, the farm has blossomed into a source of fresh, locally grown vegetables for the community, harvested daily and offered at their on-site farm stand. The Trusz family’s deep-rooted commitment is evident in their care for both the land and the local families who rely on their produce. Their stand is stocked seasonally with a rotating bounty, ensuring that no two visits are ever quite the same.

More than just a farm, Trusz Farms is a symbol of dedication—to agriculture, to tradition, and to the enduring value of honest, hard work. With plans already underway for future seasons, the Trusz family remains devoted to keeping the land productive and nourishing for generations to come. Visitors are always welcome, and the warmth of this historic homestead is felt in every ear of corn, clove of garlic, and carton of farm-fresh eggs they share.

Name: Tulmeadow Farm
Farm Type: Produce, Livestock, Dairy, Eggs, Honey, Syrup, Flowers, Plants
Bio/Story:
Tulmeadow Farm is one of Connecticut’s most enduring agricultural treasures, with roots reaching back to 1768. Nestled in the heart of West Simsbury, its 265 acres have been continuously farmed by the Tuller family for over 240 years. Originally known simply as the farm of its cultivator—as was common in early New England—it became known as Tulmeadow in the early 20th century, named after a meadow north of the cow barn and in homage to the family name. Over the centuries, the farm has evolved through many forms of production, from dairy cows and chickens to tobacco and Christmas trees, always adapting while remaining grounded in tradition.

In recent decades, Tulmeadow has embraced a direct-to-consumer model that reflects both old-world simplicity and modern sustainability. The bustling farm store sells everything from freshly harvested vegetables and pasture-raised meats to locally made jams, cheeses, and baked goods. Its greenhouse operations extend the growing season, and the beloved ice cream—made in-house since 1994—has become a regional icon. From field to freezer, every pint is crafted with care, earning Tulmeadow accolades and a loyal following.

Yet, beyond its wide array of offerings, Tulmeadow is a story of preservation and care. The Tullers work in partnership with the Simsbury Land Trust to ensure that this historic farmland and its surrounding forests remain protected for generations to come. With careful stewardship of the land, low-chemical growing practices, and a genuine passion for community, Tulmeadow Farm remains a living legacy—where the past is honored, the present is full of flavor, and the future is rooted in integrity.
Address: 255 Farms Village Road, Box 100, West Simsbury, CT 06092-2437

Name: Veronica’s Garden
Bio/Story:
Veronica’s Garden is a labor of love deeply rooted in the heart of Ridgefield, Connecticut. For over 28 years, Farmer Bob DiNucci has cultivated this land, transforming what began as a modest backyard hobby into a flourishing example of sustainable farming. Though not certified organic, Veronica’s Garden adheres strictly to natural practices—eschewing synthetic pesticides and using only organic inputs, compost, and non-GMO seeds. Each season brings new lessons, challenges, and rewards, all of which are met with unflagging commitment and ingenuity.

From their primary farm stand in Ridgefield and their second location in Danbury, the team offers an abundant selection of heirloom vegetables, seasonal greens, and hand-prepared items like farm-fresh pesto. Their CSA program, a cornerstone of the farm’s mission, connects the community to the rhythms of the harvest, offering members weekly boxes of the freshest local produce from June through October. Veronica’s Garden also proudly partners with regional markets and community organizations—including local social services and The Salvation Army—to expand access to healthy food and reduce food waste by donating surplus harvests to animal sanctuaries.

Weathering unpredictable seasons of droughts, storms, and frosts, the spirit of Veronica’s Garden remains deeply resilient. Farmer Bob, with a catalog in hand and dirt under his fingernails, is ever eager to explore new varieties and adapt to changing climates. With the help of devoted staff, loyal CSA members, and interns who return year after year, Veronica’s Garden continues to nourish not just the soil, but the community it serves. It stands as a beacon of dedication, integrity, and the simple, profound joy of feeding others well.

Name: Vibrant Farm
Bio/Story:
Vibrant Farm is a four-season, Certified Naturally Grown farm located in the heart of Litchfield County, Connecticut. Founded in 2021 by Meghan and Curtis Breuer, the farm was born of a shared desire to pursue a meaningful life rooted in sustainability, community, and connection to the land. Meghan and Curtis both studied geology at Union College and traveled the world together—Australia, New Zealand, the Bahamas—before leaving careers in environmental engineering and oilfield services to grow food, build soil, and nurture a deeper relationship with their surroundings.

Their farming journey began with apprenticeships and co-managing a diverse operation in New York. When that chapter closed, they launched Vibrant Farm on Old Mt. Tom Road in Bantam. Today, the farm thrives as a year-round operation, producing a diverse lineup of fresh greens, hearty roots, and fruit grown in greenhouses and nurtured through regenerative practices. From microgreens to winter squash, every harvest reflects their commitment to soil health, climate-resilient practices, and deep local partnerships.

Now heading into their fifth season, Meghan and Curtis have grown Vibrant Farm into a respected presence at area farmers' markets and on restaurant menus across Litchfield County. Their team—composed of passionate, community-minded individuals—helps bring each crop to life with intention and care. Through hard work and heart, Vibrant Farm has become not only a source of food but a force for good: a model of how small farms can feed communities while restoring the land and relationships that sustain them.
Address: 261 Old Mount Tom Rd. Bantam, CT 06750

Name: Wade’s Farm Fresh
Bio/Story:
Wade’s Farm Fresh is a treasured, family-run cornerstone of Bloomfield’s agricultural and community fabric. Born from humble beginnings as a dairy operation in 1919, the farm was cultivated by E.J. and Bess Wade with steady hands and uncompromising values. What began as a small roadside fruit stand grew into a larger farm store by 1969—a space that continues to flourish today under the stewardship of E.J. and Bess’s son and grandchildren.

The Wade family has long believed in one simple philosophy, passed down through the generations: “I don’t try to sell anything in my stand that I wouldn’t want to eat myself.” That sentiment, once quoted by E.J. Wade in a 1950 Hartford Times interview, still rings true every time a customer walks through the doors. Wade’s shelves are stocked with only the freshest produce, local honey, jams, baked goods, and pantry staples—all carefully selected and sorted by hand. Their motto of top quality and community care has endured for over a century.

Wade’s is more than a place to shop; it is a living history. From black-and-white photographs of the original stand to generations of Bloomfield families stopping in for fresh pies or summer fennel, it remains a beacon of consistency and charm in a changing world. The recent passing of Ronald F. Wade at the age of 91 marked not just the end of a remarkable life, but the continuation of a legacy rooted in integrity, nourishment, and hometown pride.

Name: Waggle Dance Apiary
Bio/Story:
Waggle Dance Apiary is a family-run beekeeping venture nestled in the quiet hills of Burlington, Connecticut. Guided by a deep reverence for pollinators, the family tends to their hives across the towns of Burlington, Colebrook, Harwinton, and New Hartford. Their mission is not merely to harvest honey, but to foster pollination, educate the community, and practice mindful stewardship of honey bees—those tireless workers whose well-being is so essential to our food systems and ecosystems alike.

At the heart of their offerings is a golden, unadulterated product: pure, raw, and unfiltered honey, sourced directly from their own thriving hives. By managing every step of the process—from hive health to harvest—Waggle Dance ensures the integrity and flavor of their honey is preserved in every jar. Their commitment extends beyond honey, with a thoughtful collection of beeswax-based goods such as lip balm, sugar scrubs, and artisanal soaps—all crafted with care and simplicity.

Waggle Dance Apiary reflects a beautiful blend of tradition and intention. Through local delivery, pickup options, and a presence at community events, they’ve become a cherished part of Connecticut’s local food landscape. By supporting Waggle Dance, customers not only enjoy the sweetness of local honey, but also join in a broader mission—to protect pollinators, nurture ecological balance, and celebrate the quiet magic of the hive.
Hours: Online Shop

Honey & Bee Products:

  • Pure, raw, unfiltered 100% Connecticut honey
  • Beeswax (various sizes)
  • Lip balm (made with beeswax)
  • Emulsified sugar scrub
  • Handcrafted artisanal soap

  • Gift cards (various amounts)

Name: Waldingfield Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the picturesque hills of Litchfield County, Waldingfield Farm has been a cornerstone of sustainable agriculture since its establishment as an organic farm in 1990. The farm originally dates back to the early 20th century when it served as a dairy farm, purchased by the current owners' great-grandfather, Mr. C.B. Smith. In the late 20th century, brothers Daniel, Quincy, and Patrick Horan reimagined Waldingfield, transforming the once dormant dairy land into one of Connecticut’s premier certified organic vegetable operations. Today, Waldingfield Farm is known for its vibrant heirloom tomatoes and diverse assortment of gourmet vegetables, grown responsibly through crop rotations, natural fertilization, and meticulous care of the soil.

The farm is committed to sustainability, utilizing practices like composting, green manure, and the complete absence of synthetic fertilizers or chemicals, ensuring a healthy, nutrient-rich harvest each season. Waldingfield's extensive produce list, ranging from leafy greens and root vegetables to succulent summer squashes and colorful tomatoes, is complemented by artisanal food products crafted to elevate the farm-to-table experience. Their community-supported agriculture (CSA) program, active farm stand, and consistent presence at local farmers' markets underscore their dedication to bridging the gap between the farm and local communities.

Owned and operated by brothers Patrick and Quincy Horan, Waldingfield Farm is a vibrant reflection of their passion for organic agriculture, community engagement, and environmental stewardship. Patrick, previously involved in finance and acting in New York City, and Quincy, inspired by his educational experiences out west, have cultivated not only a flourishing agricultural venture but also a rich community around organic farming. Waldingfield Farm continues to thrive as a beacon of sustainable practices, culinary quality, and local empowerment, inviting everyone to savor the freshness of organically grown produce directly from Connecticut’s fertile soil.

Name: Walnut Ledge Farm
Bio/Story:
Perched on a scenic ridge in South Glastonbury, Connecticut, Walnut Ledge Farm is a chemical-free, 14-acre family farm offering breathtaking views and beautifully cultivated land. Owned and lovingly tended by Michael and Joanna Kamis and their daughters, the farm has been in their care since 2005 and operational since 2013. With deep agricultural roots and a steadfast commitment to stewardship, the Kamis family carries on the legacy of a landscape that includes blueberry bushes nearly a century old and some of the state’s largest walnut and chestnut trees.

Walnut Ledge is best known for its vibrant Pick-Your-Own blueberry fields, a summer staple for the local community. But their offerings reach far beyond fruit. With over 10,000 garlic bulbs and hundreds of pounds of garlic scapes harvested annually, the farm has become a trusted source for this flavorful crop. In recent seasons, they’ve added elderberries, honeybee hives, and small-batch chestnut and walnut harvests—all tended using strictly natural, non-synthetic practices. Every plant is nurtured without pesticides or herbicides, and the farm’s homemade sea kelp and compost teas enrich the soil while protecting biodiversity.

The Kamis family’s mission is to grow food the way nature intended: clean, honest, and rich with flavor. Though they are not certified organic—due to proximity to conventional farms—they adhere to organic principles and strive for regenerative health in both land and crop. From the pollinators they cultivate to the soil they restore, Walnut Ledge Farm is a living testament to the belief that good food starts with integrity and ends in community. Whether you’re picking berries at sunrise or savoring the sweetness of garlic grown with care, life on the ledge is as nourishing as it is beautiful.
Address: 360 Matson Hill Road, PO Box 1, South Glastonbury, CT 06073
Hours: Monday–Saturday: 8:00 AM – 1:00 PM Tuesday & Wednesday: Additional evening hours 4:00 PM – 7:00 PM Closed Sundays

Name: Walrus and Carpenter Oysters
Bio/Story:
Founded in 2009 by Jules Opton-Himmel, Walrus and Carpenter Oysters has grown from a small passion project into one of Rhode Island’s most recognized oyster farms, supplying over 50 restaurants and markets locally and expanding nationally. With farms in Dutch Harbor (Jamestown) and Point Judith Pond (Narragansett), the company takes pride in producing two signature oyster varieties: the briny, beginner-friendly “Dutchies,” and the complex, sweet “Rocky Rhodes.” A third offering, “Thomas Points,” comes from a sister farm operated by their farm manager, grown over nutrient-rich underwater springs for a unique flavor profile.

Now owned by Brad Boehringer, the company blends hard science with sustainability and a lean farming philosophy—minimizing waste and constantly improving processes to benefit both the environment and product quality. Oyster farming plays a vital ecological role, filtering water, reducing nitrogen, and creating marine habitats. Their floating bag culture method ensures strong, shuckable shells and consistent quality.

Walrus and Carpenter Oysters prides itself on direct, same-day delivery to chefs, emphasizing freshness and dependability no matter the conditions. In addition to its wholesale program, the farm has launched local online ordering with weekly pickups and is expanding educational outreach through tours and community events. Their mission—“Farm the ocean, restore our estuaries, and feed our community”—reflects a commitment to regenerative aquaculture, culinary excellence, and local ecosystems.
Hours: Mon‑Thu 7 AM‑5 PM; Fri‑Sun closed

  • Oysters ("Dutchies," "Rocky Rhodes," "Thomas Points") – sold by the dozen

Pantry/Other

  • Shucking knife

Name: Whippoorwill Farm
Bio/Story:
Whippoorwill Farm in Lakeville, Connecticut, is a pastoral gem cultivated by husband-and-wife duo Allen and Robin Cockerline. Situated on 189 Salmon Kill Road, the farm has become a beloved destination for locals and visitors alike, known for its 100% grass-fed beef, heritage-breed chickens, and naturally raised pork. Allen, a lifelong farmer with over four decades of experience, is renowned for his mastery of pasture management, while Robin lends a warm, artistic touch to the farm’s daily rhythms and public presence.

The Cockerlines raise their animals with uncommon devotion and skill. Their cattle—crossbred from Angus, Devon, and New Zealand stock—graze rotationally, responding to Allen’s familiar call as they move through verdant pastures. The livestock are never given grain, hormones, or antibiotics. Pork and poultry are raised with the same attention to welfare, and all meat is dry-aged, vacuum-sealed, and frozen at peak freshness. Their store, open Fridays and Saturdays, is always stocked with a rotating selection of cuts, eggs, honey, and maple syrup—each reflecting the season and their meticulous care.

Beyond their products, Whippoorwill Farm has cultivated a deep relationship with the land and the surrounding community. Allen and Robin’s story—shaped by chance meetings, art school dreams, and the draw of the land—embodies the enduring spirit of small-scale, intentional farming. Their work has been featured in Yankee Magazine, The New York Times, and Rural Intelligence, and their products are cherished by chefs and home cooks across the region. This is not just a farm—it is a living, breathing philosophy rooted in flavor, stewardship, and place.
Hours: Open Year Round Fridays & Saturdays: 10:00 AM – 5:00 PM or by request via phone

Name: White Gate Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the heart of Southeastern Connecticut, White Gate Farm spans 100 acres of picturesque New England countryside. This organic farm has carved out a niche in the region by focusing on producing high-quality, health-conscious goods for its community. Their vibrant farm stand reflects their commitment to environmental stewardship and sustainable agriculture, offering fresh organic produce, poultry, and eggs to visitors each weekend.

A true family enterprise, White Gate Farm is not only a working farm but also a gathering place. From flower crown workshops to Mediterranean dinners and special seasonal events, the farm opens its gates regularly for community enrichment. Visitors come not just for the food, but also for the experience—critters tours for kids, cooking classes, rustic cabin stays, and farm-to-table celebrations round out the offerings, creating an immersive way to enjoy life on the farm.

At its core, White Gate Farm values integrity and health—both ecological and personal. Its mission is to nourish local families with nutritious food grown without compromise, while fostering a direct connection between land, farmer, and consumer. Whether it's Kevin’s sourdough bubbling in the wood-fired oven or the fresh kale bundled for market, every element is a reflection of the farm’s ethos: quality, community, and care for the earth.
Address: 83 Upper Pattagansett Road, East Lyme, CT 06333

Name: Why Not Farm
Bio/Story:
Why Not Farm is a small, family-run operation in the rolling countryside of Bethlehem, Connecticut, committed to raising animals ethically and providing clean, local food to the community. The farm specializes in Registered Black Angus cattle, along with chickens, turkeys, and eggs—all raised with care, respect, and a focus on animal welfare. Their herds are grass-fed year-round without the use of hormones or antibiotics, and poultry roam freely with access to indoor and outdoor pens.

The farm’s offerings are as thoughtful as they are diverse, with an array of premium meats available both by the cut and in bulk shares. Whether it’s Cryovac-packed steaks, whole roasting chickens, or farm-fresh eggs from Rhode Island Reds, everything is handled with a dedication to quality. Why Not Farm also embraces resourcefulness by offering pet treats made from dehydrated beef liver and chicken feet, homemade suet feeders for birds, and charming feather cat toys harvested naturally from the farm’s own birds.

Owned and operated by Susan Burkowsky, Why Not Farm is as much about community as it is about agriculture. They offer farm pickup, delivery, and shipping, ensuring that customers near and far can enjoy the fruits of their labor. With playful touches like their “12 Days of Cow-Mas” meat box specials and an upcoming line of hand-poured candles, Why Not Farm blends charm, practicality, and sustainability into everything they do.
Hours: 7 days a week. Hours may vary be sure to call ahead!

Name: Wild Harmony Farm
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the quiet charm of Exeter, Rhode Island, Wild Harmony Farm is a labor of love built on integrity and deep respect for land, animals, and people. Owned and operated by Ben Coerper, the farm exemplifies sustainable agriculture, offering pasture-raised chicken, certified organic pork, and 100% grass-fed beef directly from fields to families. Every animal is raised with care, ensuring both their health and the nutritional quality of the meals they become.

What began as a small-scale venture has blossomed into a thriving farm, thanks in part to the loyalty of local families and a strong belief in ethical farming. Wild Harmony Farm’s dedication to humane treatment is more than a practice—it’s a principle that guides every decision, from breed selection to rotational grazing methods. Shoppers can purchase meat in bulk, join a monthly subscription, or stop by the self-serve shed, open 24/7 for convenient pickup.

The heart of Wild Harmony beats in its mission: to nourish the community with food that heals. Testimonials from grateful customers speak of transformative dietary improvements, genuine customer service, and unforgettable experiences. Whether you’re preparing a wedding feast or introducing your children to nutritious meals, Wild Harmony Farm offers more than meat—it offers a movement toward health, harmony, and homegrown authenticity.

Name: Wishing Stone Farm
Bio/Story:
Tucked away on the scenic coastline of Little Compton, Rhode Island, Wishing Stone Farm has grown into a fixture in the local agricultural landscape. With its roots planted firmly at 25 Shaw Road, the farm began its journey into sustainable agriculture with a clear dedication to quality and community. Over the years, it has become a cherished destination for locals seeking fresh produce and seasonal staples.

Run by passionate growers, Wishing Stone Farm places integrity at the heart of its mission. Operating both an on-site market and participating in regional farmers' markets in Providence, the farm provides fresh goods throughout much of the year. Their emphasis on transparency is evident in their honor system market during the off months—reflecting a deep-rooted trust in their community.

From early spring to the chill of winter, Wishing Stone Farm adapts to meet the needs of Rhode Islanders. Whether selling directly from their farmstand or through city-based markets like the Hope Street Market and Farm Fresh Rhode Island Winter Market, the farm remains committed to accessible, locally grown food. Their story continues to thrive through ongoing dedication to land, labor, and the local economy.

Name: Woodstock Orchards LLC
Bio/Story:
Nestled in the rolling hills of Woodstock, Connecticut, Woodstock Orchards LLC is a family-owned and operated farm dedicated to growing its own fruits and vegetables on-site. The land serves as both a bountiful orchard and an inviting bakery, where high-quality produce and wholesome baked goods nourish both locals and visitors alike. Every piece of produce is grown with care and harvested at the peak of ripeness, embodying the farm’s unwavering commitment to quality and freshness.

Opened with a vision of sustainability and community, Woodstock Orchards embraces the dual traditions of farming and baking. The farm opens its summer season with a beloved crop of asparagus, widely considered some of the best in Windham County. A rich variety of vegetables—including tomatoes, peppers, onions, and specialty garlic—share the spotlight with hand-grown fruits like peaches, plums, apples, and blueberries, many of which are available for pick-your-own during the harvest season.

At the heart of Woodstock Orchards is a desire to offer more than just food—it hopes to cultivate joyful experiences. The team prides itself on creating a cheerful and family-friendly environment where every visitor feels welcome. By combining agricultural excellence with down-to-earth charm, Woodstock Orchards stands as a proud emblem of local flavor and honest work.

Name: Zentek Farms
Bio/Story:
Zentek Farms has stood as a proud pillar of agricultural excellence since 1914, cultivating a legacy that spans over a century. Family-run and deeply rooted in tradition, the farm has grown from humble beginnings to become one of the region’s premier wholesalers of annuals and vegetable plants. What began as a small, family operation has blossomed into a vibrant enterprise encompassing both greenhouse and outdoor growing spaces. The farm spans five acres of enclosed greenhouses and an additional three acres of outdoor fields, meticulously tended to ensure the highest quality crops.

Though Zentek Farms is widely respected in the wholesale market, they also maintain a direct connection with their community through a public retail farm stand. Here, customers can explore a diverse selection of flowers and vegetable plants nurtured directly on-site, offering a farm-to-table freshness that reflects their enduring commitment to quality.

Grounded in more than just soil, Zentek Farms is built on values of integrity, sustainability, and family heritage. Every bloom and plant offered by the farm tells a story of dedication and passion passed down through generations. As they continue to evolve and expand, the Zentek family remains faithful to their mission: growing not only plants, but lasting relationships rooted in trust and tradition.
Hours: Daily 9 AM–5 PM
